talk.start.para: took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.
â€”Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

petition.title: Forests
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

para.tab: We are dismayed at the continuing destruction of old growth and wilderness forests around Australia, despite the National Forest Policy Statement jointly signed by the Commonwealth and all States except Tasmania.

Intensive logging, most often to feed a voracious woodchip industry is underway or planned for many high conservation value forests. These forests should be protected by the commitments of the Commonwealth and State Governments under the NFPS.
These forests include:

petition.para: Coolangubra Wilderness and other areas of the S.E. Forests of NSW along with rainforest and other N.E. areas of NSW including Wingham, Mistake, Richmond Range, Chaelundi, North Washpool, Barrington and Dorrigo.
The Southern Highlands, Great Western Tiers and Tarkine Wilderness of Tasmania.
The Karri and Jarrah forests of S.W. Western Australia.
The Errinundra Plateau and other areas of the East Gippsland forests of Victoria.
The rainforests of the Proserpine region of Queensland.

para.tab: We request that the Government act urgently to protect our precious forests by utilising the Commonwealth's legal and constitutional powers, including:

petition.para: Refusal of export woodchip licences
Powers to control corporations
Protection of areas listed on the register of the National Estate
Protection and effective funding of areas identified for their World Heritage values.

para.tab: Genuine and effective action by the Government to protect these and other old growth and wilderness forests is critical. A comprehensive plantation strategy rather than exploiting native forests is the way forward for a truly environmentally responsible timber industry. We further request that the Government take effective action without further delay.

petition.title: UHF Transmission
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

para.tab: The petition of the undersigned shows that:

petition.para: 1.The UHF line-of-sight transmission is not suited to Tasmania's mountainous terrain.
2.It is unjust that compulsory UHF has resulted in poorer reception for many Tasmanians and that those living in weak "pockets" have outlaid of up to $450 in order to receive the signal.
3.It is unjust that many low-income Tasmanians and pensioners do not have the means to outlay hundreds of dollars so they can view their own television sets.
4.Compulsory UHF has resulted in some Tasmanians being denied a signal.

para.tab: Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled:
Call on the Government to:

petition.para: (a)honour its commitment to ensure that first class television reception is delivered to all the residents of Tasmania by providing additional funding for the urgent implementation of the necessary number of transmitters.
(b)provide all Tasmanians with access to their own national broadcasters, the ABC and the SBS.

petition.title: Homeless Rate Benefits
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

para.tab: The petition of the undersigned shows that:
1.We are concerned that teenagers are able to leave home by obtaining young homeless rate benefits without adequate investigation.
2.We believe that the flawed nature of the guidelines governing eligibility for young homeless rate benefits is in some circumstances encouraging family breakdown.

3.With the number of young people receiving youth homeless rate benefits increasing by a factor of ten over the past six years, we consider that there are insufficient programs to help keep families together.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should:
Call on the Government to:
(a) review the guidelines for young homeless rate benefits; and
(b) show a greater commitment to programs which prevent family breakdown.

petition.title: UN Convention on Desertification
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We, the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the proposed signing of the UN Convention on Desertification has the potential to adversely affect the rights of farmers to manage their farms, and of local authorities to govern their shires as well as infringing the constitutional responsibility of the states on land management issues.
We therefore request that the treaty not be signed without first receiving the scrutiny and approval of the Senate and subject to such reservations as the Senate might recommend.
As your petitioners in duty bound shall ever pray.

petition.title: Cellular Telephone Services
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

para.tab: That the residents of far East Gippsland vigorously support the introduction of cellular telephone services by the installation of a transceiver on Mount Delegateâ€”N.S.W.

petition.para: Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government:

para.tab: Facilitate the placement of cellular telephone transmitters to complete coverage in the electorate of Eden Monaro and areas of far East Gippsland before the end of 1994.

petition.title: Aircraft Noise
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned respectfully show concern that the Federal Airport Authorities admit that the Brisbane Airport `has come frighteningly close to tragedy' and that `it could only be a matter of time' before a passenger-laden jet crashes into Moreton Bay.

As over 46% of aircraft take off and land over residential areas of Brisbane, the likelihood of such a tragedy would have even more devastating results over thickly-populated areas. Aircraft noise is also becoming an increasingly serious problem as the volume of air traffic increases.

Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate takes urgent steps to ensure that the Cross Runway 14.32 is extended as originally planned, in the interests of eliminating aircraft noise and for safety reasons.

Dear Minister
I refer to the Protection of the Sea (Oil Pollution Compensation Fund) Regulations, Statutory Rules 1994 No. 126, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 2 June 1994.

Regulation 24 provides that the Australian Maritime Safety Authority may give notice requiring a person to produce a document or a copy of a document that is relevant to ascertaining the liability of a person to make a contribution to the fund. A failure to comply is an offence.

These measures appear to involve self-incrimination and the Committee would appreciate your advice on the reason for such provisions, which may infringe personal rights. In the circumstances it may be appropriate to undertake to amend the Regulations to remove the possibility of self-incrimination.
Yours sincerely
Mal Colston
Chairman
1 September 1994
Senator Mal Colston
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on
Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Colston

I refer to your letter of 30 May 1994 concerning the Protection of the Sea (Oil Pollution Compensation Fund) Regulations, Statutory Rules 1994 No 126, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 2 June 1994.

The Protection of the Sea (Oil Pollution Compensation Fund) Regulations were made to facilitate implementation by Australia of the International Convention on the Establishment of an International Fund for Compensation for Oil Pollution Damage, 1971.

When that Convention enters into force for Australia (not likely to be prior to 1 November 1994), oil companies operating in Australia will be required to complete, on an annual basis, a return that includes details of oil received by ship. The information provided must be certified by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) on behalf of the Australian Government in order to fulfil the obligations under Article 15 of the Convention to provide relevant data to the Fund established under the Convention.

The information provided by the oil companies and certified by AMSA will determine the contribution due from each company to The Fund. Regulation 24 is designed to enable AMSA to confirm that the information provided by an oil company is correct.

In practice, it is expected that the provision would need to be enforced rarely as the Australian industry has indicated full support of the Convention and the procedures necessary to ensure compliance.

The Committee's concern is noted and I have asked the Department of Transport to seek advice from the AttorneyGeneral's Department on this matter. I will be in a position to respond to your Committee's concern once that advice has been received.
Yours sincerely
LAURIE BRERETON
10 October 1994
Senator Mal Colston
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on
Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Mal
re: Protection of the Sea (Oil Pollution Compensation Fund) Regulations
I refer to your letter dated 30 May 1994 to my Minister concerning the Committee's concerns with the Protection of the Sea (Oil Pollution Compensation Fund) Regulations (the Regulations).

In his response, the Minister for Transport, the Honourable Laurie Brereton MP, undertook to have his Department seek the advice of the Attorney-General's Department and to respond to the Committee when that advice had been received.
The advice of the Attorney-General's Department has now been received and I have attached a copy of the advice.

You will note that the Attorney-General's Department is of the view that regulation 24 of the Regulations does not involve self-incrimination but merely requires a return for administrative purposes, no different to that required under many other legislative schemes. The imposition of the penalty for not complying with a request to provide a return is not connected to the liability to contribute to the Fund. It relates solely to the failure to provide information required for proper administration.
I trust that this advice has met the concerns of the Committee in relation to the Regulations.
Kindest regards
Neil O'Keefe
Parliamentary Secretary

Debate resumed from 10 October, on motion by
Senator Margetts
:
That the Senate take note of the report.

talk.start.para: â€”The inquiry by the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on the implications of Australian defence exports commenced on 9 September 1993. At that time the then Minister for Trade, Senator Peter Cook, referred the matter to the committee and outlined certain terms of reference for the committee's deliberations, including the definition as to what goods and services might constitute defence exportsâ€”traditionally, this has been something of a grey area; the guidelines, constraints and conditions governing Australian defence exports; the actual role of existing programs in facilitating defence exports; and to also look in a comprehensive way at the strategic, political, economic, international and human rights implications of defence exports and Australia's role in the construction of an effective international regime of monitoring and reporting on defence exports.

para.tab: This was a series of issues, therefore, that had very serious moral, political, economic, industrial and strategic dimensions and considerations grouped around the terms of reference. There is no question that it was a legitimate area of inquiry, and legitimate concerns were expressed to the committee as to the appropriate Australian industrial posture and profile, as to our role internationally and as to the guidelines which might govern the defence export industry.

The report that has been drafted by the trade subcommitteeâ€”it was submitted to the House of Representatives a day or so ago and is before the Senate this morningâ€”is, in my view, a balanced, thoughtful and deliberate report in terms of its review. It deals with very sensitive areas. I think every member of the committee is aware of the significance of human rights concerns. Certainly, the potential for linkage of defence exports with human rights issues and the potential for human rights abuses is clear and was one of the issues that was weighed up by the trade subcommittee in its evaluation. The legitimate demands of self-defence, of the right to protect sovereignty and of rights to guarantee security and independence were also weighed up by the trade subcommittee and by the joint committee as a whole.

At this point I think it is appropriate to acknowledge the much hard work done by the chairs of the trade subcommittee, Messrs Kerin and Duffyâ€”I think Senator Brownhill would be only too pleased to acknowledge thatâ€”and by the committee secretariat staff, particularly Jane Vincent, Bev Forbes and Annette Fischer, in the preparation of the report. It was an outstanding effort over time.

There is no question that the end of the Cold War brought with it a great range of opportunities for humanity. Not all of those opportunities have so far assumed a definite form. Some remain only potential. The strategic environment has unquestionably changed in some respects, as in relations in Europe there is now greater predictability and greater certainty. But in other parts of the world there is greater volatility, less certainty and, as the report makes clear, greater fluidity.

As well as that, the collapse of the Soviet empire, for example, and related matters mean there is a vastly increased potential for cheap and easy supplies of arms that are now surplus to the Cold War period and the Cold War doctrines. We confrontâ€”in Africa especially, but not confined to that continentâ€”circumstances where states simply implode, where the rule of order, as distinct from the rule of law, simply evaporates. We have seen the tragic consequences of those implosions in situations of recent times, such as Somalia and Rwanda. In both of those circumstances Australia has sought to play a very purposeful role.

We have also seen in different parts of the globe much more brutal conflicts than we have witnessed for a long time. Not since Vietnam have we seen conflicts of the savagery of Bosnia, or the impact of unrestricted arms trafficking upon circumstances whereby civilian populations suffer very greatly. Also, as everyone is aware, there is a greater potential, an increased potential, as a consequence of the end of the Cold War, in certain circumstances, for massive destruction to loom. I refer to the potentially disastrous adversarial situations that have loomed in recent times in the gulf and on the Korean peninsula. In these situations, with more arms being available and greater volatility, the committee looked very carefully at an appropriate Australian role. The deliberations of the committee very much reflected Australian opinion in the broad. A diversity of opinion was present not only on the committee but also in terms of the submissions received and the arguments advanced and considered.

International relations now are characterised in our region to an extent and globally by a degree of turbulence and disorder. That requires greater sensitivity in terms of what we do by way of defence exportsâ€”there is no question about thatâ€”in terms of the changing security environment and the changing demands upon us for a greater degree of accountability and a greater degree of control. Just to put matters into brief perspective, Australia, of course, is a relatively small defence exporter. The total value of Australian exports of defence and related goods, for example, in 1992-93 approached $37 million. Even allowing for some distortion or some lack of clarity because of the deficiencies in defence export data, it represents a minor part of total Australian exports, as the Senate would be aware. As a matter of fact, defence exports represent something less than one per cent of Australian exports of elaborately transformed manufactures which, in turn, represents about 14 per cent of Australia's exports of goods as a whole.

By contrast, the Australian Defence Force, the ADF, actually imported about $1.5 billion of defence equipment in 1992-93. I think those figures are interesting in terms of putting matters in balance. There is no question, though, that even given the relatively small size of defence exports, these issues need to be placed under close scrutiny, given the potential impact. The committee in its report endeavoured to outline issues such as the operations of the guidelines for export, including industry concerns regarding the processing time for export approvals, the role of customs in verification procedures, the defence export program, the implications of defence exports and, of course, Australia's international role.

In terms of the definitions, the committee was of the view that there needs to be greater clarity regarding what we mean by defence exports by the defence industry. In terms of that approach, there is no doubt that the committee's recommendations are entirely appropriate and will lead to a better regime overall. The committee was of the belief that there was a pressing need to develop a comprehensive description of both defence industry and defence exports. The deficiencies in the current definition are most clearly seen when it is endeavoured to apply the definition to estimate the value of defence exports. This is where conflict arises; this is where differing figures emerge.

As well as that, there are clear deficiencies in the collection of data. More needs to be done in this regard. Data on defence services, for example, which are now emerging as another area in which there is some degree of growth and potential, is not adequately captured or retrieved in the export definition and in the figures for exports of defence goods.

Actual exports may be greater than the current official data suggests, so we need a better definition, better focus and greater clarity in those areas. In terms of the overall guidelines that apply, there was agreement on the committee as well that these need to be reviewed periodically and that their operation ought to be the subject of a performance audit by the Auditor-General.

I know that a number of senators spoke a little earlier in the week on these matters. For example, I note that Senator Bourne spoke about the sensitivity of the area that was under investigation and of the implications of Australian defence exports. In the House of Representatives both Mr Gibson and Mr Langmore made some comments, and in large measure I can appreciate the concerns that they raised.

If we look at the application of the report overall, in an area where there had been little work done by the parliament it has proved to be a valuable document by way of stimulating public discussion and comment and will prove to be valuable in view of the recommendations being adopted. The committee was concerned at the number of difficulties that had been experienced. It was made clear that in a limited number of cases there had been some embarrassing failures. But the committee noted also that significant improvements had been made to the guidelines for approval of defence exports so that such issues as global and regional stability and potential economic, industrial, employment and technological benefits would be taken into consideration; Australia's strategic international relations would be weighed in terms of the decisions made; and the country's commercial credibility would be taken into account when matters were being considered.

Many submissions to the inquiry suggested that the decision making process needs to formally take account of foreign policy objectives, including human rights, as I have mentioned earlier. There is a clear recommendation in the report for a greater degree of cooperation, better communication and closer consultation between the Department of Defence and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade on these matters. I think that is one of the key findings of the report: that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade needs to have a more formal role in the process, and there is a specific technical recommendation to facilitate that.

Overall, the committee's report outlines that a defence exports effort within very clear and very firm guidelines is justified and that it can be achieved effectively without compromising foreign policy objectives and without compromising regional security. In fact, quite the contrary; it may be a very useful element in strengthening regional security and stability. However, some improvement to the approvals system is required to achieve this.

In conclusion, could I again commend the trade subcommittee of the joint committee for its work in the area. It has broken some new ground and it has definitely stimulated a greater degree of awareness in the broad, and a better focus and a greater degree of certainty in terms of the discussion and debate. The series of recommendations made, 1 through 20, are realistic and appropriate, in my view, and are capable of ready implementation; will serve to improve the regime; and will bring greater clarity to the area and a greater degree of public confidence as to what Australia is able to achieve in what is a highly sensitive area of policy making.

talker.name: Senator BROWNHILL
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

talk.start.para: â€”Mr Acting Deputy President, it was with great pleasure that I acted as deputy chairman to, first of all, Mr Kerin and then Mr Duffy, the current chairman of the trade subcommittee. Those two gentlemen have made a great contribution to the bringing down of this report. I agree with the sentiments expressed by Senator Loosley in congratulating them on the job they have done in chairing the committee. I also congratulate Beverly Forbes and Jane Vincent and the other members of the secretariat for the hard work that they have put in.

para.tab: The committee received 36 high quality submissions, representing a broad range of interests, and we took evidence from 44 witnesses at hearings in Canberra, Sydney and Melbourne. Among the recommendations made in the report, the committee highlights the need for matters of national and regional security to be of primary consideration when decisions regarding defence exports are taken. The minority report criticised the current policy of defence exports, saying that selling defence equipment in Asia fuels regional insecurity and promotes infringements on human rights.

I disagree with that point of view. Australia has always taken, and with this report will continue to take, a well-informed and balanced approach to exporting defence related goods and services. This is an issue which requires balance, and I think the guidelines that are in place for determining whether an export licence is granted reflect that need for balance. The points that have to be taken into account before granting an export licence include the implications for global and regional stability; the potential economic, industrial, employment and technological benefits that the specific export may have for Australia; and the impact on our regional and strategic relations and for our commercial credibility if we deny a country access to our defence goods.

A good example of this approach is the recent interest shown by Taiwan in buying up to six submarines from Australiaâ€”a deal which was worth about $3 billion. Despite the obvious economic benefits to Australia, it is unlikely the sale will go ahead as it would breach our current policies with China which ban all official ties with Taipei, including the sale of lethal weapons.

This report reinforces the constant need to balance our export control with export facilitation. It recommends that the guidelines be kept under continuous review with the changing economic and political realities of our region and of the world. It is ever-changing. We have had moves away from the Cold War and we now have little fracas going on in different places.

Looking realistically at the impact of Australia's exports on regional stability, it is clear that we are a very small player, especially when one looks at the hardware that is now becoming available within the superpowers following the end of the Cold War and the scaling down of armaments. Therefore, it can be said that the impact of Australia's involvement on a global scale is minimal. On the other hand, the benefits to Australia on a domestic level are great. The development of a specialised technology has far-reaching advantages for Australia's elaborately transformed manufactures, an industry which must be maintained and developed if we are to keep up with the technological advances of the rest of the world.

Apart from the obvious financial and development benefits, this report has also emphasised other advantages for encouraging the continuation and expansion of the export of defence related goods. These include the enhancement of Australia's strategic interests through regional engagement and trade negotiations. Through market development and trade in defence exports with our close neighbours, we can build a trustâ€”which is very importantâ€”and an understanding within the South-East Asian region. Furthermore, the continued development of our industries in this area promotes our own self-relianceâ€”a goal which Australia would dearly like to achieve.

This brings me to highlighting what I believe is one of the most important recommendations in the report, and that is the development of a comprehensive description of both defence industry and defence exports. It is important to realise that computer hardware, clothing and mechanical components can all be used in a military capacity and are therefore seen as defence goods. But the use of these types of items can be seen to be of great value to our trading partners outside the defence area. Because our neighbours lack the technological and manufacturing advantage that Australia has developed, they must turn to us and that can only be a good thing for Australia.

Exporting weapons and defence products will always require balance. If this balance is constantly maintained, Australia will continue to reap the economic and regional benefits of exporting our superior technology and goods. With the total valueâ€”I think Senator Loosley made mention of this earlierâ€”of Australian exports of defence and related goods in 1992-93 at some $36.8 million, the benefits are very clear for us to see.

Defence exports can help our own manufacturing base and our own self-reliance in defence equipment. If we do not export to good neighbours on the proper criteria set out, then someone else will and Australia will be the loser, as the export income and the good relations which come with those exports will be lost to us. I commend this report to the house.

Debate resumed from 12 October, on motion by
Senator Robert Ray
:
That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: â€”The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1994 covers a wide range of amendments to taxation legislation. It covers areas such as the reportable payments system; foreign investment funds and controlled foreign companies; regional headquarters income tax concessions; and social security payments. These, of course, will be dealt with in detail at the committee stage.

para.tab: I want to focus on the aspect of the legislation to which I alluded last nightâ€”the aspect which affects most workers. As a result of this legislation, the wages of many workers will, in fact, be cut by $28.40 a week. That will come as a great surprise to many workers who did not realise before the last election that the government's promise to provide $30 a week in home child-care allowance was conditional upon the money being taken away from the spouse; that is to say, the dependent spouse rebate would be abolished. That was not understood prior to the last election and, I believe, is still not readily understood by a lot of workers. So it will come as a surprise to them that their wages will, in effect, be cut by $28.40 a week.

The government argues that a number of carers do not receive the benefit of the dependent spouse rebate, that it goes into the hip pocket of the worker who, in most instances, is the male, while the mother cares for the children. The government also advanced the argument that a number of people were not receiving the dependent spouse rebate because they did not receive sufficient taxable income. That was also an important question.

However, I am concerned that this transfer from the hip pocket into the purse may well result in the same problems that arose from a similar transfer that occurred in 1976 in respect of the family allowance payments. At that time the taxation system handled tax rebates for dependent children. That was abolished and those rebates were cashed up into the family allowance systemâ€”in other words, it was a straight transfer from the hip pocket to the purse.

Since that time, successive governments have purloined from the purses of mothers something like $12 billion, and this is what worries me about the exercise that is now before us. As I said last night, if the government were concerned about the need to have the money actually go into the hands of the carer, then it could have done so by simply requiring the spouse, whether it be male or female, who was actually working to provide a certificate which showed that the money would be transferred to the bank account of the carer. That would have been a simple way of doing that. The other area in respect of those who are not receiving a sufficient income to benefit from the dependent spouse rebate could have been covered by the social security system.

As a result of what is being done, people will be quite disillusioned. I will give honourable senators an example. Applicants must fill in all sorts of formsâ€”and there are pages of themâ€”before they are eligible to get the home child-care allowance. It will be a bureaucratic headache for a large number of people, and it will be of great concern to ordinary people. Just compare this with the child-care cash rebate for people who may be in the work force. All they have to do is fill out a very simple form, go along to the Medicare office and get the cashâ€”virtually no questions asked. It is a very simple matter. On the other hand, look at what the mother in the home has to go through. She has to fill out all these formsâ€”and for what? For a mere $2.60 a week. Yet the child-care cash rebate is substantially more than $2.60 a week. In fact, it recognises that a carer is looking after at least two children.

I think mothers in the home deserve a great deal better than what this government is dealing out to them. I raised a whole range of matters, both in parliament and outside, when the home child-care legislation was discussed in December and February, and I pointed out various inequities and anomalies. For example, if the child-care cash rebate is non-income tested as a cost of earning income, why is not the same true where one spouse is working and the other is looking after children so the first spouse can engage in paid employment? That question has to be answered by the government at some stage.

Another anomaly is switching from the tax concept of annual separate net income to the social security concept. This means that many spouses who would have been eligible for the spouse rebate will get reduced home child-care allowance because expenses allowed in the tax system are not allowed under social security, and the social security concept of income embraces windfalls and gifts not regarded as income under the tax law. So that is another anomaly that has resulted.

Also, there are a number of people who will miss out as a result of this action by the government. Families leaving Australia temporarilyâ€”such as diplomats, service families and missionariesâ€”will be disadvantaged because they will have to pay full Australian tax. They will lose the spouse rebate, but they will not get the home child-care allowance because they are out of Australia for more than three months. I know the government has considered this question, but it is a matter it has overlooked. It has overlooked quite a number of matters. Families with dependent children over 16 will lose the spouse rebate at the with-child rate, but will not get the home child-care allowance. Again, that is a matter that the government has given some consideration to. When I raised those matters previously, the government thought that its scheme was perfect, but it is not perfect. In fact, since I raised those matters, others have re-emphasised the problems in shifting from the tax concept of a spouse rebate to a social security payment.

As noted in the
Hansard
report of 19 September of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, tax agents are starting to scratch their heads over clients with variable incomes needing to lodge up to 26 claims a year for home child-care allowance. And the public are not the only ones confused. Social Security is now sayingâ€”as we see from page 20 of the
Hansard
â€”that the self-employed are not to be income tested fortnightly but on the previous year's taxable income. I would like to see chapter and verse the statutory authority for that, given the great to-do that the minister made in February about the advantage of the home child-care allowance being a fortnightly income tested arrangement. Perhaps Senator McMullan could advise us as to the statutory authority for that.

As the tax lawyers in this chamber would know, the income of self-employed people by way of partnership or trust is only derived on 30 June, so they should be entitled to HCCA for 25 out of the 26 fortnights a yearâ€”that is if the minister and the department are correct in saying that HCCA is a fortnightly income tested payment. There is a whole range of these matters that really need to be discussed in the committee stage.

Is this a three card trick by the government? Why should the government not give mothers at home caring for their children the same benefits under the same income testing arrangements as those for the child-care rebate?
(Time expired)

talker.name: Senator McMULLAN
talker.role: Minister for Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”I would like to respond to a number of the issues raised in the debate on the second reading of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1994. A number of people were interested in this bill and raised a range of issues. But before I do that, it is important for me to emphasise that, as is usually the case with broad taxation laws amendment bills, the overwhelming majority of provisions in this bill appear to have and, as I understand it, do have the unanimous support of the Senate. Overall, the changes are positive ones for taxpayers and for the taxation system as a whole and that is something to be welcomed as part of the continuing progress of reform of the tax system.

para.tab: Essentially, four issues were raised in the discussion. Three related to amendments to the home child-care allowance, the provisional tax uplift, and the sales tax changes, particularly one aspect of them. The fourth issue relates to the points raised by a couple of speakers concerning the legislative framework for the reportable payments system, for which there are no amendments but about which people raised issues in the course of the debate on the second reading.

Debate on provisional tax uplift and the special matter of the amendment relating to the sales tax changes should be left until the committee stage. We have already had a lot of discussion about provisional tax uplift and there are no new issues of principle there. Debate about appropriate detail is therefore best left to the committee stage. As for sales tax, it is also a matter of the detail of the provision rather than a matter of broad principle. Therefore, in the interests of expediting the business of the Senate, I will leave those two matters for debate in the committee stage.

I would like now to turn to the reportable payments system. While no-one has proposed any amendment to the new proposal, Senator Boswell and other honourable senators raised some concerns about it. Broadly, those concerns go to whether this will be an intrusive and administratively burdensome system.

Not all honourable senators may be aware of the background to and underlying rationale of the reportable payments system because it has not been a particularly controversial announcement. As there have been no amendments, some honourable senators may not have paid much attention to it. I would therefore like to make some general points and then deal with the particular matters that have been raised.

The reportable payments systemâ€”or, if honourable senators will excuse the shortening of it, the RPSâ€”is not a tax collection system and it is not a new tax. It is a monitoring mechanism for compliance with the existing tax system. It is an income reporting arrangement to allow the tax office to compare taxpayers' income as they report it with information contained in the income tax return of the income recipient.

There is no discretion in respect of senators, most of the people in the gallery and those who are listening to the debate or who will read the transcript. We make regular PAYE deductionsâ€”fortnightly, or monthly, as the case may be. But for many other people, whose payments are made in other ways, the capacity to establish whether what is being declared as income is an accurate description of the income is not as straightforward.

RPS is another part of the mechanism for ensuring that the tax burden is being fairly distributed.
It is based on the tax file number arrangements that already apply in the employment and investment areas. Under RPSâ€”the reportable payments systemâ€”people receiving a reportable payment need only provide their tax file number to the person making the payment in order to prevent deduction of tax at source. In other words, as with other sources of income, if people provide their tax file number, no tax will be deducted other than in PAYE circumstances. But in these circumstances, that will not be the case.

However, if one chooses not to provide one's tax file number, tax will be deducted. This is logical: otherwise, firstly, there is no way in which compliance could be established; and, secondly, there is no way in which those people who are evading tax could be caught by this system. This is essentially a matter about enhancing tax compliance to ensure that the amount of income tax which is properly payable is paid.

There are predicted revenue gains for the Commonwealth: some people have said as much as $100 million. I cannot personally vouch for that; time will tell. To the extent that there is revenue gainâ€”and I believe there will beâ€”it will not be by way of imposition of a new tax; it will be by way of making people pay the tax for which they are already liable but which they are evading by non-disclosure.

A couple of areas have been nominated in respect of this system. The one that caused debate in the Senate was the fishing industry. The extension of the system to other areas will be considered only where the structure of transactions in those areas suits these sorts of income reporting arrangements and the level of tax compliance is such that the introduction of the system is warranted.

The tax office has been in consultation with affected industry representative bodies, including the National Fishing Industry Council, in respect of the application of the system to, and the development of the arrangements in, the fishing industry. This consultation has been designed to minimise the compliance cost of the introduction of this new system, but only in so far as we can do so without compromising the integrity of the arrangements. That is the rationale. It is not a new tax. The compliance costs as a result of consultation have been kept to a minimum consistent with effective and fair implementation of the system and ensuring that people pay the tax which they are properly obliged to pay.

The other issue that was raised was that of privacy, which always arises when we are considering matters such as the tax file number and similar matters. Let me assure the Senate that the Privacy Commissioner has been consulted throughout the process of the development and introduction of the system. We have made sure that the industries involved have been informed of the privacy requirements; all the relevant brochures and pamphlets produced will emphasise or contain information about privacy issues; and every endeavour will be made to inform those affected by the system of the obligations imposed on payers who have access to tax file numbers. I think most Australians consider that the obligation to comply with the tax system is important and one that should be pursued with rigour, and we will continue to do that.

Let me turn now to the issue that has been probably at the forefront of the debate about this bill, and that is the home child-care allowance. There are some people, including Senator Harradine, who have raised continuing concerns about its application over the period of the introduction of this system. But first I will go to the core of the matter before dealing with some of the concerns and claims that have been made. I will try to respond to some of the detailed issues in the time available.

The core of the matter is that this is, and is seen by Australians to be, an improvement in the method of, and an increase in, the amount of government payments to families. It is a proper recognition by the government of its obligation to provide assistance to Australian families and to do so in a fair way. In this instance that includes directing the payment to the carer rather than to the income earner, as is necessarily done through the tax system, and increasing by some $230 million per annum the amount of the payment.

All the indications are that it is, and is seen to be by Australians, a significant improvement in the operation of, the targeting of and the amount of payments to Australian families. It was an important election commitment of the government in May 1993, and its current implementation has been welcomed by families as the money is beginning to flow in this fortnight.

Although I do not think it is formally required by the standing orders, I suppose that, both in this matter and in relation to provisional tax, I should declare an interest, because my household is likely to be a recipient of this payment. For reasons of tax payments, I have to pay provisional tax, so I am affected by at least two of the measures involved here. With my well-known aversion to fish, people can be assured I am not going to be affected by that one, but I am affected by the other two. I do not think the standing orders require us to declare an interestâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”So you're declaring you're losing your spouse rebate too?

â€”Very clever. All I am saying is that I am affected by a tax measure before the parliament. I do not think that the standing orders require us to declare an interest because it is only an interest shared by other Australians. But because I will be involved in the detailed debate in the committee stage, I am informing the Senate.

para.tab: It is an important reform, one that is being welcomed by Australians. It is an important addition to the range of assistance provided to families. It has the major advantage of being paid directly to the parent with the caring responsibility. It is, in the broad scheme of things, inevitable in the debate in the Senate that people focus only on the losers. Let me give some comments about the winners from the introduction of this measure. When a measure increases the cost by $230 million, it means there is $230 million extra being paid to Australian families as a result of this payment. The families which benefited from the with-child rate of DSR will be better off, because it is paid at a higher rate. That is the first thing. It is not a big increase but it is a welcome increase.

There are some well targeted and important other things. I will mention just one. About 55,000 families with low taxable incomes who are unable to obtain the full value of the dependent spouse rebate will be, on average, $20 a week better off. That is not a bad start, over and above the increased payment and the improved targeting of the payment in general. There are around 120,000 families which will benefit from the greater responsiveness of the payment.

talk.start.para: â€”I mentioned those.

â€”I understand that. Not everybody does, but I understand that Senator Harradine did. If I have time I will respond to that pointâ€”or we will deal with it later in the committee stage. I will try to get to one of those points during my response. I was talking about the greater responsiveness of the child-care allowance to people's changing circumstances. Also, the annual amount a dependent child can earnâ€”and the family can still qualifyâ€”is more generous. In summary, there are benefits from these changes which are substantial and which greatly outweigh the relatively small impact that the change will have on a small number of families.
â€”Keating said no family would be worse off; that is what he said in the election. You can't squirm out of that.

â€”Senator Patterson has invented that furphy to suit herself. It is not true. She said in the previous debate in this house that `the vast majority of people will be better off', which makes it quite clear that she always knew that this would be, as it is, a great benefit to the vast majority.
â€”What did Mr Keating say?
â€”He said that this will be a significant enhancementâ€”and he is right.
â€”Are you rewriting history, too?

â€”No, Senator Newman is. I can tell her about the history quite simply. We made this proposal before the election. It was popular, as it deserved to be, and we are implementing it. It provides $230 million in extra benefits to families. They like it and those opposite do not. It is as simple as that. So we have this complaint that we misled people but my clear advice is that the Prime Minister never said there would be no loser. What he did say in the election speech, which I listened toâ€”I suspect those opposite did notâ€”is that this allowance is more generous than the dependent spouse rebate it will replace. He never made any secret about the fact that it would replace the rebate. That is the extent of the claim. It is $230 million more than the dependent spouse rebate. All the advertising saysâ€”
â€”They get $60 a fortnight.

â€”One of the wonderful things is that some of the lowest income families in this country are going to be very substantially better off in ways that I think all Australians will welcome. A bit of carping about it on the sidelines only helps us to highlight the contrast between our providing effective assistance to families in the greatest need and those opposite, who do not have any policies. They need to carp and express concern because they do not have any policies of their own.

para.tab: I understand that the claim which has been made that there will be up to 200,000 losers has been based on an estimate of the total number of people receiving the part-rate with-child DSR. It is nonsense to say that all those people will be losers. The majority of them will be winners also. Most part-raters will benefit from the increase in the maximum rate, which will flow up the line to them. Some of them will gain much more because their taxable income was too low to get the maximum DSR. Some will gain because they receive a part-rate DSR due to having a part-time job for a few weeks of the year. A number of other groups will be in the same or a slightly better position. Those getting part-rate because of bank interest and those with shares will have, as I understand it, no change.

Latest available estimates from the Australian Taxation Office show that in 1992-93 about 680,000 families received the with-child rate of dependent spouse rebate. The home child-care allowance data available to date shows that as many families who in 1992-93 got the maximum rate with-child DSR are already receiving the maximum rate of home child-care allowance after only 10 days of operation. A much higher proportion of these grants are being made at the maximum rate than was the case with the dependent spouse rebate in the year 1992-93. Those are important facts to put on the table.

We expect the total number of parents receiving the home child-care allowance to increase as claims continue to be lodged. At the moment they are coming in at a rate of around 20,000 per week. As I am about to run out of time, I indicate now that I will deal with the rest of the details relating to this matter in the committee stage. I will address then the detailed matters which senators have raised.
(Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Colston)
â€”I advise the committee that a running sheet has been circulated for the committee stage of this bill. Is it the wish of the committee that we proceed in accordance with the running sheet?

Senator Short
â€”I have not seen it.

talker.name: Senator McMULLAN
talker.role: Minister for Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”While Senator Short is looking at that I will take this opportunity to say that, first of all, that procedure is acceptable to us and I think it is in accordance with the normal practice. I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendments to be moved to this bill.
â€”Is it the wish of the committee that we proceed in accordance with the running sheet? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

para.tab: Clauses 1 to 5â€”by leaveâ€”taken together.

talk.start.para:
â€”I have a couple of brief comments to make which relate to clauses 4 and 5. I might make those comments now, even though there may be some reference to clause 5. I draw the attention of the government and the minister to the article that appeared on the front page of the
Australian Financial Review
in the last couple of days concerning the implications of the reportable payments system for the fishing industry.

para.tab: The national Fishing Industry Council has argued that the provisions of the bill implementing the reportable payments system will increase compliance costs for the industry by imposing further unnecessary and unproductive paperwork and administration, particularly for those who are already complying with the tax laws. In addition, the Fishing Industry Council argues that the bill's RPS provisions do not address the real issues facing the industry, in particular fish poaching and tax evasion through direct selling.

The council argues that the expected additional taxation review is likely to be significantly less because of poaching and tax evasion, which they allege the RPS system will encourage. I do not know whether the minister has had a chance to look at that matter. I am sure the council and certainly the opposition would welcome any comments he might have on that. It does seem to be a serious point as far as the fishing industry is concerned. I do not know whether it has any wider application but the fishing industry is an important industry in its own right.

talker.name: Senator McMULLAN
talker.role: Minister for Trade)

talk.start.para:
â€”I am not personally familiar with the concerns that Senator Short has raised. I know it is one of those balance issues that has arisen since the time of William Pitt and the rate of tax on the import of wine, in dealing with smugglers, and trying to reduce the tax to get more revenue. So it has been an issue of public policy for 700 years. But it seems to me that we cannot fail to pursue a matter that requires people properly to disclose the income they earn for fear that some of those who fail to do so deliberately will go to even more elaborate lengths to evade. I accept that some may. There is no evidence yet, but I certainly cannot say that it is impossible. That is a question for subsequent pursuit.
It seems to me they are certainly more likely to be exposed or capable of being pursued with regard to it.

para.tab: The Taxation Office may have more to say on the matter. If it does, I will either pass on the information during this debate or drop Senator Short a note about it. Broadly, it is something we will have to monitor. Conceptually, I think the system is right. It seems on the face of it to be the logical place to start, because there are a small number of payers paying to a large number of people in an area where there is not a PAYE system operating. So it seems a logical place to start. On the basis of the survey experience, I understand it is considered by the Taxation Office to be appropriate. I cannot go beyond that.

talker.name: Senator BOSWELL
talker.role: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

talk.start.para: â€”I also want to raise some concerns, having spoken to the fishing industry in Queensland. This new reportable payments system is being imposed on them. I think this also applies to the clothing sector. Both of those sectors of industry are not PAYE systems; they are paid on performance. In other words, a deck hand on a boat is paid by way of a percentage of the catch.

para.tab: The problem which arises here is that when fishermen sell fish to a wholesaler, they have to then give the tax file number. That wholesaler may sell it to another wholesaler; it may go through four or five different wholesalers before it reaches a retailer. That is going to put a lot of paperwork into the system. The fishing industry tells me it has a clean bill of health from the Taxation Office. It recognises that there is limited or very little evasion in the fishing industry.

The fishing industry has asked me to ask for a review of the case of the industry to see whether this measure is going to stamp out tax evasion and whether it will stamp out illegal fishing. People who do not have a fishing licenceâ€”they are known in the industry as shamateurs, halfway between an amateur and a professionalâ€”do not pay any levies. They will still be able to sell their fish.

Some people might have a job that allows them some time during the day when they can go out and fish; they may be firemen or policemen, or someone like that. These people have days when they can go out and fish and they retail their fish to fish shops and wholesalers without paying tax. The fishing industry does not believe that this reportable payment system will make it harder for those people. In fact, the industry is saying it will make it easier for those people to bypass the system, and it will impose a lot more costs on the fishing industry.

I am asking the minister whether, after a period of 12 to 18 months, he will give consideration to reviewing the cost-effectiveness of keeping amateurs out of the industry. If it is not effective, will the minister withdraw the proposal? This proposal was originally designed by the Taxation Office. I understand that the Taxation Office told the fishing industry that it would be a good way to move these people who were not registered fisherman out of the industry. Can the minister give me a response to the fishermen's concerns?

talk.start.para: â€”I raised this matter about the fishing industry last night. I felt that it might have been better to have this new division deferred so that we could have a more extensive inquiry. This is a very important matter, and it was not thoroughly ventilated before the Senate committee. I agree with Senator Boswell's reasonable request that there be a thorough investigation carried out in respect of this matter after a period of 12 months to see how it is affecting the fishing industry. I also want to go into a number of other matters regarding the reportable payment system. I refer to the definition of reportable payment on page four.

talker.name: Senator McMULLAN
talker.role: Minister for Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”Senator Boswell made two preliminary points before the point that both he and Senator Harradine made to which I will also respond. With regard to the extra paperwork: I said during the second reading debate that we have been in discussion with the Fishing Industry Council seeking to minimise the cost of compliance consistent with maintaining the integrity of the system. It is not as if this is an area where there is no paperwork or in which people have no obligations now to report to the tax system. It is not going to require the development of a new system. It is consistent with our overall approach. We will seek to keep the paperwork to a minimum, but I cannot guarantee that it will be nil.

para.tab: Senator Harradine asserted in his speech during the second reading debate thatâ€”and I did not want to respond to it in a way that would be controversial or give offence to the honest people in the industry, of which there are many, I acceptâ€”this is an industry with a very high record of compliance. I have not been closely involved with the administration of the tax system since the last election, but I have to say that, overall, that is not consistent with my recollection of the surveys that were undertaken when I was involved.

I do not wish to say that is in any way a slur on many of the people in the industry whom I know are honest citizens and are paying their proper taxes. There is no doubt that there are many in that area who are that way inclined; but I cannot say regionally whether there is some variation in that because I do not have any evidence to base it on. There is a view that there is a compliance problem within this industry. If there is not, then that will show up reasonably quickly in the paperwork.

That brings me to the point that both Senator Harradine and Senator Boswell raised as to whether we can in some way monitor the impact of this. That is something which I have raised with and will refer to the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear), who is the minister directly responsible. I assure the committee that there will be some form of follow-up to monitor cost-effectiveness.

Let me qualify it now so that when it comes back there is not some sense that, in giving that assurance, I have given something we could not deliver on. Firstly, as I am advised, the industry specification of sources of taxation revenue is probably less than perfect; so the base may not be ideal. Secondly, there are consequential changes. Once this system is introduced, it is possible that some of the people involved will move into the PAYE system and out of this system of payments, because the benefit of not being in the PAYE system will be reduced. The figures will not be unambiguous, and I make that clear right from the start.

It is reasonable to request that we make some attempt to monitor industry by industry the consequences of this. I cannot give honourable senators a guarantee about how comprehensively we will be able to do that, because of the problems in the statistical base from which we are working. Some of the parallel changes that will go on that will not be identified as consequences of this change will show up in other parts of the statistics. I make those qualifications beforehand so that, when the report, such as it is, is developed subsequently, people do not accuse me of not having fully advised the Senate. I accept the broad thrust of the point the honourable senators have made and will seek to do that.

talk.start.para: â€”I ask the minister to take into consideration clause 5 of the bill at this stage, because it is very awkward to talk about clauses 1 to 4 without referring to clause 5.

para.tab:
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Colston)
â€”Is it the wish of the committee that we take clauses 1 to 5 together? There being no objection, it is so ordered. Does the minister wish to move government amendments to clause 5 at this stage?

speech.speaker: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

talker.name: Senator McMULLAN
talker.role: Minister for Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”by leaveâ€”Yes, I think it might be most appropriate if I did so. I move:

speech.para: 1.Clause 5, page 6, proposed paragraph 220AF (1)(c), line 3, omit "1 November 1994", substitute "1 December 1994".
2.Clause 5, page 8, proposed subsection 220AJ (4), lines 21 to 23, omit the proposed subsection (but not the penalty at the end of proposed section 220AJ), substitute the following subsection:

para.emphasis: Section not to apply to pre-1 December 1994 payments

para.tab: "`(4) This section does not apply to a reportable payment made before 1 December 1994."

speech.para: I think these amendments are well known and understood.

para.tab: Amendments agreed to.

talk.start.para: â€”The question now is that clauses 1 to 5 stand as printed.

â€”Following Senator McMullan's statement, I feel that will not really achieve a great deal. For example, the fishing industry has made a last minute appeal. It thought everything was okay. Obviously the industry has been in close contact with the Taxation Office and, at the last minute, has realised that everything is not okay.

para.tab: I must have misunderstood or misheard Senator McMullan, because I thought I heard him say that the clause that we are considering does not impose any further paperwork.

talk.start.para: â€”No.

â€”So the minister did not say that; I misheard it. Clearly, there is extra paperwork. I wish to refer to page 4 and the definition of reportable payment. Reportable payment means a payment that `is declared by the regulations to be a reportable payment for the purposes of this Division'. Does that not enable the government to extend to the whole of the economy by regulation a massive expansion of paperwork and bureaucracy which will be a disguised tax on employment and business?

para.tab: Here we are giving the government open slather. I do not know what we are doing that for because the definition makes it perfectly clear that a reportable payment means a payment that is declared by the regulation to be a reportable payment. We know what the government considers to be a reportable payment and now by regulation it can virtually say what it likes.

The second point, interestingly enough, is that reportable payment means a payment that is assessable income. It might well be that an employer does not know what is assessable income for the purposes of the payee. The payer may not know in respect of moneys provided to the payee what may be assessable income. For example, if one sells one's car, does the payer know whether it is a personal or a business car? These are the sorts of things that may or may not have been considered by the officials. Certainly, it will cause a lot of confusion.

Finally, the penalty is set out in proposed new section 22OAF(2) on page 6 of the bill. If these things are not done by the payer, the payer must deduct 48.4 per cent of the payment. The minister, although not seeking to belittle the position, seemed to say, `If the tax file number is not given and certain other requirements are not observed'â€”for example, the one that I am talking about nowâ€”`then the payer must deduct 48.4 per cent of the payment.'

Take the case of a fishing contractor who is working for a payer. That contractor may have commitments. In fact, almost 100 per cent of the amount he receives from the payerâ€”the employer; the principal contractorâ€”might be outgoings for his workers or to buy a boat or something like that.

Under this system, the government is deducting 48.4 per cent of the outgoings of a person's responsibilities to his or her employees. Why is that amount included at such a high rate? Should it not be compared with, for example, the 15 per cent to 25 per cent that is applied under prescribed payments schemes? Why is there such an enormous penalty when, for example, an employer could be confused and not know what is assessable income?

talker.name: Senator McMULLAN
talker.role: Minister for Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”Senator Harradine has raised several points, and I will need to deal with the last one in more detail. Senator Harradine asked why it is proposed that we proceed by way of regulation. He would know better than any honourable senator that those regulations are all subject to the scrutiny of, and the potential disallowance by, the Senate; that is one thing of which he is the master. But we would not want to deal with each instance by way of a bill.

para.tab: Certainly, this proposal is consistent with the way in which the prescribed payments systemâ€”which is the closest analogyâ€”operates. It is not as though there is an incentive for the government to declare lots of these payments because, in areas where we are already getting revenue, it is expenditure for the government for nothing. Even if some senators are very suspicious of the assurances that I give, I can say that there is no incentive or benefit for the government to do that. I can assure honourable senators that we would proceed with that very cautiously. The development of these regulations is being done with very close consultation with the industries concerned. I put that on the record.

With regard to the withholding of 48.4 per cent of a person's income if a tax file number is not supplied, all we are proposing to do is deal with people under this system in exactly the same way as every other person is dealt with when a tax file number is not supplied, including under the prescribed payments system. If a tax file number is supplied, 15 per cent or 20 per cent is withheld, and that is more comparable with the PAYE system. We are not proposing to do that here.

Under the PPS, the normal PAYE system, bank interest or whatever source of income is involved, if a tax file number is not supplied, 48.4 per cent is deducted. There is a simple reason for that: if that were not the case, people in the highest tax bracketâ€”who pay 48.4 per centâ€”would benefit from not providing a tax file number, compared with people on lower rates of tax who would not benefit. The system could not operate fairly at other than the top rate.

We do not want anybody to pay us under this clause. Our objective is that nobody will pay us, because we want everyone to declare. It is not a revenue measure for us. We hope that nobody pays under this clause. It is a safety net to ensure that people do not have the incentive not to declare and that there is not a skewed advantage in favour of those people in the higher income bracket.

talker.name: Senator BOSWELL
talker.role: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

talk.start.para: â€”The minister raises a very pertinent issue. Firstly, he is right: nobody will pay. The honest people will declare their tax file numbers while the people who are going to bypass the system will be greatly encouraged to bypass the system.

para.tab: In his contribution, Senator McMullan raised the matter of prescribed payments. That is exactly the problem that the fishing industry is trying to avoid. People in the fishing industry know the problems that prescribed payments present to those in the cottage building industry. Even builders with only two or three carpenters and who use subcontractorsâ€”painters, tilers, bricklayers and electriciansâ€”are spending up to two days a month filling in their forms.

Not so long ago I held a meeting at my house attended by builders in the district. They pointed out to me that no new builders are starting up in the cottage building industry because, for every 30 days that they could work, there are probably two days of non-productive time taken up with paperwork. They pointed out that the average age of builders around the district was 58 or 59 and that no new people were coming through. Meanwhile, the ones staying on are getting rid of as many people as they can and using subcontractors.

That is exactly why people in the fishing industry do not want to get caught in this trap. They see that the paperwork will increase and that, instead of being out fishing and earning money, they will be stuck in the office filling out these forms. They also maintain that it will not in any way reduce the amount of tax evasion. They will still be paying their tax but the amateurs or shamateurs will still be avoiding tax, selling their product over the fence to neighbours or in the pub or direct to the retailer.

Those people are sayingâ€”as Senator Harradine is sayingâ€”that the government will not derive any useful benefit from this measure. They are saying that, if the government thinks there will be a benefit, they are prepared to try it out, but that it should not be allowed to go on forever without review. They will give it a go but, if at the end of, say, 18 months it is not found to be effective in keeping out the amateurs, the government should withdraw it. That is the commitment that they are asking the government to give.

The minister has given a sort of half-hearted commitment. I do not know how that will be implemented. I do not know whether he will come back in 18 months time and say it has been a goer or it has been totally useless. Perhaps the minister can tell the committee how he plans to carry out that proposal.

talker.name: Senator McMULLAN
talker.role: Minister for Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”I certainly do not intend to make up government policy on the run, which I would have to do to give a detailed response to Senator Boswell. In the three years for which I was responsible for tax policy, every industry for which a new system of tax collection was proposed told us with absolute certainty that there would be no extra revenue from it. In the main, that did not turn out to be the case.

para.tab: There is an understandable concern before a system starts to operate that it might be very complex. The fear of the unknown is common. People can anticipate enormous problems and create castles in the air, but in the main they are not as great as imagined.

I accept that compliance takes more paperwork than non-compliance; that is true. That is why the honest people who are already paying would like to see us gather tax from those who are not paying. The honest people in the fishing industry and the other industry affected will be better served by us requiring the dishonest people to pay as well and so make the system fairer. That is the broad point.

With regard to Senator Boswell's specific request, I am not the minister responsible, but I have undertaken to refer it to the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear). I cannot and will not here make up how this is going to be administered, but I note Senator Boswell's point. It is not a new point; the industry has discussed it with us. We will report back at the first stage at which we have a full level of figures for a full financial year. I do not think 18 months will meet that requirement, but I do not want to get into that sort of detail now. Senator Boswell can understand the delayed payment of it.

I think in 18 months time we still will not be in a proper position to assess it. I will refer it to the Assistant Treasurer. I do not think I am in a position to formalise it because I cannot make a commitment on his behalf in this sort of matter, as it is essentially administrative and some of the responsibility lies in the discretion of the tax commissioner.

It is in the government's interest, as well as the industry's interest, to monitor the system. If this system is not generating extra revenue, there is no benefit for the government in incurring the cost of implementing it. We will keep an eye on it and will seek to keep in consultation directly with the industry, which is, I think, the best way to do it and which I give Senator Boswell an undertaking we will do.

talk.start.para: â€”There is a final issue I want to raise in respect of this clause. Under this provision, is it possible that a householder would be required to obtain a payee's tax file number? Say, for example, it is winter time, the guttering is rotted and the householder requires a plumber to fix the guttering. Is it possible under this clause that that householder may be required to demand from the plumber the plumber's tax file number and, in the absence of that plumber's tax file number, would be required to deduct 48.4 per cent of the payment and pay that to the Taxation Office?

talker.name: Senator McMULLAN
talker.role: Minister for Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”Those sorts of payments are already covered by the prescribed payments system. The only way in which a household activity such as that would be caught upâ€”it would not be under this clause, but under the prescribed payments systemâ€”is if the value of the work being done were above the minimum threshold, which is $15,000. Provided the work being done was less than $15,000, which all the sorts of examples Senator Harradine is talking about would be, there would be no requirement for a TFN relationship between the tradesperson or worker and the householder.
â€”What then is the purpose of new subclause (f) in respect of the making of pensioner exemption declarations as an alternative to quotation of the tax file number?

speech.speaker: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

talker.name: Senator McMULLAN
talker.role: Minister for Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”I am advised that the purpose of that is to ensure that pensioners are taken out of this system. Simply asserting that they are a pensioner would be sufficient to take them out of the system. It is to give a guarantee of that, as I am advised.

para.tab: Clauses 1 to 5, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 6 to 50â€”by leaveâ€”taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 51.

speech.para: Clause 51, page 44, lines 22 to 26, omit paragraphs (b) and (c), substitute the following paragraph:
"(b)to reduce a taxpayer's entitlement to a rebate of tax in respect of a dependent spouse if home child care allowance is paid to the spouse.".

para.tab: Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 52 to 56â€”by leaveâ€”taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 57.

speech.speaker: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

talker.name: Senator McMULLAN
talker.role: Minister for Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

speech.para: Clause 57, page 46 (line 32) to page 47 (line 33), omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

para.tab: "57. Section 159J of the Principal Act is amended:

speech.para:
(a)
by omitting from subsection (1B) `1 or';

(b)
by inserting after subsection (5D) the following subsection:

tab.tab: (a)after taking into account any reduction because of the application of any other provision of this section, a rebate is allowable to a taxpayer under this section for a year of income in respect of a dependant who is the spouse of the taxpayer; and

speech.para: the rebate is to be reduced or further reduced, as the case requires, by the amount, or the sum of the amounts, of the home child care allowance.';

tab.tab:
(c)
by inserting `home child care allowance,' before `or a child disability allowance' in paragraph (a) of the definition of `separate net income' in subsection (6).".

speech.para: I will speak to this amendment when there is subsequent debate.

speech.speaker: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

talk.start.para: â€”The coalition will not be supporting this amendment moved by the government, because it leaves thousands of families worse off. Whatever the minister said at the end of the second reading debate, Mr Keating said before the last election that the home child-care allowance was more generous than the dependent spouse rebate.
â€”That is right.

â€”For many families it is not more generous than the dependent spouse rebate. Previously, I have gone through the families that will not be better off and for whom it will not be more generous. We will not be supporting this amendment because we will not let Mr Keating and this government get away with breaking another one of its election commitments. It said that families would be in receipt of $30 and that they would be better offâ€”it was more generous. Senator McMullan knows that many families will not be better off.
â€”But you know it is more generous. You are just wishing it was not. You know it is more generous; $250 million more generous.

â€”Not every family who is in receipt of the dependent spouse rebate will be better off, so it is therefore not more generous. For many people, it is not more generous. As I have said before, the home child-care allowance has been a disaster from the beginning to the end. I bet the people in the Taxation Office cannot believe the way they have to deal with the people in the Department of Social Security and the difficulties they have encountered with transferring this allowance from Taxation to Social Security.

para.tab: It is a commendable first step in the recognition of the role of parents, mostly mothers, caring for children at home. But it began as a deception, a pea and thimble trick on the part of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in the election speech, and it has deteriorated into what can only be described as a bungle and a debacle. When the home child-care allowance was first before the parliament, I raised a concern at the number of people who are unlikely to benefit from this new allowance or who would receive a substantially lower benefit from it than they presently receive from the dependent spouse rebate. That was the first time that was ever brought to public attention.

This government was not going to tell people, `Look, I am awfully sorry, it is more generous for some, but there are a lot of you who are going to miss out or who are going to get less money than you got under the dependent spouse rebate.' The government did not bother to tell them that. It is the different treatment of income under the Income Tax Assessment Act and the Social Security Act which causes thousands of Australian families to be worse off. According to evidence given to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, up to 800,000 people could be affected by the different definitions of `income'. Mr Peter McDonald, the National Director of the Australian Taxpayers Association, in his evidence to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on 19 September put it this way:

speech.para: . . . there are some very serious anomalies that will affect hundreds of thousands of families and they will be worse off at the end of the day . . .
That, for me, is not the same as, `It is more generous than the dependent spouse rebate.' He went on to say:
From what I have been able to glean out of the Australian Taxation Office statistical annual reports, there are in the order of at least 200,000 families who may be worse off.

In addition to these families, as I outlined earlier in the debate, the bill as originally drafted would mean that a number of other families would have been worse off because of differences in the qualifying criteria. Families overseas for longer than 13 weeks will be adversely affected. That would include aid workers, missionaries, academics, exchange studentsâ€”people who go away for a period longer than 13 weeks and who are paying tax here in Australia; people who are on Australian salaries when they are engaged overseas in those activities.
