They would not be eligible for the home child-care allowance and would no longer be eligible for the dependent spouse rebate at the rate payable for those who have children. They would be $372 a year worse off.

para.tab: Another group, families with children who are dependent full-time students, aged 18 to 25, whose income is less than $1,785 a year, will be worse off. I was told by a government senatorâ€”I cannot remember who it wasâ€”that, `There are not many students who earn less than $1,785. They all go out to work.' Let me tell that senator that there are a lot of country students who cannot earn $1,785 from part-time jobs. There might be young people in the cities who can get jobs at McDonald's, but out in the bush students are not able to get part-time work and earn that amount of money.

There are families which will be adversely affected by the inequitable treatment of unrealised capital gains under the Department of Social Security definition of income. Contrary to the government's claims that the home child-care allowance would benefit all those on low incomes, couples where both partners are unemployed would be excluded from receiving HCCA because it is means tested on only the child carer's income. Because of the introduction of the partner allowance, which effectively splits the unemployment benefit between both members of an unemployed couple, the child carer's income will be too high to receive the home child-care allowance.

Some people who receive very irregular incomes preferred the dependent spouse rebate because it made it much easier for them to reconcile their financial affairs at the end of the year. Mr McDonald, the National Director of the Australian Taxpayers Association, described the administration with regard to these people and the HCCA as absolutely abominable. He said that many people in part-time employment, with wild fluctuations in income, could find themselves having to lodge up to 26 applications on an ongoing basis each year. That seems unbelievable.

Families that have relatively low incomes spread between two partners could also be worse off. Rural families will have particular problems because the social security income test includes many forms of income not included in the income tax test. There are also anomalies between taxpayers who are wage and salary earners and those who are self-employed.

This amendment is clear evidence that the government has realised that this legislation is fundamentally flawed. The government has admitted that its bill, as originally drafted, would have left a large number of Australians worse off. The government's amendment will provide that families are able to fall back on the dependent spouse rebate, if they qualify for that rebate.

But the crucial point in this amendment is that those families with dependent children who currently qualify for the with-child rate of dependent spouse rebate and do not qualify for the home child-care allowance will still be worse off because they will be able to claim the dependent spouse rebate only at the without-child rate. They would be eligible only for an amount that is paid at a considerably lower rate. They will be $372 a year worse off.

The government originally sought to obtain political capital by introducing changes that were designed to demonstrate its commitment to recognising the role of home child carers and to helping families with a parentâ€”more likely than not, a motherâ€”at home. The home child-care allowance was Mr Keating's key election policy commitment to women. As I said before, he pledged in that campaign launch that this allowance would be more generous than the dependent spouse rebate that it would replace.

For many families, it is not more generous than the dependent spouse rebate it replaces. Mr Keating hoodwinked the Australian public and, in particular, he hoodwinked Australian mothers who are at home caring for their children. They were the people who were tricked and hoodwinked in that election campaign. Thousands of families will be considerably worse off as a result of the move from the dependent spouse rebate to the home child-care allowance, even with this amendment.

Having given the implied promise that no family would be worse off, that the home child-care allowance would be more generous than the dependent spouse rebate, the government should have made sure that people who do not qualify for the home child-care allowance were eligible to receive the dependent spouse rebate at the higher level at which they presently receive it.

I will be moving an amendment, which was foreshadowed by Senator Watson and circulated in the chamber, which provides that, if a family does not qualify for the home child-care allowance, it still will be eligible to receive the dependent spouse rebate at the higher with-child level. That is the purpose of my amendment. These families were not identified by the government, and they still will not be dealt with adequately unless the government is prepared to adopt the amendment that I will move. The opposition will not be supporting the government's amendments.

talker.name: Senator LEES
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

talk.start.para: â€”The Australian Democrats also will not be supporting the government amendments. I will not go through what Senator Patterson has detailed. We were pursuing a very similar amendment, but we are no longer doing so in order to support Senator Patterson's amendment. We will still, however, be amending it, and the coalition has indicated that it will support us. So there are alternatives to what the government is now proposing.

para.tab: Without going through the full detail, let me say that the Democrats support the principle of HCCA. We support the principle of ensuring that the parent who is at home and largely responsible for looking after children is the one who should have that money in pocket and should know how much the amount is. As we have seen from the statistics, many women are not even aware that there is that rebate intended for them through the male spouse's income tax.

It is wrong for the government to seek to paint into a corner those of us who have problems with the way HCCA is organised and running, suggesting that somehow we are not in favour of the system or the principle. We certainly support the principle, but we have major problems with where we have ended up and with the anomalies in the system brought about by the different treatment of income by the two systemsâ€”the tax system and the social security system.

If the government has now acknowledged that there are problems, has introduced this legislation to claw back some money for those who lose all HCCA and indeed acknowledged a further problem about a fortnight agoâ€”which is why we have this amendment before usâ€”we cannot see why it is not sufficient to make allowance for those families who used to get the dependent spouse rebate and who will now get nothing.

The government now acknowledges with this amendment that many people are losing part of that payment. But the amendment goes only part way to the solution. The government is going only a little further along the line, saying that families can have back some of the money. But these families will be about $241 a year worse off, which is basically a week's pay for low income earners. If the government has acknowledged in the first place that the principle is right, I cannot see why there is a problem. If there is a further problem, hence the amendments, why do we not go that extra step and make sure that all families will benefit?

I refer again to the advertising. I do not have the original advertisement before me, but I have already gone through it in my contribution to the second reading debate. Nothing in that ad even talks about replacing the dependent spouse rebate, hence the number of complaints and calls to my office once people began applying and began to understand how the system really works. We have heard on talkback radio over the past few weeks the confusion about it, with people asking, `What has happened to the $60? We have lost $50-odd through the tax system.'

I say to the government that, if the advertising had been more carefully thought out, some of the flak that we now have simply would not be occurring. If the advertising had gone that extra step and been honest enough to say, `We are replacing the dependent spouse rebate. You may be entitled to the home child-care allowance,' we would not have some of the problems with the lack of community understanding that we have today. So we will not support the government's amendment but we will support the opposition's amendment and we will move an amendment of our own.

talk.start.para: â€”I want to refer to what I said on 23 February 1994. I do that to indicate that I, too, will be opposing the government's amendment and supporting the opposition's amendment. I indicated then that if a family has a student child on Austudy, it receives the spouse rebate, under the current circumstances, of $1,425. As a result of the legislation that we are discussing today and the operation of the HCCA legislation, that family would stand to lose $237; that is the cut that it would experience. Does a child cost $237 less once he or she becomes a student? Do the parents of that child pay less in indirect taxes in respect of food and services purchased?

para.tab: At the moment, couples with student children up to the age of 25 get a spouse rebate of $1,425. With the combined legislation, they are denied the home child-care allowance once the last child is over 16 and leaves school, or turns 18. The government suggests that, if that is the case, they will get the without-child grant. Why? That is what we have to ask ourselves. It is miserly. It is a sort of anti-child mentality that is creeping in. I do not think the government is doing this deliberately. I think there are members of the government who understand that this really is a taxation question.

When the minister, Senator McMullan, was summing up, I took a note of what he said. He said something like this: `This area must essentially not be able to be achieved through the taxation system.' That is, to try to get the money to the actual carer requires measures which cannot be achieved through the taxation system. That is a lot of nonsense. Of course it can be achieved through the taxation system except in respect of families whose income is not sufficient for that purpose, and that can be dealt with in the social security area.

Why did the government not do away with all of this bureaucracy, with all of this paperwork? I showed honourable senators what people have to fill out. That should be done away with and we should simply continue with the DSR. We could do so in this way: the DSR would not be payable on a weekly or fortnightly basis through the taxation system unless the worker indicates on the rebate form where the money is to be paid toâ€”that is, to the bank account of the carer.

What is wrong with that? It would be simple. Answer it, please. The minister did not think of it. Why did he not think of it. He is going through all the hoo-ha of setting up an enormous bureaucracy and confusing people no end when it could have been done through the taxation system by that simple method. Why did the minister not do that? There are more examples than the one I have just referred to; they are endless. I refer honourable senators to my speech of 23 February. I do not want to go through that speech again because I know we have to get on to the matter of drought, which is a very important area. But this is also a very important area. I wish to conclude my remarks by saying that I believe that the government is wrong. The government ought to concede that it is wrong and it should support the proposition that has been put forward by Senator Patterson on behalf of the opposition.

speech.speaker: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

talker.name: Senator SHERRY
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

talk.start.para: â€”I will respond to a couple of points. It is pretty clear to the government what the outcome will be with the opposition, the Democrats and Senator Harradine opposing our amendment. A number of issues that have been raised in the debate have been raised previously on a number of occasions and, indeed, have been responded to by the minister and other speakers on behalf of the government.

para.tab: I have to cover a couple of issues, even though they have been touched on previously in this debate, from the government's perspective. The Prime Minister, Mr Keating, did not mislead the people about the promise. He never said there would be no losers. I will quote from his election speech. I viewed the election speech; I am not sure whether the opposition did. When he announced HCCA the Prime Minister said, `This allowance is more generous than the dependent spouse rebate it will replace.' We have delivered on this promise. Overall, HCCA is estimated to cost some $230 million more than the dependent spouse rebate, and that is not an insignificant amount of money in the context of a government program.
Senator Lees made some comments about the advertisements. The advertisements did not in all cases refer to the fact that it replaces the with-child rebate of DSR.

talk.start.para: â€”In all cases; it is a little loophole.
â€”It is slick advertising.

â€”It is not slick. It is very difficult to explain in an advertisement a major social reform like this in all its detail. It is not easy when we have so many cases of change and people are affected in different ways.
â€”You were not telling the truth; you were speaking politically.

â€”I have not finished my comments on this. Senator Herron should perhaps wait until he hears the comments. The advertisement was designed to give a simple message about eligibility criteria. The direct mail which was sent out to over 1.5 million families inviting them to claim did include this information. It was extensively market tested and the level of understanding on this point was extremely high. In addition, all letters advising recipients of a grant of HCCA reminded them to fill in a new employment declaration form if they were receiving the DSR via lower regular tax instalments. As I said earlier, it is not easy to explain to over 1 1/2 million people the detail required in all circumstances through a TV and radio advertising campaign.

para.tab: I want to touch briefly on the hypocrisy of the coalition with regard to this issue. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Costello, tells us all the time that he wants to cut the deficit. However, when it comes to voting on legislation the coalition, through its approach to this government amendment and to the later amendment, wants to impose a regime where there are no losers whatsoever.

talk.start.para: â€”That is what you said.

â€”No, we did not say that; that is the opposition's assertion. Regardless of policy rationale, the opposition has taken a position that there can be no losers whatsoever. Mr Ruddock, in his press release of 7 October on this matter, stated, `No Australian family should be financially disadvantaged'â€”absolutely none, despite the fact that we are improving the contribution by some $230 million. So the opposition says we should cut the deficit, but we should continue to allow for child-care expenses in a payment that supports people to stay home to care for children. From the opposition's perspective that is an absurd position.
â€”You are in government. We are telling you what you promised people.

â€”We are certainly in government but the opposition is potentially the alternative government and its hypocrisy on this issue has to be closely scrutinised. The opposition cannot go around claiming that there should be significant reductions in the deficit without giving any of the detailâ€”hiding it.
â€”You can't go claiming it is a more generous payment than it is. That is what you can't do.

â€”Again, as I have said in this debate and as the minister has said, the opposition makes an assertion which is incorrect. The opposition also says that we should cut the deficit but should continue to pay parents to stay home to care for the young adults aged 19 to 25. Again, that is the opposition's assertion and, indeed, what it is arguing for.

para.tab: The opposition says that we should reduce the complexity of the system. This is the opposition's approach: `We are peeved because we lost the last election.' We have heard it time and time again since the last election. The opposition is saying, `We will take an irresponsible approach on these issues. We will give the government hell because we lost the last election and because we are peeved.' That is what the opposition is saying.

talk.start.para: â€”We are more than peeved, Nick.
â€”I hope those opposite are; but they continue to show this banal, stupid approach on policy development.
â€”It is not banal and not stupid.
â€”It is because it is totally inconsistent with their approach. The opposition says that we should reduce the complexity. Again in his press release of 27 July, Mr Ruddock said:

speech.para: The current social security system has become a confusing maze . . . the Opposition has long advocated the introduction of a . . . simpler system.

But the coalition is now advocating through its position a system that would be almost unworkable in its complexityâ€”where families have to prove that they did not qualify for the HCCA in the social security system, even if they did not claim and receive it, before getting any DSR in the tax system. That is an absurd position for the opposition to be taking.

para.tab: The coalition has greatly exaggerated the number of losers. I suppose that when it is in opposition, has been there for so long and is likely to be there for so long, it has to take this sort of approach to play up concerns in the community. That is very unfortunate for those people in the community who have been conned by the opposition. It has greatly exaggerated the number of losers and it gives wrong examples of losers. It has stated that the government is hurting people by counting carers' pensions as income for HCCA purposes. In fact, it is already counted as income for the purposes of the DSR separate net income test. That is one example where I believe the opposition has misled the Australian people.

As I asserted earlier and as the minister has asserted, we did not give an unqualified undertaking that there would be no losers. We gave an undertaking that under this new proposal Australian families would be $230 million better off. That is why I hope the committee supports this amendment. This amendment and others which were foreshadowed by the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) in his second reading speech will allow taxpayers the choice of claiming the without-child dependent spouse rebate instead of claiming the home child-care allowance, if they wish.

The amendments will simplify the arrangements and remove any adverse consequences for a family choosing the home child-care allowance payments in lieu of the taxpayer claiming the without-child dependent spouse rebate. This is achieved by allowing taxpayers to calculate their dependent spouse rebate entitlement by determining the notional rebate they would have been entitled to and then subtracting from that notional rebate any HACCA payments received during the relevant period.

The 1994-95 transitional year arrangements require this amendment and others to ensure that entitlement to the with-child dependent spouse rebate for the period from 1 July to 29 September 1994 is retained. So I hope the committee will support the government amendment but I suspect that will not be the outcome, given the way in which the votes will line up. I think that is an unfortunate blow to the very significant social reform to which this government committed itself at the last election and on which it is delivering.

talk.start.para: â€”I do not want to argue but it is extraordinary that the government is insisting on the without-child rate. If parents are paying for the students, what does the government want the parents to doâ€”kick them out and make them eligible for the young homeless allowance? That would be more expensive. The whole thing should have been simplified.

para.tab: The minister did not answer a matter that I raised, and I raise it seriously again because I think it is a serious matterâ€”if not for now, for some future time. I ask the minister what consideration was given by the government to having this whole matter predominantly dealt with through the taxation system, and where is the paperwork relating to it? The way things are going, it will cost the government millions of dollars to transfer this from the taxation system to the social security system.

Admittedly, those people who do not have a taxable income that would have allowed them the full dependent spouse rebate may have had to be dealt with through the social security systemâ€”but not necessarily so. That could have been done through tax credits, for example, because everybody who receives income must have a tax file number and must make claims, so they could also have been dealt with through the taxation system.

Was consideration ever given to the simple measure of requiring the taxpayer, the income earner, to notify the employer on the rebate form to pay the amount direct to the carer? Unless that were there, the spouse rebate exemption would not have been available to the worker. That would have been a sensible, easy, efficient manner of dealing with this matter. Frankly, I would like to know from the minister what it has cost the Department of Social Security thus far to put all of the measures in place as a result of the legislation that we passed previously establishing the home child-care allowance.

talker.name: Senator SHERRY
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

talk.start.para: â€”I think the delivery of these payments through the social security system is much more effective and efficient. It is very difficult to deliver it through the tax system because many of the people who are eligible to receive this payment are not in the tax system because they are not employees. We could have a system that delivers a formal payment through the tax system, but we would also need a delivery of payments through the social security system. That, in itself, would be very inefficient. So the bottom line for the government has been to deliver the payments through the social security system to avoid two delivering mechanisms.

para.tab: Senator Harradine asked about the cost that has been incurred to date. I cannot give those figures now. I have asked the department to obtain a figure, and I will give that to Senator Harradine at a later stage today or when it becomes available.

speech.speaker: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

para.tab: Clause 57, line 32 (page 46) to line 33 (page 47), omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

"
57.
Section 159J of the Principal Act is amended:

speech.para:
(a)
by inserting after subsection (5D) the following subsection:

para.tab: (a)after taking into account any reduction because of the application of any other provision of this section, a rebate is allowable to a taxpayer under this section for a year of income in respect of a dependant who is the spouse of the taxpayer; and

speech.para: the rebate is to be reduced or further reduced, as the case requires, by the amount, or the sum of the amounts, of the home child care allowance.';

(b)
by inserting `home child care allowance, child care cash rebate,' before `or a child disability allowance' in paragraph (a) of the definition of `separate net income' in subsection (6).".

As I stated during the second reading debate, and again when I spoke to the government's amendment No. 4 to clause 57, thousands of Australian families will be worse off as a result of this legislation. Families that qualify for the dependent spouse rebate will not be eligible for the home child-care allowance because of the stricter Department of Social Security criteria. In addition, there will be thousands of families who will qualify for HCCA but who, because of different income definitions, will not receive the full amount of HCCA.

para.tab: When the parliamentary secretary was speaking to the last amendment, he said there would be $230 million more and people would be better off. The promise that the Prime Minister made was that the home child-care allowance would be more generous than the dependent spouse rebate. He should have then qualified that and said it would be more generous for those who qualify for the home child-care allowance. When he said, `We are going to have $230 million to distribute to carers of children at home', the honest thing to do would have been to qualify it by saying `for those who are eligible for this $30 a week'â€”although it will not be $30 a week for all of them anyway. He should have said, `Some of you will be worse off, you won't be getting $30 a week, and some of you won't get anything at all.'

Those families with dependent children who currently qualify for the with-child rate of the dependent spouse rebate and who do not qualify for the home child-care allowance would still have been worse off under the proposed government amendment which we have just voted against because they would have been able to claim the dependent spouse rebate only at the without-child rate. The intention of the amendment I have moved is to ensure that those families who currently receive the with-child dependent spouse rebate and are not eligible for the HCCA because of stricter eligibility tests will continue to receive the with-child dependent spouse rebate. In addition, the amendment removes from the calculation of separate net income both the child-care cash rebate and the home child-care allowance.

speech.speaker: Lees Sen M.H.

talker.name: Senator LEES
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

para.tab: Proposed clause 57, paragraph (a), after section 159J(5E), insert the following subsections:

speech.para: "`(5F) If, during a full year of income, the spouse of a taxpayer qualified for the maximum rate of home child care allowance (within the meaning of the Social Security Act 1991), the taxpayer is not entitled to claim all or part of a rebate in respect of that spouse under this section.

"`(5G) If, in a year of income, as a result of the operation of subsection (5E), a rebate is reduced or further reduced, as the case requires, by an amount, or the sum of amounts, of home child care allowance (within the meaning of the Social Security Act 1991), then, in spite of any other law, that rebate is not payable until the end of that year.".

We will be supporting the opposition's amendment. My amendment does two things. Firstly, it makes it clear that, if the spouse of a taxpayer qualifies for the maximum rate of home child-care allowance, the taxpayer is not entitled to claim all or part of a rebate in respect of that spouse under this section. In other words, people have to go into the HCCA system. Secondly, if there is a problem with the amount being claimedâ€”in other words, if they are worse offâ€”then that can be made up only at the end of the year.

talk.start.para: â€”The coalition supports the amendment moved by the Democrats. We will support it because it will further address the shoddy manner in which the government has approached this legislation from the outset and also ensure that what positive aspects there are are preserved. The insertion of proposed subsection (5F) would prevent taxpayers claiming partial spouse rebates where the spouse qualifies for the full rate of home child-care allowance. This amendment recognises that it is only where the full rate of HCCA is payable that reliance upon the dependent spouse rebate should be forgone. Of course, the number of people who will qualify for the full rate of HCCA will be far smaller than the number of those who do not. We can thank the government for that. This amendment would ensure that, unless the full rate of HCCA is payable, access to the dependent spouse rebate is preserved.

para.tab: The insertion of subclause (5G) to clause 57 would mean that partial spouse rebates would be payable at the end of a given year of income. Both amendments reflect the fact that retention of the dependent spouse rebate despite the introduction of the HCCA is justified as a safety net measure only. The dependent spouse rebate is not retained to allow taxpayers to withhold the benefits of a rebate from their spouses. Rather, it is necessary for the protection of families this government has forgotten in what has been a cheap and a deplorable bid for votes.

speech.speaker: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

talker.name: Senator SHERRY
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

talk.start.para: â€”I think some of the arguments are fairly well worn, but I want specifically to comment on the amendments of the coalition and the Democrats and why they will not work.

para.tab: The coalition and the Democrats say they do not want to run a dual systemâ€”a with-child DSR and the HCCA. They want to give people the option to fall back onto the DSR only if they do not qualify for any HCCA payment during the previous year. There is no practical way to design such a system. This is because the DSR is based on a financial year eligibility and the HCCA is based on eligibility in a fortnight. To pay DSR only after HCCA qualification for the year is tested would require clients to test their HCCA qualification 26 times a year, each fortnight. This would be nonsensical and surely cannot be supported by the coalition, the Democrats or the Greens. As well, it would be virtually impractical to determine HCCA qualification retrospectively, which is what the Democrats' amendments propose.

To preclude any payment of DSR if the family qualified for maximum HCCA, even if they did not claim it or receive it, runs a strong risk of these families missing out altogether and losing up to $1,560 a year. This is when the coalition and the Democrats are complaining that the government amendment would have resulted in a maximum loss of around $240 a year.

The government amendment was sounder in terms of policy and was workable for clients and administrators. In allowing people to get either the without-child DSR or HCCA throughout the year, we ensure no-one receives nothing. At the end of the financial year they can apply for the without-child DSR and if they received less HCCA they could get the difference between the two. There are also a number of technical problems with the way the amendments are being drafted which we believe cause problems.

Finally, I want to make some reference to the position of Senator Lees and the Democrats. As reported in
Hansard
of 23 February this year, Senator Lees, when speaking on the HCCA legislation, said:

speech.para: This bill is more than just cosmetic. It represents a big shift in both philosophy and community attitudes . . . It is a major improvement on the old system of the dependent spouse rebate.

The Democrats are now saying, `The government's family policy is based on a big con.' That is the press release of the 6th of this month. It does beg the question: if Senator Lees believes that now, why did she not do sufficient work on this matter back in February? But she is still wrong. The Democrats voted with the government on the HCCA bill, accepting that there were some losers.

talk.start.para: â€”Not this many.

â€”As reported in
Hansard
of 28 February, Senator Lees said:

speech.para: We believe the package is an improvement for low income families. In making these changes, we have to consider the balance, the total package and the effect it has on all families.

Senator Lees is now saying by press release, I notice, that there will be between 100,000 and 200,000 losers. We do not believe that is correct. Again speaking on the HCCA legislation, as reported in
Hansard
of 28 February 1994, Senator Lees said:
. . . our definition of children is not somebody aged 19, 20 or up to 25 years of age.

Yet she is now saying that these are amongst the group of losers, as evidenced by her press release on 6 October. I would suggest that Senator Lees's position is now somewhat hypocritical as well, like the opposition's.

speech.speaker: Lees Sen M.H.

talker.name: Senator LEES
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

talk.start.para: â€”I cannot let that go unchallenged. Firstly, yes, I stand by what we said then, that it is a matter of balance. But the government, in moving these additional changes in legislation and now amendments again to those changes, has also acknowledged that the number of losers is substantially more than we believed in the first place. I acknowledge that some of the losers at that stage were going to be students, and they remain part of the losers under this. We cannot move amendments to tackle only one particular lot of losers. Surely it is fair enough, now that we have all acknowledged that there are large numbers of losers, that we move amendmentsâ€”and these amendments, by the way, are those amendments which were issued on 11 October.

para.tab: We realised with our very first draft that there was a problem. We are assured by those who have drawn up these amendments for us that they achieve what we want to achieve. But I think that all of us in this chamberâ€”the government includedâ€”have acknowledged that there are far more losers than we first thought. I stand by what I said earlier this year and said again today: we welcome a policy change that would ensure that the spouse who remains at home, primarily looking after children, gets that money in hand, rather than have it come through the pay packet of the spouse who earns the majority of the income. We stand by everything we said in February.

After the committee hearing only a few weeks ago, the government, the coalition, Senator Harradine and the Democrats had the opportunity to hear from a number of people that the government should have heard from and whose opinions it should have sought in the first placeâ€”people who have given us specific details and some numbers. From what they have said, there will be a wider range of people who will be losers than any of us in this place envisaged in the first instance.

talk.start.para: â€”No, we knew before.

â€”Senator Patterson may wish to speak for herself later. When we agreed that a balance had to be struck, we believed that far fewer people would be disadvantaged than proved to be the case when the committee hearings concluded. With these amendments we are giving an opportunity to people who lose outâ€”but it is only an opportunity. Senator Sherry is quite right in saying that some people may choose not to get any money. That is their choice. Our amendment, in part, states:

speech.para: If, during a full year of income, the spouse of a taxpayer qualified for the maximum rate of home child care allowance . . . the taxpayer is not entitled to claim all or part of a rebate in respect of that spouse under this section.

Presumably, if they have qualified they will apply. If they do not apply, there is nothing we can do to force them to apply. It is a voluntary situation. They can choose not to go into the HCCA system. From listening to Senator Harradine, I think that there might be a few who will take one look at the forms and decide they cannot be bothered. That is their choice; we are not going to force people into it. But we also do not want a system where people can be put under any pressure not to be part of it. I stand by our amendments and by my comments back in February.

speech.speaker: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

talk.start.para: â€”I will be brief but I have to correct Senator Lees for saying that after the Senate inquiry into this bill we all discovered that there would be more losers. I stood up in the chamber when we were debating this before and outlined all the losers. One of my staff systematically went through the legislation when it came through and identified all the losers. We even set out a table. I came into this place and said that I believed there would be many losers.

para.tab: The light did not dawn on meâ€”as it did on Paul on the road to Damascusâ€”at that Senate committee. We knew it when the legislation came in. We have been saying it over and over again. Admittedly, the Democrats have come on side and have agreed that there would be many losers. The government has finally admittedâ€”even though it would not admit it to the Australian public before the electionâ€”that there were losers.

The government has tried to patch up the legislation but we do not believe that it has tried to patch it up fairly. We believe that the amendments we have movedâ€”our amendments and those of the Democratsâ€”attempt to address the situation. But, as Senator Lees has said, the government should have done something about it. It should have streamlined it and consulted interested groups. We should not have had to get to the point of trying to fix legislation on the run.

speech.speaker: Kernot Sen C.

talker.name: Senator KERNOT
talker.role: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

para.tab: Clause 65, page 51, line 34, omit "8%", substitute "5%".

speech.para: The purpose of this amendment is to reduce the provisional tax uplift factor for 1994-95 and subsequent years from eight per cent to five per cent. Yesterday I canvassed the arguments, and I will do so again very briefly, for our settling on five per cent. The main reason we think eight per cent is unfair is that it is an uplift factor which is nearly four times the inflation rate. The effect of that will be that small businesses, farmers and independent retirees will have their taxable income from last year automatically increased by eight per cent. It does not take cognisance of the so-called other factors, the other things which are happening in the economy and in their industry.

para.tab: The government will collect something like $250 million from this. We know that most of it will be refunded in the next tax year, but I think the important thing to note is that in the meantime it will affect the cashflows of small businesses. It would be much better for the $250 million to be given back to small businesses so that they can get on with the job they do wellâ€”job generation.

Why five per cent? We think that is a more appropriate median figure for expected provisional tax income growth than eight per cent. The government has forecast growth in average weekly earnings this year to be about 3.5 per cent; in real GDP, 4.5 per cent; and, in inflation, 2.25 per cent. So five per cent is reasonably consistent with growth. The all ordinaries index grew by five per cent and there was a 5.72 per cent rise in retail trade in the year to June. Setting the uplift factor at five per cent would allow for the expected rise in interest income as interest rates rise, and there could be some recovery in property incomes.

The point of setting it at that figure is that it would provide a well-timed boost to small business. I have heard the government's argument. Of more interest to me, I guess, is the position on this matter of members of the opposition because they say that they are the champions of small businesses. The government probably acknowledges that they pay a lot of attention to the big end of town and not quite as much to the smaller end.

I heard Senator Kemp, Senator Short, Senator Panizza and Senator Boswell speak yesterday about how bad the principles of the tax system are for small business. That is obviously the reason we said that this is an opportunity to do something about it. Groups such as COSBOA, with which the opposition would be familiar, the Small Business Forum, ACCI and the Retailers Council have asked the opposition for assistance by supporting this amendment.

The opposition has chosen to use a number of arguments which I canvassed yesterdayâ€”essentially, that it is plundering the revenue, which it is not, and that small business is already engaged in working it out for this year so they do not want the money back yet, but they might get it back next year because the opposition will put everybody on notice that it will not do it this year but it will think about doing it next year. The other reason is that it does not want to block supply. People in small business believed that for a short time until it was possible to point out to them the difference between money bills, tax bills, supply, appropriation and all the different terminologies that can often be used deliberately to confuse people. I think it is the politics of this issue that are more important to the opposition than the immediate opportunity to support small business, and I think that is regrettable.

talk.start.para: â€”As Senator Watson said during the second reading debate on this bill, there are a number of measures in this bill that leave a bitter aftertaste in the mouth of members of the coalition. Not least of those is the government's decision to maintain the provisional uplift factor at eight per cent. It does seem too high. I will be asking Senator McMullan to give us much more detail. The government has been pretty coy to date as to how the eight per cent figure was derived, because it certainly does seem much too high when we take into account the government's own forecasts for inflation and real income growth during 1994-95. I hope Senator McMullan will address that.

para.tab: We agree with the Democrats that the eight per cent figure is too high. As Senator Kernot said, we have put the government on notice that next year we will be looking very closely at whatever figure it brings up. But there are some important points of principle in this matter. So far as the government is concerned, of course, it is yet another very clear example of the disdain in which the government holds the small business sector, self-employed persons, retirees and the like. There is no doubt that it is very damaging to simply maintain the eight per cent figure this year. It does hit the small business sector and we recognise that.

I point out, though, with respect to Senator Kernot, that it is a short-term hit in the sense that it does not increase the total tax paid over time by provisional taxpayers. What it means is that they will pay less provisional tax next time than they will this year. So if we take it over time, of course, it does not affect the total level of the tax bill. Certainly, the $250 million or thereabouts that Senator Kernot referred to is not an unimportant figure, particularly for many struggling small businesses today.

On the other side of the coin there are some important principles. We in the coalition have for long maintained the principle that government budget measures are entitled to carriage unlessâ€”a very important considerationâ€”the measure represents a broken promise on the part of the government and unless the measure is retrospective. They are the two particular reasons why the coalition would feel obliged to oppose government budget revenue measures.

This year, in this instance, neither of those two conditions applies. The coalition has been arguing strongly that the government should be taking much stronger measures to get its fiscal house in order. Small business is in trouble today because of the inept, incompetent economic management of this government. Because the government has let huge budget deficits run, it has put more pressure on interest rates, and high interest rates are the killers of small business. Through the ineptitude of its fiscal management this government has been the prime architect of the problems that the small business sector faces today.

Given that there are not the two preconditions that we have always had as a matter of principle in relation to opposing budget measures, it is difficult for the coalitionâ€”as a principle to coalitionâ€”to say to the government on the one hand, `Get your fiscal act together. Get your budget deficit down', and on the other hand to say, `You have determined your budget for this year, but it is far too high a deficit, anyway. We want you to take a measure which will increase that deficit by another $250 million or so.' That would put still further upward pressure on interest rates and compound the problems that the government has already imposed on the small business sector.

It is for those reasons that the coalition, while understanding the point that Senator Kernot has made, will not be supporting the Australian Democrat's amendment. I hope Senator Kernot realises the irony and the hypocrisy of what she proposes. She talks about playing politics, but she is the ultimate political opportunist. If the Democrats were fair dinkum and were really serious about wanting to do things for small business, they would stop taking the continual measures which are now in their economic policy platform and which would vastly increase government expenditure to the tune of billions and billions of dollars. I think the Democrats expenditure proposals at the moment are something like $20 billion plus over the present level.

talk.start.para: â€”What rubbish!
â€”Like what?

â€”That has to be financed by additional taxation, or possibly by borrowing in the short term. In the end, the taxpayer has to pay for the totally extravagant, damaging, job destroying policies of the Democratsâ€”particularly in the rural areas of Australia that are suffering so grievously today. If the Democrats were really serious about having any concern for small business in this country, and about having any concern for those people in the bush who are having such a desperately difficult time today, they would be pursuing policies which were aimed at decreasing the burden of taxation on small business; to decrease the level of interest rates to give small business a chance to grow and thrive as we all want it to do.

para.tab: Yet, the whole thrust of the Democrats' policies ever since I have been in this place, but increasingly over the last five years, has been bigger government spending, higher government taxation, higher interest rates, less savings for investment, less job creation, less small business, and less growth in the economy. With great respect to Senator Kernot, I have to say that the hypocrisy of the Democrats in moving this amendment is monumental.

I am delighted to say that that irony, that hypocrisy, and that basic inconsistency in the economic policy proposals of the Democrats are very well recognised in the small business community. The coalition is sorry that the uplift factor being maintained at eight per cent is as high as it is. I have asked Senator McMullan to explain to us precisely how the government arrives at eight per cent.

There are important points of principle here. If a party is going to be a disciplined and principled political party, unlike the Australian Democrats, then there are certain principles that it has to adhere to. This is one in this particular budget measure. For those reasons, with reluctance, we will not be supporting the Democrats' amendment.

talk.start.para: â€”When Senator McMullan responds, I wonder whether he could enlighten the committee by giving us some figures about the estimated growth in provisional income for the next financial year, what the growth was last year in the taxable income of provisional taxpayers, how many had a growth of five per cent or less in taxable income last year, and how many had a growth of five per cent or more in taxable income. That information might be useful for the committee to consider.

talker.name: Senator McMULLAN
talker.role: Minister for Trade)

talk.start.para: â€”I cannot supply all the information that various honourable senators have asked for because not all that material is available, available quickly enough or available to me; but I will do what I can.
â€”Some of it was in the Senate committee hearing.

â€”Yes, some of it is on the public record already; but I am just talking about some of the additional specific things to which people referred. I will provide what information I can. The fascinating thing about that debateâ€”I am trying to be as objective observer as I can of the debate between Senator Short and Senator Kernotâ€”was the interesting struggle for a bit of credibility, about who will be seen as the credible opposition. It was a nil-all draw.

para.tab: I thank Senator Short for taking some of the hyperbole out of this debate. He brought some more sober assessment to the implications of itâ€”both for small business and for the revenue, and he was correct on both counts. His contribution about macro-economic policy was not quite so considered and does not stand as a very sober reflection, but it is a debate for another day. Looking at what is happening in interest rates in other countries would perhaps expose some of the weaknesses in his points; but this is not the time to get involved in all that. It is interesting to see this conflict going on and I expect to see more of it as the struggle for credibility between the competing opposition parties continues. Good luck to them both.

One of the things to rememberâ€”and I will talk about the basis for setting the provisional tax uplift factor in a momentâ€”is that a substantial number of people who pay provisional tax get a lot of their income from interest. If that is where a person's income comes from, it certainly has increased substantially.

talk.start.para: â€”Not by 10 per cent.
â€”Your income has not increased by 10 per cent?
â€”No.

â€”I ask Senator Panizza to think about that for a moment and then come back to me. The other thing is that people derive their income from profitability related measures. That also has increased very significantly. I do not think eight per cent would be an unreasonable assessment of incomes driven by measures related to profitability.

para.tab: The other thing to remember is that those most likely to gain most from those income sources rising quickest are those with the highest income. So the unintended consequence of Senator Kernot's proposed amendment to clause 65 is that some of the people with the biggest incomes in this country are the biggest winners. That seems to me to be a distributional problem.

There is not the sort of information base to break that down. That is not me quoting the tax statistics, it is just an application of logic to known factsâ€”that must be soâ€”and it is a redistributive impact which, if Senator Kernot thought about it, would dampen her enthusiasm for this proposal. I know we are getting close to the suspension of the sitting for lunch and we want to get this particular clause finished before then, so I will not speak any more in the generality.

The level of aggregate income subject to provisional tax is difficult to predict with accuracy. Nobody should pretend that we can predict with precision for any one year exactly what it will be. Whatever we do, it will be too high for some people and too low for others. That is why we have the arrangements that allow taxpayers to approach the Taxation Office to vary their provisional tax, as some do, and those figures were given to the Senate committee. That goes to some of Senator Harradine's points but not all.

talk.start.para: â€”There are penalties if they get it wrong.

â€”Of course, that is right and that is why it tends to be higher income people who use it most oftenâ€”not because of the penalties but because of the point Senator Panizza was making about the possible cost. Sometimes that is exaggerated but I accept that there is a potential cost and, in some circumstances, a significant cost. I accept that that is logically correct.

para.tab: So we try to get an uplift factor which is on average, over time and across taxpayers, a reasonable reflection of the growth in income of provisional taxpayers, and the eight per cent uplift factor has regard to the expected average annual growth in income subject to provisional tax over the next several years. We do not want to provide a timing advantage to recipients of income subject to provisional tax compared to PAYE taxpayers. I think we have to balance the fairness and equity measures in that.

So there are a number of hidden equity issues in this that are important. There are significant revenue measures but I would just be wasting the committee's time if I went through thoseâ€”Senator Short has already dealt with themâ€”and there are redistributive factors. But some of the areas of income most prone to having provisional tax applied to them are those which are increasing most quickly. So one has to realise the balancing factor.

I do not want to pretend there is great science here; that we could predict that next year it will be 7.9 per cent and bet the house on it. But one has to look at the medium-term prospect. Looking at the nature of income involved, the low but still existent rate of inflation, and the increase in interest rates and profitability, this is a reasonable assessment. I would be surprised if we found a significantly increased number of people seeking a reassessment, or finding that they had significantly overpaid and were seeking a rebate but the statistics will show that up afterwards and those are matters we can pursue over the years. However, when it comes up next year and we have a look at those figures, we will see.

In the time available, those are the broad parameters of the criteria of making the decision and the best statistics I can supply in response to the questions people asked. If people subsequently want to ask specific questions not related to this clause, which I hope we can finish dealing with, on behalf of the minister I will be happy to try to seek that information for them.

talk.start.para:
â€”In the
Hansard
referred to, it was made clear by the Treasury officials that the last figures they were able to give usâ€”the figures for 1990-91â€”showed a growth in provisional taxpayers of 0.03 per cent when the uplift factor was 10 per cent. Why on earth this cannot be examined on a year by year basis, I do not know. In the circumstances, I will be supporting Senator Kernot's amendment.

para.tab: Question put:
Question so resolved in the negative.
Progress reported.

debate.title: VOCATIONAL EDUCATION AND TRAINING FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL 1994

para.tab:
Debate resumed from 20 September, on motion by
Senator Crowley
:
That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Gibson Sen B.F.

talk.start.para: â€”I rise on behalf of the coalition opposition to speak on the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 1994. The major amendments proposed in this bill will do two things. The bill will set the level of Commonwealth vocational education and training funding for 1994 to 1996. Secondly, it will provide for payments to the Australian National Training Authority for additional trainees under the Australian traineeship system and career start traineeships.

para.tab: The Commonwealth provides grants to the states and the territories for the provision and support of vocational education and training, primarily in the technical and further education system. Prior to 1 January 1994, grants to the states and territories were provided in accordance with the provisions of the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Act 1989. These grants contributed to general operating costs and infrastructureâ€”in other words, they were recurrent expenditure grants and capital expenditure grants. From 1 January 1994 the funding arrangements under the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Act 1989 were replaced by funding arrangements under the Vocational Education and Training Funding Act 1992. Under the new arrangements a single pool of funds, comprising the previously separate recurrent expenditure grants and capital expenditure grants, is passed to ANTA for allocation amongst the states and territories.

The Australian National Training Authority Act 1992 gave effect to an agreement announced by the Prime Minister in July 1992 between the Commonwealth, states and territories for the establishment of ANTA. The objectives of the agreement include the establishment of a national vocational education and training system, closer interaction between industry and providers of vocational education and training, an effective training market and improved cross-sectoral links. The functions of ANTA include allocating and remitting funding to state and territory training agencies on the basis of guidelines determined by the ministerial council, and administering any programs agreed by the ministerial council as requiring national delivery within the guidelines approved by the council.

Within the bill currently being debated the main provisions are in clause 4, which will insert new sections 9, 9A and 9A(1) into the Vocational Education and Training Funding Act 1992. Section 9 currently provides for payments to ANTA for allocation under the ANTA Act 1992 of $638.96 million in 1994 and $719.7 million in 1995. The effect of the new section will be to amend the amounts payable to ANTA in the following manner: it will increase the amount payable in 1994 from $638 million to $673.6 million and the amount in 1995 from $719.7 million to $755.7 million, and it will set out the amount payable for 1996. It is a very substantial amount which we are putting into this part of education in Australia.

In the area of administration, a lot of difficulties are surfacing. The real issues that we need to face are: what are the intentions of the federal government, and what are its strategies as outlined in the white paper? Is the government really focused on increasing and improving the skills of Australians, or is it more interested in trying to pull down the unemployment figures just for a gloss effect for public perception purposes?

My colleague the shadow spokesperson and member for Braddon, Mr Miles, informs me that there are deep concerns being expressed in relation to the questions of training and skilling in this area of education. For example, a recent report by Vince Fitzgerald, which was commissioned by ANTA and was entitled
Successful reform: competitive skills for Australians and Australian enterprises
, expresses some of those concerns. In its chapter entitled `Successful reform', under the heading `Inadequate performance planning and reporting', it says:

speech.para: Continued reliance on Frameworks, Guidelines, Policies, Procedures, Protocols, Memorandums and other paraphernalia of government avoids the central question of what is the performance target, what is the work and business plan and where are the annual reports against reform targets for each of those agencies or organisations actually responsible for the reforms.

We are not going to skill this country and we are not going to develop a more competent work force unless this money is effectively used and unless there are administrative arrangements in place which set up clear, measurable targets that are identifiable publicly and that can be achieved. At the moment, all the evidence indicates that money is being allocated by the parliament, but the progress is not very great. There is deep concern out there expressed by a whole range of people, organisations and industry involved in the area.

para.tab: This report said that there are confused accountabilities and responsibilities. If we are going to make progress and if there is not to be so much red tape and bureaucracy in this field, the government has got to give some clear direction in this arena. The Fitzgerald report says in its conclusion to this particular chapter:

speech.para: Our assessment . . . relates to both the substance of the national training reforms themselves and to their strategic management. In both areas they have been found wanting.

The report finds the reforms wanting with regard to strategic management. The whole direction of ANTA really comes back to the federal government and, clearly, there is lack of direction from this government. There are literally thousands of people out there in businesses who are ignored or locked out of the training procedures.

para.tab: The act also set out the goals of an effective training market and other objectives which the government and the council have agreed to, but they are simply not being realised. There is also a concern that the proposed funding levels as set out are unrealistically low, and the government is really trying to force an agenda onto the states which is going to cause problems.

The agreements between the states and the federal government have not yet been made, and there is a suspicion that the federal government is pushing off responsibilities to the states and giving them a certain amount of money, but expecting them to do far more than that money will ever achieve. That same approach is also being taken in the areas of health and law and order. They are state areas of responsibility for which the government keeps cutting the real funding while still expecting the states to do something about them. It is about to do the same, I suspect, with regard to vocational education and training.

The other aspect worth highlighting in this bill is that it gives the Commonwealth minister power to determine whether states are meeting targets for new trainees rather than leaving that task to the ANTA board. Why does it have to be the federal minister who has the power to determine whether the targets have been met?

talk.start.para: â€”Because he is responsible to parliament. You have been asking questions, Senator, that's why.
â€”Fair enough.
â€”It's called parliamentary responsibility; what you should demand from the opposition.

â€”That is true, but one would have thought that the ANTA board should then be responding directly to that minister about that. The coalition has supported the establishment of a national training authority to bring vocational education and training in all states under a common umbrella. We support the funding of ANTA to enable it to carry out its roles and responsibilities and also support the increased funding to provide further places for apprenticeships, traineeships and career start traineeships.

para.tab: This government has had an abysmal record in TAFE education over the past 10 years. This bill is a very late response to the decline in apprenticeships and traineeships which has occurred over the past few years. For example, the 1993-94 target of 46,000 apprenticeships is less than half the 1992-93 level. Even if the 1995-96 target of 60,000 new apprenticeships is achieved, that number will be less than the levels achieved four years ago. The question of funding for ANTA is only one aspect that needs to be addressed. The government needs to give ANTA some sense of direction so that it can get on with the job it was established for. The opposition does not oppose this bill.

talk.start.para: â€”The Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 1994 is largely about funding the Australian National Training Authority in terms of growth funding for the Finn participation targets for young people, funding for off-the-job training provider assistance and funding for an additional 50,000 entry level trainees for the Australian traineeship system and career start traineeships as part of the white paper initiatives. Of course, we realise that business was let off the hook in relation to the changes in the business training levies. That is part of the reason governments now find themselves being required to pay more into training schemes because business is less and less willing to provide research and development and training schemes. Business does not want government regulation but is expecting governments to do more and more for it.

para.tab: The Greens will be voting for this bill. We encourage the provision of extra traineeship positions for young people. There is some concern, however, in the traineeship sector that traineeships are being provided in haste and the quality is being sacrificed. The big question, though, is: where are the jobs? Where are the permanent jobs for these people when they train for three to four years and finally qualify as professionals? The government has not addressed this fundamental issue.

I know the government would probably turn around and say, `It is through economic growth,' but we do not have to be an Einstein to see that the type of change we have made in many policies in recent times has meant that the type of growth has changed. We are concentrating very much on imported capital which actually sheds jobs. One does not have to be terribly intuitive to see that there is further job shedding within the government sector; at the same time as some positions are being created, unemployment is being created in other areas. In reality, what we do see is a growing number of people in part-time or less tenured positions in short-term jobs. That is, fewer jobs within regions and fewer jobs for younger people.

We have growing social problems. One does not have to look very far in Western Australia to see that the kind of growth we have is mainly holes in the ground or smokestacks. So we have growth and environmental problems, but they do not necessarily translate to growth in the jobs in the areas where there is the greatest need for employment in our society. Economists recognise also that the tactic of wage subsidies is only useful to the short-term unemployed as an incentive for an employer to take them on. Wage subsidies are not the way to go to help the long-term unemployed.

talk.start.para: â€”What are?

â€”It is a real pity that the minister is trying to suggest that he does not know what ideas have been put forward for job creation. There was a potential under the regional development strategyâ€”where it was possible to create regional based development and community based developmentâ€”to ask people about the real needs of the communities. The whole exercise ended up being a waste of time. All that happened was that two people from the regional development task force went to the major industries and said, `What do you want?' We got more of the same as we have had for a long time. There is a lack of vision by this government about what is needed within a region. It does not ask the right questions of the right people. If the government does not know what is needed that is very sad. I think it is time the government found out.

para.tab: The job compact at large was a process of negotiation between the government and training bodies, but did not adequately involve employers. If employers are not involved, how can they take on the responsibility for employing people? How do we get them to change their mind-set and inherent bias when it comes to employing the long-term unemployed? Some employers have already been quite vocal in their response to wage subsidies. They have said that it does not matter how many wage subsidies the government throws at them, they will not take on a long-term unemployed person over someone who is short-term unemployed, because of their personal problems, their potential emotional baggage and their deteriorated skills and confidence. We need to do a lot of work to involve employers more in the training process so that there is a smoother transition between the training of marginalised groups and employment.

There are other obstacles to job creation and one of them is the mind-set of big business. Big business admits to its general house policy of not being interested in creating jobs. It says its responsibility is not to the Australian people but to its foreign shareholders and that the welfare of the Australian society is not its concern. Government is fighting a losing battle by constantly giving sweeteners to big business to try to woo it into establishing its head offices here and offering tax reduction strategies to create jobs. It is all to little availâ€”corporations are only interested in employing the minimum numbers of workers for minimum wages and conditions, if they can get away with it.

For strong and stable job creation the government should involve itself in more job creation schemes so that the newly trained and the long-term unemployed have something to show for their training once they are ready to work.

talk.start.para: â€”What do you think Working Nation was about?

â€”Once again, we have an interjection about Working Nation. I would like to know what Working Nation was about; it certainly was not about job creation. The options for the government include providing jobs in community services, infrastructure, public sector employment, capital works, et cetera. We also need to concentrate on creating jobs in areas that young people perceive as important in terms of their future, and areas that they would like to be involved in. Some of these areas are capital works projects, land care, environmental programs, maintenance of World Heritage areas, recycling and waste disposal, labour intensive agricultural activities and implementing energy efficient power sourcesâ€”perhaps some decent energy policies would create a lot more jobs than are being created at the moment. But the government is not doing that; it is pandering to the coal industry, which uses subsidies and creates pollution and very few jobs.

para.tab: The government is letting jobs go down the tube. We have talked about 30,000 jobs going down the tube from within the footwear, clothing and textile industry. Where is the government bleating about that? Where is the government bleating about those people who are working in sweatshop conditions? It is women in those jobs so the government does not care. We are talking about jobs in tourism, accommodation and service industries, and cultural industries, and the expansion of plantation forests for industry viability and to save our old growth forests. We are too busy cutting down trees to worry about creating jobs for that area.

The government needs to urgently consider providing more jobs for young people in these areas. It needs to be serious about providing more than training. Once people are ready to enter the market force, the government needs to make sure that there are real jobs for them. It should not abandon people once they have finished their training, and leave it up to the obscure notion of market forces.

talker.name: Senator SCHACHT
talker.role: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

talk.start.para: â€”I will wind up this second reading debate on the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 1994. I do not think there are any amendments to it. The bill will be carried without opposition and I thank the Senate for its cooperation in that. I was not going to speak but, in view of the contribution of Senator Margetts, I cannot constrain myself. Sitting here listening to Senator Margetts, I felt a sense of incredulity and almost exasperation, after all that we have tried to do. Senator Margetts may criticise us and say that we have not been as successful in some areas as we have in others; that is a debate I am willing to take on. However, trying to take part in this debate is like trying to be on Venus and debate someone on Mars.
â€”We do seem to be on different planets, don't we?

â€”Yes we do. That is absolutely true. That is one thing we will have to agree on. I almost feel like going out and shooting myself after hearing Senator Margetts' range of views about what we have not done and what is wrong. Talking about jobs in the environmental area, yesterday in the Senate I gave a response to a question on green jobs, a government outline in response to a book produced by the Australian Council of Trade Unions in conjunction with the Australian Conservation Foundation. We made it quite clear that we are very supportive of developing the environment industry and sustainable jobs.
â€”How are you implementing the greenhouse strategy and all of the jobs there?

â€”We made that commitment from the industry portfolio. I know people in the green movement usually think of it as the enemy in terms of the environment, but we do have a substantial environmental industry section of the department looking at ways of supporting those interests of the private sector which want to develop green jobs and industries, whether it is environmental remediation or environmental consultancies, both within Australia and overseas. The figure I gave yesterday was that we estimate there will be many hundreds of billions of dollars in these industries over the next decade or so.
â€”A million and a half on solar energy is something you can do.

â€”Solar energy is not the only green industry that this government is interested in. We are interested in everything from waste management through to alternative energy areas. We are putting money into research in a broad scope of areas, not just the one or two that happen to please the Western Australian Greens. The environmental industry association that we have dialogue with, including representatives from Western Australia, is very supportive of what we are trying to do.

para.tab: I could not quite get the gist of Senator Margetts' comments on training. She was complaining that the subsidies that we are providing through Working Nation are not effective, and she quoted some unnamed sources saying that that was not really effective. Already the trend is that these are being taken up for the long-term unemployed and the subsidies are starting to work.

talk.start.para: â€”They have been taken off the statistics.

â€”Yes, they have been taken off the statistics and will be taken off the statistics when they go into the training program. We are criticised for suspending the training levy for two years. I suspect this was a response from the very same people who have been complaining to Senator Margetts about the training initiatives that we put up.

para.tab: We have responded to industry by saying there has been a culture change going on. Industry does accept its responsibility, but its own long-termâ€”Senator Margetts may say selfishâ€”future requires that it has a well trained work force. The culture change is under way and we said that after two years we will review whether the levy will have to be replaced. We hope it does not because we will have the evidence that industry has taken up the challenge for the vocational training of its own staff. The increasing number of smart industries in Australia realise that their most important asset is a well trained staff that is motivated to achieve quality product and quality outcomes in the services they provide to their consumers. This government is very supportive of that; it was one of the major themes in our Working Nation industry statement earlier this year.

ANTA is a very important part of the government's program for getting a flexible and adaptable skills base in the community. It will serve the interests of employees, so that they get decent jobs to which they have a commitment and from which they get satisfaction, and industry, so that it has access to quality trained people and is internationally competitive.

I know Senator Margetts may not agree with the idea that Australia should become an internationally competitive economy; but this government is committed to that, the ACTU is committed to it, and the various industry associations are committed to it. They all know that in the long run that will deliver a better standard of living for all Australians than some notion that Senator Margetts has of a closeted economy that cannot provide the standard of living to which ordinary Australians all aspire, and quite rightly so. ANTA is one of the central planks of micro-economic reform in Australia, to ensure that we have Australian employees going out into the work force.

talk.start.para: â€”So we are going to reduce our wages down to the levels in Taiwan or Indonesia or China.
â€”ANTA is not about reducing wages; it is about doing the exact opposite.
â€”But the international competitiveness focus is.

â€”I think Senator Margetts is talking about the 1950s, not the 1990s. What we are talking about is this: when we have well-trained, quality staff we can pay them much higher wages because their productivity and the quality of their work is substantially improved. If we want a non-trained work force, a no-skill work force, then we do have to pay them wages at a Third World level, because in terms of productivity or quality they cannot produce a competitive product. But when we have well-trained staff with the right skills, and the competency in those skills, we can pay decent wages equivalent to a First World economyâ€”which we want to beâ€”which can provide the standard of living which ordinary Australians desire to have. That is what this government is committed to. ANTA is going to be an essential part of that program in providing those skills.

para.tab: It is a big achievement to get the states to agree with the federal government that we will have a national system of skill based competency training and change the whole structure of training for skill and vocation from what has been traditionally done in Australia through four-year apprenticeships and so on. We are changing all of that to ensure that our community and our industry is internationally competitiveâ€”a better economy and, above all else, a more civilised economy, where people can live with some dignity because they have decent skill based jobs.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

debate.title:
PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1994
WINE GRAPES LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1994
PRIMARY INDUSTRIES LEVIES AND CHARGES (WINE GRAPES) COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1994
NATIONAL RESIDUE SURVEY ADMINISTRATION (MEAT CHICKENS) AMENDMENT BILL 1994

para.tab:
Debate resumed from 10 October, on motion by
Senator Bolkus
:
That these bills be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: â€”I am pleased to speak on the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 and three other equally important bills: the National Residue Survey Administration (Meat Chickens) Amendment Bill 1994, the Wine Grapes Levy Amendment Bill 1994, and the Primary Industries Levies and Charges (Wine Grapes) Collection Amendment Bill 1994.

para.tab: These four pieces of legislation span a range of primary industries and, taken together, demonstrate an admirable commitment to self-help. The National Residue Survey Administration (Meat Chickens) Amendment Bill 1994 provides for the maximum rate of the national residue survey levy to increase from 0.02c a head to 0.06c a head. Almost all primary industries in Australia contribute to the national residue survey to ensure that the food they produce is free from harmful residues. The survey for each industry is fully funded by that industry.

In this case, the Australian Chickenmeat Federation sought an increase in the levy to provide the industry with greater flexibility in long-term planning. The chicken meat industry has developed from so-called backyard status in the late 1960s to a modern, dynamic industry, now second only to beef in terms of meat production.
