Some 40 years ago, Australians consumed about three million birds annually, or less than half a kilogram of chicken meat per person, per year. In 1993-94, Australians ate their way through 325 million birds. That equates to two Kentucky Fried Chicken snack packs or three Mc Chickens, or perhaps 13 bowls of chicken noodle soup per person, per week, per year.

It is important to note that the chicken meat industry in Australia directly employs 16,000 people, indirectly involves 45,000 people and has retail sales figures approaching $1.7 billion. Having said that, there is mounting concern about the impact of the drought on intensive animal feeding industries which rely on grain. The chicken meat industry is a prime example. Should grain prices continue to rise, the industry will have to decide whether to absorb the extra costs or pass them on to consumers.

Clearly, the impacts of this drought go beyond the farm gate. Our chicken meat industry is also hamstrung by the high cost of capital, the high cost of labour, and the subsidies provided in rival countries. The United States and the European Union are aggressive protectors of their domestic chicken meat industries, while Thailand has rapidly become a major chicken meat exporter, through tax incentives and cheap labour.

For all of these reasons, the possible relaxation of Australian quarantine regulations relating to imported chicken meat causes great concern to the Australian industry. This concern is twofold: first, the impact on local producers, and second, the possible introduction of the world's most feared disease in the poultry industryâ€”the newcastle virus. I am pleased that AQIS has decided against allowing raw chicken meat into Australia and I trust that its position paper, which suggests cooked chicken meat will not pose a disease risk, is correct. The chicken meat industry upholds high standards and, on behalf of the federal coalition, I hope the industry's commitment to the future is matched by the same level of commitment from the government.

The Wine Grapes Levy Amendment Bill 1994 and the Primary Industries Levies and Charges (Wine Grapes) Collection Amendment Bill 1994 propose to end the current levy exemption for wine producers producing less than 10 tonnes of fresh grapes; place a maximum limit on the amount of levy that is used to support marketing; and increase the limit on research and development component.

Part of the money raised through the wine grapes levy finances the operations of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporationâ€”the body responsible for wine promotion; administration of the wine label integrity program; export control; and determining Australia's geographical indications for use in describing and presenting wine. The remainder funds the Grape and Wine Research and Development Corporation. Funding spent on research is matched by the government on a dollar-for-dollar basis. The Australian Wine Makers Forum and the Independent Winemakersâ€”both representing small winemakersâ€”support the changes proposed by this legislation.

As the reputation of Australian wine grows throughout the world, our export trade continues to strengthen. In 1994-95, it is estimated that we will export 162 million litres of wine. This amounts to an increase of almost 400 per cent since 1989-90. In value terms, exports are expected to come close to $500 million.

One of the most recent developments in the wine industry has been the agreement reached between Australia and the European Community signed in January this year. The agreement paves the way for improved access of Australian wines to European markets and eliminates technical trade barriers in return for the phasing out of European geographical names as names for wine. The search for new names to replace beaujolais, hock, madeira, chianti and, eventually, champagne, chablis, moselle and others will be a challenge for Australian winemakers. But it does provide an enormous opportunity for Australian wines to further establish their market niche with distinctive names. Given the industry's vision and foresight, the federal coalition has no doubt that the industry will achieve its $1 billion annual export targets by the year 2000.

The final piece of legislation in this cognate debate, the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994, covers a range of minor changes to various primary industry acts. These include the Farm Household Support Act 1992, the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Policy Council Act 1984 and the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Act 1980. The Farm Household Support Act, for example, covers the operation of the farm household support scheme designed to provide assistance to farmers unable to meet living expenses or to access commercial finance. This assistance is provided for a period of nine months. If, during that time, the farmer leaves the farm the assistance becomes a grant. If the farmer remains in the industry, the assistance must be repaid at commercial interest rates. Those who leave the industry within the nine-month period will receive the balance payable for a period as a lump sum in addition to their re-establishment grant of $45,000.

This bill makes a small but important change to the administrative arrangements for farm household support. It extends from 14 to 30 days the time allowed for farm household support applicants to obtain a certificate of inability to access finance. Many farmers have experienced problems in obtaining such a certificate within 14 days because of the difficulty in physically accessing financial institutions. So I am pleased that the government has acknowledged this difficulty.

Although the household support scheme is, in theory, a useful form of assistance to farmers in difficulty, in practice it has not worked and only some 260 farmers currently receive benefits. For this reason, the government has been forced to introduce the drought relief payment in order to put food on the tables of drought stricken farmers. We will later today be dealing with that legislation comprehensively. As I said earlier, the consequences of this drought go beyond the farm gate. They impact on small businesses in country towns, and on the people who work for those small businesses. It is evident that Australia will bear the high personal and economic costs of this drought for many years to come.

speech.speaker: Woodley Sen J.

talk.start.para: â€”The Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 is an omnibus bill amending numerous acts within the portfolio. I would like to restrict my comments today to those amendments relating to the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Act and the Farm Household Support Act. In relation to the second of those, I certain support the comments made by Senator Tambling.

para.tab: Looking firstly at the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation, amendments contained in this bill will ensure that the organisation when performing its functions takes into account the principles of ecologically sustainable development. These principles will be written into the charter of the organisation and, in future, a person with expertise in environmental and ecological matters will be required to be a serving member of the organisation's board. I expect that this provision will come into effect when the new AWRAP board members are appointed some time next year.

Following these amendments, ESD principles will need to be considered by AWRAP in its corporate planning, in its annual reporting and in its allocation of funding for research and development activities. The Democrats have said on previous occasionsâ€”almost ad nauseamâ€”that the definition of what constitutes principles of economically sustainable development should be more clearly spelt out in legislation. I urge again that the government take this suggestion on board.

Further amendments contained in this bill, which I understand are being made at the request of the AWRAP management, would provide the organisation with greater flexibility in the way in which it allocates its funds. More specifically, it would be able to direct moneys received from patents and trademarks to activities other than research and development. The Democrats will be supporting these amendments.

I turn now to the Farm Household Support Act. The explanatory memorandum states that the purpose of the amendments is to improve the delivery of farm household support to farmers experiencing financial difficulties and to allow for the more efficient administration of farm household support. Experience I have had with social security legislation has made me very wary when an explanatory memorandum uses terms like `improve the delivery' or `allow for more efficient administration'. Often these terms seem to be `draftese' for measures which leave a lot of people worse off. Fortunately, after we have gone carefully through the amendments to the Farm Household Support Act it does not seem that there would be too many in a worse situation. We are thankful for that.

Firstly, the amendments would allow farmers more time to obtain a certificate verifying that they are unable to access any further commercial finance. This extension from 14 to 30 days would be useful because of the problems many farmers have in simply getting time to travel into town to a financial institution. Those problems are exacerbated by the fact that financial institutions have been exiting the bush almost as fast as some farmers. Secondly, the act currently provides that, where a person is attempting to sell his or her farm but is having difficulty doing so, the secretary or a delegate can extend the grant period of farm household support beyond the normal nine-month limit. Amendments in this bill would allow recipients who have been refused an extension of their grant period to ask for a review of that decision.

A third amendment in the bill would ensure that a farmer can access the nine-month grant period of farm household support only once. In other words, a farmer who sold up and received a lump sum payout of the grant period would not, if he or she should subsequently re-enter farming, be eligible for a second grant period. The final amendment in the bill is one I want to talk about at slightly greater length. It would require people with farm household support loans to inform the Department of Primary Industries and Energy if they change their address, sell their farm or have some change in their financial position which may affect their capacity to repay the loan.

The amendments set out also that the penalty for failing to provide this information would be imprisonment for six months, which the explanatory memorandum says is consistent with similar penalties in the Social Security Act. I note that many of the clauses in the Social Security Act relating to imprisonment have an accompanying note which says that a court can, if it wishes, impose an appropriate fine instead of a term of imprisonment. I am interested to know if similar flexibility is available under the imprisonment clause contained within this bill. Prison terms, surely, should be a last option. Perhaps the minister would like to comment on this provision in his response to this debate. I ask him to note that.

One final comment I would like to make about farm household support is that the Democrats have always been concerned that this payment is made as a loan and not as a straight-out grant. In the House of Representatives debate the member for Maranoa, Mr Bruce Scott, made the very good point that the last thing that people who have exhausted every source of commercial credit available to them need is another loan hanging over their heads. Of course, given that the chances of being able to sell a drought stricken farming property are pretty slim, that is exactly what they end up withâ€”a loan accruing interest at commercial rates.

Since the object of the farm household support payments is solely to cover day-to-day living expenses for farm families who have no money whatsoever, and no capacity to borrow from any sort of financial institution, I believe they should be made as a grant. When it was first introduced in 1992, my colleague Senator Lees criticised the loan aspect of the scheme when she said:

speech.para: Basically, this amounts to the Government making money out of alleviating poverty.
Surely that is an obscenity. She continued:
To make it clear, we are talking about farmers who need a payment to put food on the table, but may end up after two years with a debt of some $20,000.

The two-year limit, for those farmers who qualified when the scheme was first introduced, will expire early next year at which time they will begin to be charged interest and will have to start making repayments. What we are talking about here is some of Australia's worst-off farmers being penalised for not selling up and getting out of farming altogether. With conditions in rural Australia the way they currently are, most farmers would be lucky to give their farms away, let alone sell them.

para.tab: Yet in March next year we are going to see people having to repay a debt to the Commonwealthâ€”a debt accumulated while those people were basically living in poverty, and a debt on which the Commonwealth is going to charge a commercial interest rate. I simply reiterate that the Democrats believe that, since the object of farm household support payments is solely to cover day-to-day living expenses, they should be made as a grant.

talker.name: Senator SHERRY
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

talk.start.para: â€”I do not intend to comment for long given the time and some albeit critical comments. The Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 is an omnibus bill which gives the opportunity for senators to make fairly wide ranging contributions. The bill goes to amendments in relation to the Wine and Brandy Corporation members of which, I should mention, I was fortunate to have dinner with last night at one of their meetings in Canberra. I think that corporation, together with the research organisation, are doing a fine job in assisting the exports of wine and meeting the $1 billion target.

para.tab: I just mention a particular problem that the export of wine has caused. Unfortunately, the dried fruit industry has been a victim of the wine industry's success. I talked to some dried fruit growers and packers in Mildura on Monday during my visit to that city. Unfortunately, many of the grapes that are required for dried fruit production are going to wine production. Clearly, that is a supply and demand situationâ€”the better price being offered by the wine industry. The unfortunate aspect of that is that the dried fruits industry is not able to supply the market. The dried fruits industry has been a fine example of a very successful and innovative industry, particularly over the last decade when it faced significant competition in the form of cheap dried vine fruit from countries such as Turkey and Iran, where labour is obviously much less expensive.

An interesting aspect of the dried vine fruit industry is that it has met that competition by innovative technology. In the technology that I have looked at, every individual piece of dried vine fruitâ€”every piece of sultanaâ€”that is packaged is individually scanned, cleaned, sized and colour coded. I think there are a million and a half pieces of fruit in one tonne of fruit so it gives us some idea of the sort of technology required to do that. Because of that type of technology, the industry has been able to maintain its market and defeat imports, not just in Australia but also in Europeâ€”primarily Germany. Until this year, Australia was the largest dried vine fruit exporter in the world.

It is an interesting issue because it highlights the fact that the basis of success for rural industries is not in maintaining high tariff protection. There may be some industries where tariff protection at times is necessary, but at the end of the day the dried vine fruit industry has defeated the competition by technology and by innovative marketing. It is the most successful industry of its type in the world. As I said, it is an unfortunate downside of the wine industry's success that it cannot obtain the grapes now to export and meet its export markets. I notice Senator Lees has just come in. She may want to comment on the legislation. I will leave my remarks there. I thank senators for their contributions.

talker.name: Senator LEES
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

talk.start.para: â€”I apologise for my lateness; I had presumed Senator Brownhill, whose name is above mine, would still be speaking. However, I will keep it very brief. I simply want to comment on two bills within this package: the Wine Grapes Levy Amendment Bill 1994 and the Primary Industries Levies and Charges (Wine Grapes) Collection Amendment Bill 1994.

para.tab: As has been mentioned, these bills seek to end the levy exemption for Australia's small wine producers, or those who are processing less than 10 tonnes of grapes. In the past, the small producers have effectively paid the levy through the costs passed on to them by the larger producers so eventually the money has filtered through the system somehow. However, they have not been recognised as official levy payers and therefore have not been entitled to become involved in the activities of the Wine and Brandy Corporation.

Today's changes mean that the small wine producers as official levy payers will now be able to access the marketing, labelling, and research and development activities of the corporation. They will also get a vote at the corporation's annual general meeting. Australia's wine industry supports the changes implemented by these bills, therefore the Democrats will obviously have no problems in supporting these bills as they stand. They provide significant recognition for small wine producers. As Australia's wine industry is surging towards its billion dollar export target by the year 2000, the small producers will continue to play the very vital role that they are playing in achieving that target.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or debate.

Debate resumed from 12 October, on motion by
Senator Schacht
:
That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

talk.start.para: â€”The Drought Relief Payment Bill is the federal government's belated response to the drought which has ravaged so much of Queensland and New South Wales for the past four years. I am concerned that this legislation, like so many other primary industry bills, is cobbled together for passage through this parliament but really does not do justice to that important industry, the primary industry. It is a pity that we see primary industry bills hastened through on the last day of a sitting week, usually in a manner that frustrates the program. It is a pity that we have to deal with this bill in such a manner again today.

para.tab: The bill acknowledges the hardship faced by farmers in exceptional circumstances due to drought, by offering a new welfare payment called the drought relief payment. I understand that the DRP will be subject to the income and off-farm assets tests that apply to jobsearch and will be on the same scale as the jobsearch allowance. The federal coalition welcomes the drought relief payment and, in particular, the government's decision to exclude consideration of farm assets, life insurance and superannuation when DRP rate calculations are being made. For some time the federal coalition has called on the federal government to lift the assets tests in times of severe economic hardship. We are pleased that the government has seen the light.

While the federal coalition is keen to expedite this legislation through parliament, we want to place on record our concerns and our criticisms. For a start, we are at a loss to understand why the government has taken so long to recognise the plight of drought stricken farmers in this country. Similarly, we are disappointed that the government has ignored the consequences of the drought for our important small business sector. It is a matter of record that the government was forced into announcing this package by pressure from opposition members of parliament and through the power of the media.

Once Australians realised the extent of the drought, the fact that there was a real crisis on the land, the government had to act. But not before the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, had arrogantly dismissed the drought as something farmers had to live with. `Look,' he said, `It's always out there. Farmers have just got to learn to manage it.' The reality is that farmers are ill-equipped to cope with such severe droughts, particularly in the current economic circumstances. It is worth repeating that small businesses, particularly those dependent on the rural sector, are hurting and have been forgotten by the government.
As my colleague the shadow minister for primary industry, Mr John Anderson, said in the other place this week:

speech.para: Machinery agents probably start to hurt before most farmers do. In anticipation of tough times, farmers close the cheque books early. Many of the machinery agents out there, who are an absolutely vital part of the farm infrastructure of this nation, have long since folded. I do not know how some of them keep going under the current circumstances.

He added that everyone from fuel agents and contractors to the corner store operator were feeling the pain. It was therefore incumbent on the government to acknowledge the full impact of the drought on rural Australia. My colleagues and I believe in a three-tiered approach to severe drought. First, the adequate delivery of welfare provisions; second, the retention of farms and farm assets; and third, recovery.

para.tab: Drought is not just a welfare issue. It is also an economic issue. The farm sector is extraordinarily important to Australia providing a quarter of our export dollars. Hopefully, that figure will improve, once the drought breaks and we take advantage of rising commodity prices and expanding export opportunities to Asia.

Our farm sector also provides enormous opportunities for employment not only at the base farm production level but also in the food processing sector, which employs some 200,000 people. The government has acknowledged the need to establish new mechanisms to ensure that the farm sector is able to recover and plan for the future once good rains come. Those plans must include preparationsâ€”such as commitments to income equalisation deposits and farm management bondsâ€”to help farmers prepare for the next downturn. Again, that has long been federal coalition policy.

We must not forget that the farm sector is as much a victim of the drought as it is a victim of Labor's failed economic policies. Our farmers have suffered years of farm inflationâ€”sometimes two and three times that of their overseas competitorsâ€”while sending 70 or 80 per cent of their agricultural product abroad. The fact is we are price takers on international markets. So, when our competitiveness is gutted by high domestic prices and ever-rising costs, farmersâ€”not the governmentâ€”make up the difference.

Over the last decade or so, high inflation rates have been accompanied by high interest rates which at one stage exceeded 20 per cent for 18 months. The damage done to the farm sector, at a time of historically low commodity prices, was immense and incalculable. It left farmers, in net terms, with a debt load of about $17.3 billion.

We are now witnessing the end result of a decade of federal Labor governmentâ€”that is, a financially weakened and vulnerable farm sector. Given the financial hardships faced by farmers in the 1980s, they have been unable to prepare themselves for a modest downturn, let alone a severe drought such as this one. Also relevant to the drought debate is the government's refusal to grapple with the problem of high cost imposts, post-farm gate. Report after report has made it clear that the Australian beef industry is disadvantaged by the high costs involved in processing beef in this country compared with our competitors, New Zealand, Argentina or the United States of America.

The latest report, released six weeks ago, explains why our producers are internationally competitive: they take a lower return at the farm gate. Farmers are still bearing the brunt of the federal government's decision that the farm sector should face a level playing field, ahead of anyone else. As a nation, we need to address the problem of post-drought reconstruction and, as far as possible, prevent our best farmers from going under. Clearly, the government agrees with the federal coalition on this point. It has picked up one of our rural assistance policy commitments: that the maximum allowable assistance with interest rates be significantly upgraded from $50,000 a year to $100,000 or $300,000 over five years.

The government has also picked up our policy to extend relief beyond the end of the drought. That extra time will allow farmers, farm leaders, lenders and governments to negotiate ways of reconstructing debt loads. Now that the government is committed to post-drought assistance, it is not unreasonable to ask lenders to offer a similar long-term commitment to farmers. To that end, the coalition has set up a shadow ministry subcommittee to investigate this issue.

While the severity and rapidity of the drought caught many by surprise, I would like to remind the Senate of comments made by the shadow minister for primary industry last year. Speaking in the other place, Mr Anderson warned that a severe drought was emerging in parts of Queenslandâ€”a situation so serious that it demanded food parcels and donations from charitable organisations. He also highlighted the growing human tragedy: the strain on farmers and on their families as they struggled to hold on to drought stricken properties. That was May 1993.

Now, more than a year later, the government has bowed to public and parliamentary pressure and announced a drought relief package. It is worth noting the comments of the President of the New South Wales Farmers Association at a drought meeting in Sydney this week. Mr John Crawford put the crisis in historical context when he said that New South Wales was facing its worst drought in 50 years, and that many farmers were killing their breeding stock. Given the severity of the droughtâ€”and the anomalies in the existing guidelinesâ€”it is clear that new mechanisms need to be developed in order to better identify areas of greatest need.

For instance, there are enormous needs in the Scone, Maryvale, and Mudgee areas, which have somehow been excluded from the list of exceptional drought areas. Those farmers face extraordinarily difficult circumstances yet, under the current rigid guidelines, may have to wait many months before receiving assistance.

In winding up, I would like to reiterate the federal coalition's concern about the devastating effects of severe drought on the small business sector, as well as the farm sector. Small businesses in badly affected areas have experienced a severe and sustained downturn in trade, with a corresponding reduction in income and, what we all have to acknowledge, the threat and constant problem of rising interest rates. We need to ensure their survival. After all, small businesses have substantial investments in assets and expertise which will be crucial to reconstruction after the drought.

The federal coalition has called on the federal government to return severe drought to the national disaster relief arrangements. This would provide a mechanism for assisting small businesses where currently no mechanism exists. Overall, the federal coalition welcomes the initiatives in this legislation, and is pleased to support the bill.

question.speaker: Newman Sen J.M.

talk.start.para: â€”My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Paul Keating in his press release of yesterday said:

question.para: My considered support for Australia's involvement in the Gulf has been corroborated by a number of sources today. Namely, by the recollections of Senators Evans and Ray . . .

When did the minister corroborate Mr Keating's version of events? How could the minister's repeated refusal to answer my questions in this chamber yesterday be taken as corroboration by Mr Keating? I again ask the minister: was advice sought from the ADF? If so, when? What was it? Was the Prime Minister's adviser, Hugh White, present? Will I stop while the minister gets his briefing from the leader?

talk.start.para: â€”No, carry on, Senator Newman.
â€”Were the minister's advisers present, and did the advice include the proposal to deploy FA18s?

â€”I will leave the first part until last because I think it might be appropriate as the opposition has a complete misunderstanding of the processes involved. Let me at least run through them for the record so those opposite will understand the processes.

para.tab: The meeting of 29 November was not a final decision meeting; it was a meeting between senior ministers to establish what a common view would be. Having established that common view, each of the relevant ministers would then give instructions to their departments; a cabinet submission would be drawn up; that would be considered by cabinet; the opposition leader and defence spokesman would be consulted; the caucus would be consulted; and a statement delivered in parliament. That is the process. So the meeting on 29 November was not a meeting of a cabinet committee or of a cabinet subcommittee. So in terms of that process, that is why there are not cabinet note takers, and this is a constant process of government. No doubt those on the opposition side, in the long dark memories of when they were last in government, followed a similar process.

Senator Newman asked me whether the Prime Minister's foreign affairs, defence and immigration adviser was present at the meeting on 29 November. He was present at that particular meeting. There was at least one other senior adviser present. I think the Deputy Prime Minister's senior adviser was also present at that particular meeting.

I was asked whether there were any Defence officials or advisers at that meeting. The answer is no. They constantly met with me through the whole of the Gulf conflict to give me advice which I would take on board at any one of those senior meetings.

I was asked a question about FA18s. At the time of the first commitment, which was in fact for sanction enforcement, not a question of conflict, the only commitment that we entered into was for two frigates and a supply ship. As events unfolded and the new United Nations decisions came down, and when the six-week deadline was put on Iraq to comply, a whole menu of possible contributions for Australia was considered.

talk.start.para: â€”By whom?

â€”By me, and later on raised with others. In my view, though, the question of FA18s was only ever raised with me per se and was rejected after discussions with Defence officials, and it was not put forward necessarily as a recommendation of the department officials. Clearly the question of F111s was raised first by US officials during the AUSMIN talks with the CDF.

para.tab: In terms of its being raised with senior ministers, I have a recollection that I raised it during the meeting on 29 November when we were considering whether we should have two combat ships or four combat ships involved in the more intense operations in the Persian Gulf rather than in the Gulf of Oman. So it was in that context that it was raised. I would suspect that the Prime Minister is confused over that one point, as to whether it was FA18s or F111s discussed at that meeting.

Finally, I will go back to the first question. Senator Newman asked me how the Prime Minister could base his press release on my recollections. The Prime Minister based the press release on an answer to a question I gave on the
Sunday
program on 14 August 1994. That program preceded the official launch of the Hawke biography by a day or two.

Laurie Oakes asked me about an allegation. Honourable senators know it well; it has been repeated many times. I gave the following answer: `Well, I can't say whether it happened or not'â€”that is, whether Paul Keating made a statement about US involvementâ€”`but I have no recollection of that. My only real recollection of the meeting, in terms of opposition, was the sort of whimsical opposition of John Button, who said that we shouldn't be involved and that he was an east of Suez man.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: â€”My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. I was interested to read newspaper reports this week of a survey which claimed that many small businesses had negative perceptions of the government. This result is difficult to reconcile with my own contact with the small business sector, which I have found to be very open-minded and positive about government policy. I observe that the minister said that these results should be viewed with caution. Could the minister inform the Senate on what grounds he reached his conclusion?

â€”I am aware of the Yellow Pages small business index special report. I have already issued a statement saying that it should be treated with some caution. All of us who have any connection with small business realise that the small business community is a pretty robust bunch of people. They usually have a very direct attitude about the government and politicians, whether they are federal, state or local. Many of their complaints, as reflected in this survey, deal with those perceptions. We recognise that those perceptions are strongly held but, despite that, this government has a good working relationship with the small business community.

para.tab: However, there are a couple of reasons why we should view some of the responses with caution. For example, one of the areas in which the small business community disagrees with government policy or has a negative view is taxationâ€”39 per cent of the respondents mention taxation. Clearly, they want reduced taxation. Twenty-five per cent of the respondents also said that they disagree with the federal government on the so-called absence of incentives for small business.

There is quite a contradiction. All incentives cost the federal government revenue. Whatever the government provides costs money. If we provide increased incentives, we either have to increase taxation or cut expenditure somewhere else. So there is clearly a contradiction. But it is not unusual for people in the community to say, `Increase taxation elsewhere, but not on me. Give my sector of the community increased government assistance.'

While I am talking about assistance to the small business sector, I point out that the sectors that have access to the programs announced in the industry part of the Working Nation statement earlier this year have responded very well. The Small Business Coalitionâ€”representing 37 small business organisationsâ€”unanimously welcomed the initiatives in Working Nation, as the initiatives helped small business. I also point out that there have been other surveys recently indicating the health and growth in small business. The Yellow Pages small business index report on industrial relations, released by the very same organisation, showed that nearly a third of employers surveyed took on more staff in the past quarter.

Another comprehensive survey with the Australian Bureau of Statisticsâ€”a business expectations surveyâ€”has been developed by the ABS in response to the need for better information on future trading conditions in Australia. The survey is conducted by mail each quarter, and 3,000 representatives of Australian businesses are sampled. That survey showed the expectations for the December quarter 1994 and September quarter 1995. They both showed that the outlook for small business is very good indeed. Profits in the medium term are expected by small business to rise by 26 per cent and employment is expected to rise by 1.5 per cent. Small businesses are also expecting to increase capital expenditure by a remarkable 19 per cent in the medium term.

These expectations are borne out today by the excellent employment figures, which show that in September 75,700 new jobs were created in Australia and around 69,000 of them were full-time jobs. This means that for the first time in Australia's history total employment is now a record eight million plus. More Australians are employed than ever before, and of these the figure for female employment is 3.4 million.

talk.start.para: â€”So it should be.
â€”Again, I have to draw attention to the fact that every time I give good news to the Senate, Senator Kemp interjects because he hates good news.

â€”My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Could the minister inform the Senate how many applications were received for membership of the Immigration Review Tribunal in response to public advertisements prior to the last round of 20 new appointments? Did all of the minister's appointees make applications through the normal processes for the panel to assess? Were all the successful applicants interviewed by the panel? If not, which ones were not interviewed and what were the reasons for their appointments?

â€”The second part of Senator Short's question as to who was interviewed he flagged yesterday, and I took the matter on notice. In terms of the number of applicants, I will take that on notice and give him that answer with the other answers.

â€”Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It shows the grasp this minister has of his portfolio because he told me in answer to a question on notice two days ago that there were 750 applications, which therefore means that 97 out of every 100 applicants were rejected. Is the minister seriously telling the Senate that persons such as Mr Alevizos and Mr Labbozzetta, preselected Labor Party candidates for the next election, and others appointed because of Senator Bolkus's political patronage and nepotism, were better qualified for appointment than the 730 or thereabouts applicants who were rejected, many of whom had outstanding and highly relevant qualifications?

â€”This is a continuation, and in response to this question I had a look at the qualifications of Mr Alevizos. Not only has he got formal qualifications in education with a graduate diploma in business administration, and head of the humanities faculty of Seymour Collegeâ€”he is senior teacher of history and legal studies of that collegeâ€”but he also is a former member of the executive of the South Australian Greek community and has other associated interests. The matter is not as simple as Senator Short portrayed yesterday. The point I make is that every time Senator Short has raised a point about any of the appointments, he has come in with a slanted view, a critically biased view and he has blackguarded reputations. For instance, he mentioned yesterday Pam O'Neil, the person who has been the head of the tribunal since 1989. She has developed a good reputation over that period. Senator Short himself has not criticised her but probably has praised her in the time that he has held the shadow portfolio, and I am sure other shadow ministers have praised her as well. But yesterday he came in and accused of her being politically biased.
â€”Answer the question.
â€”The answer to Senator Short's question is that we have chosen the best group for the job, and I am sure of that.

â€”My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer the minister to reports, which I am sure he has seen, of recent developments in the Gulf, including reports of Iraqi troop withdrawals from that country's border with Kuwait. Is the minister in a position to outline for the Senate the current situation? On the related issue of international sanctions, can the minister give an assessment on a report by UNICEF which suggests that up to 2,500,000 women and children in Iraq face severe malnutrition because of acute food shortages?

â€”As honourable senators will be aware, there are now confirmed reports of the withdrawal of Iraqi troops on the border with Kuwait, and the immediate military threat to Kuwait has now clearly passed. But it would be premature to draw any conclusions about longer-term Iraqi intentions and, in that context, the United States, while cautiously acknowledging that Iraqi withdrawal, is continuing to deploy forces in Kuwait. Kuwait itself is continuing its defensive deployments, and the UK, France, and some other members of the Gulf Co-operation Council have also deployed forces there.

para.tab: As I said in this place on Monday, the Australian government does, of course, fully support the statement by the President of the Security Council on 8 October emphasising the necessity for Iraq to fully implement all relevant Security Council resolutions and reaffirming the Security Council's commitment to Kuwait's sovereignty and territorial integrity. The Australian government also supports efforts by the United States to implement measures to ensure that Iraq is unable to invade or threaten Kuwait in the future.

We also strongly support efforts now under way in the UN Security Council to ensure that Iraq withdraws all its troops which it has moved into the border region to prevent Iraq from threatening its neighbours now or in the future. In that context, the precise form of the Security Council action, whether a resolution or a presidential statement, is still at an early stage of discussion, but measures which are under consideration, if accepted by the council, would preclude reinforcement of the troops that Iraq would be permitted to leave behind and would threaten serious consequences should Iraq not comply.

One possible measure which has been publicly discussed is the imposition of a demilitarised zone, also referred to as a no-drive or a no-tank zone, south of the 32nd parallel, 230 kilometres from the Iraq-Kuwait border. The implications, I have to say, of such a measure would need careful consideration as there has to be a clear perception by Security Council decision makers, even if this is not made fully public at the time, as to what actually happens next in the event of such measures of prevention actually failingâ€”the trip wire being crossed, in other words.

As to the second part of Senator Loosley's question, I am aware of UNICEF's report detailing the appalling humanitarian situation facing the people of Iraq, but it needs to be appreciated that Iraq is already permitted under the terms of UN Security Council resolutions 706 and 712, passed in 1991, to sell oil to an amount of $US1.6 billion over a six-month period, of which 30 per cent has to be available for humanitarian relief. But the Iraqi government has chosen not to exercise that option. It has always been within the Iraqi government's capacity to comply not only with that oil-for-food resolution but also with the relevant UN Security Council resolutions that would lead to a lifting of all sanctions.

The responsibility for the situation in which Iraq now finds itself is, therefore, entirely and unequivocally that of Saddam Hussein. That said, one's heart does still, of course, go out to those ordinary people of the country who are victims of this appalling man's intransigence. In that sense, I should also point out that we in Australia have contributed $3.6 million in emergency food aid to Iraq. This included $700,000 given to the non-governmental organisation CARE in November last year for emergency food aid for the needy and particularly for children.

talk.start.para: â€”My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Does the minister believe that recent developments in the NRMA ballot, in which progressive results of the count were made available to some members of the NRMA board prior to the ballot closing date, constitute proper practices? In light of the NRMA's misleading advertising campaign, the dissemination of conflicting information, the early counting of votes, the absence of scrutineers at the count and the conflict of board members' interests, what capacity is there for the federal government to intervene at this late stage, especially in terms of the provisions of the corporations law? Will the federal government now give consideration to requesting the NRMA board to conduct a re-ballot of NRMA members, and to request that the Australian Electoral Commission be appointed to oversee that ballot?

â€”My advice is that there is no requirement under the Corporations Law to keep the results of a vote of members confidential prior to the ballot closing. I am further advised that, other than the Corporations Law, it is a matter for the articles of association of the NRMA, what legal interpretation is given to those articles and what common law principles are applied to those articles of association.

para.tab: In respect of Senator Bourne's second question, the ASC is continuing to closely monitor the restructuring of the NRMA to ensure that there is compliance with the requirements of the Corporations Law and, of course, as it monitors the NRMA, that is very much a matter for the ASC to determine how it does so.

In respect to a re-ballot, I am informed that in order for a re-ballot to take place a defect in the manner in which the vote of members was conducted would have to be determined by reference to the requirements set out in the articles of association of the NRMA, as I mentioned earlier. Therefore, it is primarily the responsibility of NRMA members to take action to enforce their rights in relation to matters arising out of voting by members.

talk.start.para: â€”My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. Each year in Germany, the city of Hanover conducts the world's largest information technology fair, CeBit. Next year, 1995, Australia will be the partner country to CeBit 95. Can the minister inform the Senate of the export opportunities likely to arise for the Australian information technology industry from Australia's centre stage participation in next year's fair?

answer.speaker: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

talk.start.para: â€”CeBit 95 is a very important showcase for the latest computer hardware and software, and for telecommunications, networking and associated technologies. It is internationally regarded as a very important event. Last year, it attracted some 675,000 visitors from 100 countries and 5,850 exhibitors from 54 countries. In 1995 it will be even bigger, with 6,000 exhibitors having confirmed space. Attendance is expected to be over 700,000 and some 8,000 representatives of the press will be covering the event. So it is very significant for Australia to have been chosen as the partner country; and an important recognition of the Australian information technology industry and its significance, role and growth in the very hot international competition in this industry.

para.tab: It is interesting to noteâ€”and a bit unusual, I suppose, to indicate in response to a ques-

answer.para: tion from a government senator; but it is trueâ€”that there is a bit of a problem. We are succeeding too well. We might have a problem because we have been allocated space to accommodate 122 Australian companies but, I am delighted to say, already about 130 Australian companies and organisations have placed commitments with Austrade. To put that in perspective, usually we get about 20. Our initial target, which we thought would be a great success for CeBit 95, was 65. We had to increase that to 122. We now have 130. It is not a problem beyond resolution; and the problem of succeeding too well is a very nice problem to have. It is an example of not just the information technology industry but Australian industry generally being much more outward looking and export oriented.

para.tab: We will be operating at CeBit 95 under the banner of `Intelligent Australia', designed to embody our skill in creating and using IT applications in a variety of areas, as well as our development in information technology and telecommunications equipment, which is selling very well all around the world. Telecommunications equipment has been associated with some of the trade missions that I have taken away. There have been successful sales in Latin America and in many of the countries of Asia. We have also succeeded in some of the other competitive markets around the world. There are good prospects if the Japanese market opens, as we hope it will, that we will do well in Japan. So we should be very proud of our expertise.

Senator Foreman asked me specifically whether we could get an assessment of the likely export outcomes. Of course, it is speculative, but Austrade's estimate at the moment is that our presence at the fair, based on claims of previous participants, could conservatively result in an extra $200 million in export earnings for participating companies. Previous individual participants have claimed to have each gained between $1 million and $2 million worth of business. So we can see from the level of participation, and the previous history of success, that about $200 million in extra export earnings is a reasonable expectation. That is not a bad return on taxpayers' money when we realise that it will cost Austrade $2.8 million to participate.

talk.start.para: â€”My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Justice. I refer the minister to the appointment by the Minister for Justice of Mr Daryl Smeaton to head, as its executive member, the newly established Commonwealth Law Enforcement Board. I ask: is it true that up until the time of his recent appointment by Mr Kerr, Mr Smeaton was in fact a senior political adviser to Mr Kerr? Is it also true that Mr Kerr appointed his senior staffer to the position, which carries a salary package in excess of $100,000, without it being publicly advertised? Apart from the fact that he had worked for Mr Kerr, can the minister please advise the Senate as to the professional qualifications and experience of Mr Smeaton which influenced Mr Kerr in making his appointment? Does the appointment of Mr Smeaton add further to the stench which surrounds the habit of Labor ministers appointing mates and Labor staffers to top jobs?

â€”Mr Deputy President, there are in this place offensive questions and offensive contributions. But when someone asks a question about the appointment of a person who has been a long time public servant of the Commonwealthâ€”for some 20 years or soâ€”who has spent a short period of his professional career on the staff of a minister and who has then taken on a position back in the public sector, appointed without interference and on his merits, I think we have really hit the bottom of the gutter, and Senator Calvert ought to be ashamed of it.

â€”My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. I note that the annual report of the Australian Customs Service was tabled in the Senate yesterday and that the report revealed a downturn in the seizure of drugs in 1993-94. Has the minister any comment on the changes in the figures for drugs seizure? In this context, is the minister aware of claims that there is insufficient presence of Customs and other law enforcement agencies in some areas of the Australian border, particularly Torres Strait? Can the minister inform the Senate whether there is any validity in these claims?

answer.speaker: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

talk.start.para: â€”Yes, the Customs annual report was tabled in the Senate yesterday. I place on record that the new CEO, Lionel Woodward, and the staff are getting on with the job of carrying out the reform process of Customs in accordance with the recommendations of the Conroy review, which both sides of parliament strongly endorsed. That review gave special emphasis to improving contacts with industry. However, we have not in any way reduced our concern about protecting the border of Australia, in which Customs has a critical role to perform.

para.tab: In that context, the annual report for 1993-94 shows that on a weight basis seizures were down from the previous year. However, this arises because two very large seizures of marijuana accounted for the bulk of the seizures by weight in 1992-93. Accordingly, on a weight basis, the figures understandably fluctuate.

While I cannot give any guarantee that 100 per cent of drugs attempted to be smuggled into Australia can be intercepted, I believe that Customs and other law enforcement agencies are doing an excellent job in their border protection work. By way of example, since the reporting period we have seen a seizure of 1.5 tonnes of cannabis leaf in North Queensland, a seizure of five tonnes of cannabis resin in Queensland and some very significant heroin seizures, including 124 kilograms in Darwin.

I am aware of claims that there is insufficient presence of Customs and other law enforcement agencies in the Torres Strait area. Those claims were made last month by none other than Senator Ian Macdonald. On North Queensland Television on 29 September, Senator Macdonald said:

answer.para: I do have descriptions of the type of people who are doing it and the descriptions of an actual person involved. And certainly I'd be making the authorities aware of those things that have been told to me.

There seems to be a remarkable lack of Federal Police in the Torres Strait Island areas, and I'll be pursuing when I get back to Canberra why the Customs presence is so minimal and that there is no, or apparently no, Federal Police presence at all.
For the record, two weeks later, so far as my records show, Senator Macdonald has not raised this issue with me, my office or the Minister for Justice.

talk.start.para: â€”Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I will not sit here on a televised day and have the minister telling lies about me. As I said I would in the chamber, I wrote to the Attorney-General on 4 October. The minister just is not aware of what is happening in his own department. I asked the Attorney-General to pass the letter on to any other relevant minister.
â€”Order! That is not a point of order, Senator Macdonald.
â€”According to my records, we have not received any information in Customs about it.
â€”Here it is, you dill!

â€”If Senator Macdonald has written to the Attorney-General with the information, I am very pleased, because he said he knew of the presence of people and who they were. I hope that in that letter to the Attorney-General he has given information about criminality that he knows about; that would be his responsibility as a citizen.

para.tab: I want to put the record straight about the presence Customs has in the Torres Strait. There are eight Customs officers on Thursday Island tasked with maintaining Customs control. Customs cooperates with the Australian Federal Police, the Queensland police and the PNG authorities to continually assess the risk in the Torres Strait area and exchange information. Customs staff carry out their role with a 42-foot launch and there is also a Customs Coastwatch presence. Torres Strait is the most heavily patrolled area of any area of the Australian coastline. So that is what we are providing. In the recent new Coastwatch contract we gave special emphasis to the upgrading of Coastwatch surveillance in the Torres Strait area.

talk.start.para: â€”I direct my question to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Given his comments in New Zealand on Monday to a greenhouse conference that `in Australia's view negotiation is bound to take longer than the short time left until the Berlin conference' in relation to Australia being unable to meet its obligations under the United Nations Convention on Climate Control in a timely fashion, can the minister explain why the government has not learnt from its mistakes in signing UN treaties before the wider implications of signature are known and is still proposing to sign the UN Convention to Combat Desertification tomorrow? Will the minister concede that such haste is not in Australia's best interest but is simply the result of a desire to be internationally popular?

â€”Australia's approach to negotiations in relation to climate change is governed by the need to protect and promote our environment, our trade, our economic and our foreign policy interests, including our commitments to global action and to Pacific island countries, which are vulnerable to the potential impacts of climate change.

para.tab: As a party to the framework convention on climate change, the most practicable approach for Australia that would advance our national interests is to remain actively engaged in the negotiation process. Australia will take an active role in INC and the conference of the parties' negotiations so that we can promote the development of realistic and equitable proposals for increasing the effectiveness of global action related to the strengthening of the convention's commitments. That is based on the principle of equitable burden sharing among developed countries. Australia also seeks to encourage greater involvement by developing countries over time.

Senator Chapman has the gall for some reason or other to raise our involvement in an international convention on desertification. Let me say in relation to this convention that Australia was active throughout the five negotiating sessions, reflecting our very strong commitment to international efforts to promote sustainable development and in view of our experience as a developed country in addressing arid land management. The Australian delegation included officials of government departments, representatives of the states, representatives of the National Farmers Federation and also the Australian Conservation Foundation.

Interest groups were invited to attend briefings with government officials, both before and after each negotiating session, and also to contribute to the Australian brief for the delegation. Australia's objectives for the negotiations on desertification were to seek a convention which was global in its scope, but which also provided for the development of regional, national and local programs to combat desertification.

We took a very constructive approach, focusing on the causes of desertification and encouraging a bottom-up approach to dealing with this very important issue. The central element of our strategy to achieve the convention's objectives is the preparation, publication and implementation of national action programs to combat desertification.

Australia's preference was to make optional the preparation of such national action programs, as I have said in here before, by affected developed parties. Our record in relation to our international involvement in both the framework convention on climate change and in desertification is in support of these very important principles, and I believe that we can stand on our record in that regard.

talk.start.para: â€”Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It is clear from the minister's answer that he is oblivious to the continuing widespread concerns about this particular convention on the part of many groups in the community, as has been revealed by the opposition's committee of inquiry into this matter which has raised a wide range of issues and concerns. Therefore, I ask the minister why the government refuses to delay signing this convention for several months to allow further proper investigation of these issues, given that there is no urgency to sign the convention because it will take approximately six months until sufficient countries have signed the convention to enable ratification.

â€”The negotiations for a desertification convention were concluded on 17 June this year. The convention is to be open for signature at a special signing ceremony in Paris on 14 and 15 October. I have to say to Senator Chapman that I do not give a damn about the coalition's inquiry into this particular matter. The opposition would be better off having an inquiry into the disunity within its own ranks on this and all sorts of other issues. The opposition would be better off having an inquiry into how the hell it might win a few elections or into its leadership woes. I can suggest all sorts of things that the Liberals would be better off involving themselves in rather than worrying about desertification.
â€”On a point of order, Mr Deputy President: I think the minister has wandered away from the question and he should be directed back to the question.

â€”Mr Deputy President, my point of order is as to relevance. The answer the minister has been giving has nothing to do with the question. Maybe the minister could give a damn about what people like the National Farmers Federation and the Australian Mining Industry Council say. What is the hurry?

â€”On the point of order: this is yet another occasion when Senator Kemp takes a spurious point of order outside the standing orders to make an inaccurate point that my comments on a coalition inquiry referred to other matters. I think he should be thrown out.

â€”Order! I have a whole list of names I would like to throw out! In respect of the point of order: the latter part of Senator Kemp's point of order was gratuitous; the first part was legitimate. The latter part of the minister's answer was out of order. Have you finished, Senator Faulkner?
â€”Yes, Mr Deputy President.

â€”My question is also directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories in the context of his recent statements about Australia's failure to meet either its national or international commitment on greenhouse gas reduction and the government's appeal for more time in the context of the decision at the recent ANZMEC ministers meeting in which a decision was taken not to implement minimum energy performance standards that took four years to develop and are a central plank to the national greenhouse response strategy. I ask: how does the government expect to retrieve any credibility in its greenhouse response when there is no commitment and no integration between ministries? Does the government expect ever to meet greenhouse targets in the current circumstances?

â€”The government remains committed to our national and international targets. It is true that the recently released greenhouse gas inventory confirms that, with the current measures in place, Australia is only a little over halfway towards achieving stabilisation of emissions in the year 2000. A coordinated effort involving all the key government agencies is currently under way to address the shortfall in greenhouse gas abatement. In December of this year, cabinet will be considering the second phase of Australia's domestic response to greenhouse.

para.tab: To facilitate this process there are a number of interdepartmental working groups at the Commonwealth level developing a range of possible policy options for consideration by cabinet. In addition to that, a task force of Commonwealth and state officials will be examining how the states might contribute to additional action. Furthermore, to ensure that the community at large has an opportunity to contribute to this important process, we will be asking for input from our national greenhouse advisory panel. Community stakeholders can coordinate contributions and input through the panel.

With respect to the recent decisions of ANZMEC on national minimum energy performance standards, which Senator Margetts asked me about, these matters obviously are the domain of my colleague Senator Collins, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I suggest to Senator Margetts that any detailed questions in relation to those matters be referred to Senator Collins. My understanding of the ANZMEC meeting is that national minimum energy performance standards for refrigerators, freezers and electric storage hot water heaters were not rejected at that meeting. I think ministers agreed to communicate with each other again on the matter, following discussions with both the industry and consumer groups.

In my view, the national energy performance standards are a very important part of our greenhouse response and they certainly should be implemented as soon as possible. I expect that Australia will be in a position to report on additional policy options to those that were reported in our first national communications to the conference of parties in Berlin. I believe that this is going to signal Australia's continued commitment to greenhouse gas abatement.

talk.start.para: â€”Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister and I assure him that we will be directing a number of future questions on this issue to Senator Collins. The minister knows that many actions of the government are contrary to the national greenhouse response strategy and to ESD policies, and these contra-productive policies are usually deemed more important and are better resourced. Will it be more difficult and expensive to meet targets the longer emissions are allowed to grow, and will it not disadvantage us more and more if other countries act while we do nothing?

â€”I have made the point very clear that Australia is not standing still and doing nothing. It is clear, and I think most people with at least an average level of intelligence would accept, that the longer the situation goes on without abatement, the more difficult the challenge will become. If we look at the greenhouse gas inventory that was published, we see that there is a clear difference between the baseline levels that were indicated for 1988 and those of 1990. So it is not unreasonable to suggest that without proper measures in place the problem will get worse.

para.tab: I am indicating to Senator Margetts that the government is committed to an appropriate national greenhouse response. We will be looking at new options to ensure that we meet the national and international targets that have been set.

talk.start.para: â€”My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Noting the Prime Minister's comments at a business dinner in Adelaide last week, that an Australian republic was central to Australia's economic fortunes in the Asia-Pacific area and would `open up tremendous trade opportunities', will the minister please quantify how much Australia has lost in international trade, from what countries and what commodities, say, in the last two years, by not becoming a republic?

â€”Mr Deputy President, it is not a matter of losing trade as a result of being a monarchy. It is a matter of changing the perception of the kind of country we are by becoming, in due course, a republic and, as such, perceived to be genuinely independent, genuinely responding to changed circumstances, genuinely being a country determined to assert our independence and to play a new and striking role in the region.

para.tab: A lot of the decisions that are made about contracts, a lot of the decisions that are made about tender purchases are based on qualitative judgments about the kind of country we are perceived to be. There is no doubt that the kind of country that the opposition would like us to remain, the kind of country that Joan Sutherland would like us to remain, is not the kind of country that is likely to be perceived by any of the thriving, new, dynamic economies in our region as a country with which it is sensible to do modern business. I do not know what the Prime Minister had in mind in the remarks which Senator Panizza quotes but that seems to me to be a pretty reasonable approximation.

talk.start.para: â€”Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. The Prime Minister must have had a reason for making this statement and he must have done some research. I know that Senator Evans's memory is not too good going beyond 12 months. So would he like to give us an idea of the benefits we would gain, from which countries and in which commodities, say, in the next two years, if we became a republic today?

â€”It is the case, as is universally well known, that the Prime Minister always intensely researches the answers that he gives, except of course in circumstances where the answer is self-evident, and it was such a case on this occasion.

â€”My question is directed to the minister representing the Minister for Justice. I refer to recent investigations by the Australian Federal Police into alleged illegal telephone monitoring and recording by Telecom, and ask: does the minister acknowledge that Telecom lost its shield of crown immunity in February 1992, under sections 26 and 29 of the Australian Telecommunications Corporations Act? Can the minister confirm that, surprisingly, the Federal Police have been given legal advice which is in conflict with that generally accepted view, namely, that they cannot execute search warrants on Telecom because Telecom is protected, presumably, by the shield of the crown? What is the source of this astonishing advice? To what extent has this advice prevented the Federal Police from gathering evidence?

â€”I thank Senator Spindler for this question primarily because it gives me an opportunity to notice the presence in the President's gallery of the McKiernan family, all the way from England and Ireland, who I believe are having one of their last days in Australia. It is good to see they have come to see their brother perform.

para.tab: As for Senator Spindler's question, I am not in a position to respond immediately in regard to crown immunity. This is a legal matter which is being pursued with the Attorney-General's Department, and of course I will take that part of the question on notice.

In respect to the second part of the senator's question, I am advised by the AFP that the Director of Public Prosecutions initially provided advice to the AFP to the effect that a search warrant under section 10 of the Crimes Act 1914 would not lie against premises of Telstra by virtue of the ruling by the Full Federal Court in Rogers v. Moore 1993 41 FCR page 301.

As to the third part of the senator's question, the DPP advice flowed from consultations on the investigation by the AFP of alleged offences by Telstra against the Telecommunications Interception Act 1979. As to the last part of the question, the AFP investigation remains ongoing and therefore I am not in a position to comment on the nature of the evidence gathered by the AFP.

question.speaker: Spindler Sen S.E.

talk.start.para: â€”Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am grateful to the minister for the opportunity to add my good wishes to the family of Senator Jim McKiernan. Coming to the second part of the minister's answer, I would like to point out to him that on good advice Rogers and Moore is inapplicable to this particular issue since it refers to the Crimes Act 1914 provisions. To assist the minister, I would like to briefly quote to the minister section 26:

question.para: ALTC is taken for the purposes of the law of the Commonwealth, of a State or of a Territory:

para.tab: (a) not to have been incorporated or established for a public purpose or for a purpose of the Commonwealth; and
(b) not to be a public authority or an instrumentality or agency of the Crown; and
(c) not to be entitled to any immunity or privilege of the Commonwealth;

question.para: If the minister finds it difficult to interpret thatâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”Order! Your time has expired.
â€”May I finish, Mr Deputy President?
â€”I wish to take a point of order. These were the people who imposed these restrictions so they are going to have to live with them.

â€”Order! I have a habit of allowing both the questioner and the answerer to finish the sentence and to make logic of what is being said. Senator Spindler, if you can finish in one sentence, carry on.
â€”Section 29, I would point out to the minister, provides that there must be:

question.para: . . . express provision of this Act or any other law of the Commonwealth.

talk.start.para: â€”I can say two things: Senator Spindler might be surprised to know I really have not focused on or read that particular part of the report he is referring to. On that basis, I could probably be accused of dereliction of duty. Secondly, I might also suggest to Senator Spindler that we will take on board his legal advice and pass it on to the Attorney-General, the Minister for Justice and the Attorney-General's Department. Hopefully, in the melting pot of advice that they get, they can distil your suggestion with theirs and come up with an answer.

â€”My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. As the minister would be aware, hopelessness will set in with farming families fighting the drought if the bank foreclosures haunt post-drought recovery. Therefore, the minister would be aware that three weeks ago, on 21 September, when announcing the government's drought assistance package, the Prime Minister said that he would be personally meeting with the major banks `in the first instance'. He said, `We'll be meeting about what their policy and attitude is to supporting farmers through this period and what longer-run view they are going to take.' Therefore, I ask the minister: has the Prime Minister kept his commitment and met with senior bank officials on behalf of the rural community? If so, when, and who was present? What were the results of the meeting with regard to a bank drought policy and a government mechanism to monitor that policy?

â€”I will have to ask Senator McGauran to repeat the last part of his question, as I could not hear it. In terms of dealing with the meeting with the banks, the Prime Minister said yes in the first instance. Is Senator McGauran pointing at me?
â€”I am pointing at Senator Ray.
â€”It's rude to point!

â€”The Prime Minister was referring to the substantial commitment that he gave on behalf of the government. In respect of that post-reconstruction period, the Prime Minister said that the government would consider providing generous investment allowances in respect of drought-proofing measures, which in policy terms is very welcome news for the rural sector of Australia. He said he would speak to the banks in respect of those measures, and I know that the Prime Minister will do that.

para.tab: I have, in fact, written to the Australian Bankers Association and received a very positive response to that letter in respect of the support that the banking community is giving the rural sector. I know that, in terms of the feedback I have had directly from primary producers across Australia, there was an opportunity second to none of canvassing all issues in respect of the drought, including their relationship with lenders. Not only did I not receive any detailed or aggressive criticism of the banks, but the reverse was in fact the case.

All the primary producers to whom I spoke, and the peak bodies that represent them, told me that they had very little complaint to make about the way they were being treated by their banks. The banks I spoke to were, in every individual case, extremely responsible about the situation that farmers were in and were making a positive effort in respect of farmers who were assessed as being long-term viable, to sustain them through this very difficult period.

I know that a number of banks have quite sophisticated, internal arrangements in terms of people who are dedicated to the rural lending sector in order to look after these particular accounts. I, along with many others, will be interested to hear the result of the discussions the Prime Minister has with the banking community. We are in a strong position to speak to the banks on this occasion because the federal government in its drought package has provided an extremely substantial package of assistance, a great deal of which is directed to subsidising the interest on the loans that the banks are providing. We are in a strong position to say to the banks, `We are doing our bit to help farmers through this drought. We hope you will continue to do yours.'

talk.start.para: â€”Can the Minister for Environment, Sport and Territories elaborate on recent media reports that Australia has entered into a sport cooperative agreement with the New Zealand government to assist New Zealand athletes in their preparation for the Sydney 2000 Olympics? What benefits can Australian athletes expect to receive from closer cooperation with New Zealand?

â€”We have close sporting relations with New Zealand. The Australian Sports Commission and the Hillary Commission in New Zealand have a formal arrangement under which exchanges of programs and information can take place. For example, our highly successful Aussie sports program has been introduced into New Zealand as Kiwi sport. In return, we have borrowed extensively from the New Zealand volunteer program to introduce our national volunteer involvement program. New Zealand is already a full member of the Sport and Recreation Ministers Council and its officials body, the Standing Committee on Recreation and Sport. I met with my New Zealand counterpart, Mr John Banks, on 10 October to formalise a closer exchange arrangement under which both countries will benefit in the lead up to the year 2000 Olympics in Sydney.

para.tab: We are not talking about giving away any of our trade secrets in our highly successful sports, such as swimming or cycling, or in areas such as biomechanics expertise. What we are looking at is a higher level of competition between athletes of our two countries in events such as a track and field grand prix. International competition is one of the key success factors in world sport, and the more that both we and New Zealand can get in the form of competition, the better for both of us.

There are also some other potential advantages for Australian sport. The University of Otago is to establish a swimming flume, which is essentially something akin to a treadmill for swimmers. I fell as though I am on the treadmill here at the moment! And I know my colleagues would like me to get off it. We do not have one in Australia and we will have access to the one in New Zealand.

We will also be able to use the New Zealand alps for high altitude training. At the moment we have to use expensive locations in Europe or North America for altitude training. Arrangements which we put in place under the agreement will be done on a sport by sport basis, and I think it goes without saying, and I know Senator Evans would agree, that only sports that wish to participate in this scheme will be involved. To date some 30 sports have been consulted concerning their willingness to be involved and to participate in this program. I believe it will bring mutual benefit to both New Zealand and Australiaâ€”and some benefit to the Australian Senate if I sit down.
