debate.sub1.title: Motions to Take Note of Answers

talk.start.para: â€”On Tuesday, 11 October 1994, Senator Faulkner asked me whether it was in order for a senator to move to take note of two answers to questions. As I advised then, senators have frequently moved to take note of two or more answers, including answers by different ministers. This has been allowed on the basis that the relevant procedures empower a senator to move to take note of any answers given that day, and a senator is therefore able to move to take note of one or more answers.

para.tab: There is no substantive infringement of the rights of any senator, in that a senator who wishes to speak to any of the answers covered by a motion may do so. A senator may wish to speak for five minutes on each of two or more answers, and if those answers are the subject of only one motion, the senator is limited to five minutes on all of the answers, but any particular senator cannot be guaranteed five minutes speaking time on any particular answer in any event.

I would propose that the practice be allowed in accordance with the numerous precedents, but if any senator indicates a view that there is a problem with it, I would be happy to refer it to the Procedure Committee.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht), to a question without notice asked by Senator Jones this day, relating to the Torres Strait Islands border.

speech.para: Senator Schacht obviously wrote the question for Senator Jones, and he could not even get the question right, let alone the answer. Senator Schacht has shot off his mouth yet again and made an absolute fool of himself, an absolute and unmitigated fool of himself, and it is no wonder the South Australian Labor Party wants to get rid of him off the ticket. He is an embarrassment to the government, to this chamber, to the parliament and to the Labor Party in South Australia, and I can well agree with even that miserable lot that want to get rid of Senator Schacht.

para.tab: As Senator Schacht has crawled back in here and concededâ€”he did not have the grace to apologise for thatâ€”I did in fact write to the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) on 4 October explaining exactly my concerns. I will seek leave to incorporate this letter or a copy of it. In the last paragraph, I say to the Attorney-General:

speech.para: As well I would think that some of the concerns I raise in this letter would be matters more appropriately dealt with by other Commonwealth Government Departments but rather than me forward copies of this letter to other Ministers I would appreciate if your staff could arrange to forward a copy of the letter to any Minister with relevant responsibilities who may be able to assist in finding solutions to the problems which are raised with me by constituents.

Senator Schacht says that there are plenty of people there to look after what everybody in the territory knows is a gross, illegal trade which is continuing. There are people coming from New Guinea through the Torres Strait islands into Horn Island, flying to Cairns. As I said on TV, I can identify the person that people raised with me. They tell me it is a man in a red hat, that they do not know his name, but they see him coming down regularly. In a small town like Thursday Island, if everybody can identify him it should not require any great investigative work by the Federal Police or Customs officers to find that person and do it.

para.tab: I have written to the Attorney-General; I have written, through him, to Senator Schacht, who is too incompetent and lazy to know about it; I have written to the Queensland police minister and others drawing to their attention my genuine concerns raised with my by constituents who have very genuine concerns about this illegal traffic. It is not just the drugs and the traffic of people, but there are very dangerous diseases in plant and animals in Asia and New Guinea. They only have to get into Cairns on the leaves of some of these marijuana plants and we have a major problem on our hands.

Senator Schacht says that the Customs people are doing a great job and that there are plenty of people there. Let me tell Senator Schacht what the National Director of the Board of Management of the Australian Customs Service, Les Jones, is quoted in the
Townsville Bulletin
as saying. He said:

speech.para: The task faced by customs officers in the region was daunting.
And so it is. Again quoting Mr Jones, he said:
There are seven staff there.

People who know the Torres Strait, know the number of islands in it, know how close it is to New Guineaâ€”one of the islands of the Torres Strait, part of Australia, is only a couple of kilometres from the mainland of New Guineaâ€”would know how difficult it is to police and would know that we need more people. Senator Schacht says, `We have plenty of people up on the border.' There are seven.

para.tab: Let me tell senators how many Customs officers there are in the whole of Queensland. There are 577. There are 4,372 in the whole of Australia. But on our doorstep, where people can get in a tinny, a little aluminium boat, to come across, how many do we have? We have the great number of sevenâ€”seven out of 4,000 officersâ€”and Senator Schacht says it is all okay. It is a major problem which is why I, with all responsibility, wrote to the Attorney-General and wrote to the Queensland minister. Then Senator Schacht accuses me here of not even raising the matter. He is a dill and a buffoon. It is a wonder that Mr Keating leaves him thereâ€”

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)
â€”Order! You will withdraw that comment, which was quite unparliamentary.

talk.start.para:
â€”Mr Acting Deputy President, in deference to your ruling, I withdraw it. But Senator Schacht is incompetent. It amazes meâ€”and most of his colleaguesâ€”that Mr Keating leaves him on the front bench. He has made an absolute fool of himself, not only in this instance but in every instance possible. He is a complete embarrassment to this parliamentâ€”certainly to the government. I think the least Senator Schacht could do would be to tender an apology for the disgraceful attack he made. I seek leave to have that letter incorporated in
Hansard
.

para.tab: Leave granted.

The document read as follows
â€”

speech.para: 4th October, 1994
The Honourable. Michael Lavarch MP
Attorney General
Suite MF 21
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Attorney,

On Thursday Island recently a number of constituents, many of whom are community and civic leaders, raised with me the problem of an apparent break down of law and order in Thursday Island, which they claim is evidenced by an increasing number of major robberies and break and enters and violent assaults.
These matters are principally matters for the Queensland Government and the Queensland Police Force but they do have a Federal element.

It is indicated to me that a lot of the stolen goods turn up in New Guinea and there is a belief held by many varied people that the increase in crime is directly related to the purchase and transportation of drugs from New Guinea, through the Torres Strait Islands and into mainland Australia.
I am aware of Treaty conditions we have with Papua New Guinea which allow for movement by Papua New Guinea nationals into the Torres Strait.
I am informed however that there is a regular traffic of people and goods into mainland Australia.
Obviously I am not in a position to do more than pass on concerns raised with me by constituents and I have no information which would enable police to take action.
It is however told to me that "everybody knows what is happening and the people involved" and it would seem to me that trained investigators would have little difficulty in gathering the facts.

I am told that occasionally the Federal Police do mount undercover operations in the islands but these seem to be a bit of a joke as most of the locals know two to three weeks before these operations occur that there will be undercover police in town and apparently they are readily identifiable when they arrive.

There is the additional matter of health and quarantine concerns on any plant material brought from Papua New Guinea into Australia. You will well appreciate that one of the disasters which Australia is not equipped fully to deal with would be an outbreak of some form of plant or animal disease from Asia and the North.

I am not aware of what arrangements you have with the Queensland Government in relation to policing the frontiers of our country in the Torres Strait nor if there is any permanent Federal Police presence in the islands.

My understanding is that there is no regular and permanent Federal Police presence and I would be grateful if you could have one of your officers write to me to explain the arrangements and why there are no Federal Police in the area.
I am aware that there is a Customs presence but the locals again tell me that the numbers of customs people are grossly inadequate for the huge tasks involved.
I enclose a copy of the letter I am writing to the Queensland Minister for Police about the same issue.

As well I would think that some of the concerns I raise in this letter would be matters more appropriately dealt with by other Commonwealth Government Departments but rather than me forward the copies of this letter to other Ministers I would appreciate if your staff could arrange to forward a copy of the letter to any Minister with the relevant responsibilities who may be able to assist in finding solutions for the problems which are raised with me by constituents.
Yours sincerely,
Ian Macdonald
Senator for Queensland

talk.start.para: â€”Senator Macdonaldâ€”I should say Senator Ian Macdonald so that poor Senator Sandy Macdonald does not get tainted with the incompetence and stupidity of Senator Ian Macdonaldâ€”
â€”Order! Senator Schacht, you could have put that a little more delicately than you did.

â€”Senator Ian Macdonald said that they could identify a man with a red hat. I must say that this is the most extraordinary explanation I have heard in the Senate for a long time. Senator Macdonald does not have a red hat but a red face for trying to explain the contradiction in what he said on North Queensland Television on 29 September. He said in his interview:

speech.para: I do have descriptions of the type of people who are doing it and the descriptions of an actual person involved. And certainly I'd be making the authorities aware of those things that have been told to me.

In the letter he has just incorporated, all he says is, `I have no information which would enable police to take action.' All he has said is that it was a man with a red hat. This is extraordinary. He is running around North Queensland, bagging the Australian Customs Service and the Australian government, saying that he can identify one individual.

para.tab: He writes to the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) saying that he has no informationâ€”that is in his letterâ€”and then he says in this chamber that it was a man with a red hat. What an extraordinary comic opera he is performing. What he has been caught out on is seeking publicity in North Queensland for his own political motivesâ€”probably his Liberal Party preselection in particular. When he wrote to the Attorney-General, the letter he has incorporated, he said that he could not give any evidence. I think Senator Macdonald is the one who has been caught out and I thank him for tabling that letter to the Attorney-General.

I think it is really unusual that Senator Macdonald would write a letter of such importance and simply ask the Attorney-General to pass it on to any other relevant minister when he knew that I am the Customs minister and when, as I understand it, there is a Customs office just around the corner from his own electorate office. One would have thought that he could have at least made an effort to write to me or raise the issue with me during the past two weeks, but he did notâ€”he raised it with the Attorney-General. The reason Senator Macdonald did not want to raise it with me is obvious: he had no information. He has been caught out in a publicity stunt.

The other issue Senator Macdonald raised was the resources of the ACS in the Torres Strait. Yes, it is true that there are seven officers. Of course, he did not mention the contract officers we employ under Coastwatch who operate in the Torres Strait and who add to the resources of Customs. That area is the main area of surveillance. It has been upgraded in the recent new contract for Coastwatch that the ACS has just let to a North Queensland helicopter company. I am sure Senator Macdonald would be very pleased to hear that we are employing a local company to provide specialised surveillance of the Torres Strait. That company has been very appreciative of the fact that the Australian Customs Service, through proper procedures, was able to give that contract to a North Queensland company.

It is true, as I said in my answer, that I would never claim a 100 per cent ability to stop the illegal importation of drugs into Australia. With our coastline of over 20,000 kilometres, much of it uninhabited, it is extremely difficult to guarantee that. In conjunction with other authorities and other services, we make the best effort that we can to stop the illegal importation of drugs.

We are quite open about our successes. I have mentioned the fact that last year, compared with the previous year, there were fewer seizures, which is one way of describing it. But in recent months we have had some spectacular seizures, including some in Queensland. I think Senator Macdonald should give credit to the officers of Customs and the Australian Federal Police for their success in making those seizures and in protecting our border from illegal drugs.

talk.start.para: â€”When are you going to apologise?

â€”I will never apologise to Senator Macdonald because he has been exposed for the humbug of going on television in North Queensland and claiming that he knows the identity of a particular person when his letter to the Attorney-General says that he has no information. He tells the Senate that the best he can do is to say that it is a man in a red hat. All we have got out of this is Senator Macdonald's red face.

talk.start.para: â€”by leaveâ€”On the same matterâ€”
â€”Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of orderâ€”
â€”Just listen! There Senator Schacht goes, shooting off his mouth again.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)
â€”Senator Macdonald, if you want to address the chair, address the chair.

talk.start.para: â€”I claim to have been misrepresented. In accordance with standing order 191, I mention the matter in which I have been misquoted or misunderstood by Senator Schachtâ€”it is difficult for Senator Schacht to understand anything. Senator Schacht has quoted very selectively from my letterâ€”fortunately the letter has been incorporatedâ€”and did not read the next paragraph, which I will read to make sense of what he is accusing me of. The paragraph Senator Schacht referred to says:

speech.para: Obviously I am not in a position to do more than pass on concerns raised with me by constituents and I have no information which would enable police to take action.
But then the letter continues:
It is however told to me that "everybody knows what is happening and the people involved" and it would seem to me that trained investigators would have little difficulty in gathering the facts.

In a community of about 2,000 people, everybody knows what is happening. That is the way it was described to me. All of the people on Thursday Island know of this person. I do not know the person's name, but it would not take a trained Customs investigator more than a day to find out who it is. Anyone in town can say who the person is. talk.start.para: â€”I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins), to a question without notice asked by Senator McGauran this day, relating to water conservation.

speech.para: I think my comments might be helpful to the government because there is a bit of a problem. I want to make sure that farmers get the full benefit of the government's intent because there are a few little slippages in terms of what was said.

para.tab: The issue is the application of the investment allowance to water conservation projects. I refer to the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) of 21 September in which he said that the government will provide incentives for farmers `to better protect the agricultural resource base during drought and encourage improved land management'. In particular, the government will consider providing a generous investment allowance for farm storage and water facilities.

The difficulty is that the present income tax investment allowance remains in effect for units of property for which contracts of acquisition were entered into or for which construction commenced prior to 1 July 1994, if those units are installed and ready for use prior to 1 July 1995. It applies expressly to a range of structural improvements, on land used for the purpose of carrying on a business of primary production, for the purpose of conserving water or such improvements for the purpose of conveying water. The section involved is 82AE(b)(iv) and (v).

The purpose of my raising the matter in response to the minister's answer is that there is a problem with this provision and I think it has not been clearly understood. Section 82AM states that the investment allowance is not allowable for expenditure incurred in respect of a unit of property if a deduction is allowable under section 75B of the act. Section 75B covers all of the items listed in section 82AE(b)(iv) and (v), so it appears that either, firstly, the reference to section 75B in section 82AM is a drafting error and ought to be amended so that there is no doubtâ€”and this is the pointâ€”that those farmers who invested in dams, wells or irrigation qualify for the investment allowance; or, secondly, the policy of the government is to deny the investment allowance for expenditure on conserving and conveying water.

I do not believe this is the case, but it is certainly a matter that needs to be passed on to the Treasurer (Mr Willis) because I think the position as to these two alternatives needs to be clarified. I certainly hope that farmers will be able to get the full benefit of what I think was intended because there are certain restrictions in terms of the current wording of the Income Tax Assessment Act in relation to the investment allowance. I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans, who is at the table, to pass that information on to the Treasurer and the Prime Minister so that the farmers involved can get the full benefit, which I think was intended, arising from the problems with the drought, in terms of the availability of the investment allowance.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

â€”I present the government's response to the interim report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on the Evidence Bill 1993. I seek leave to incorporate the document in
Hansard

para.tab: Leave granted.

speech.para: Minister for Justice
The Hon. Duncan Kerr MP
Senator B Cooney
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Cooney
I refer to your Committee's Interim Report on the provisions of the Evidence Bill 1993.
The Committee's first recommendation was that
`matters noted [in the Report] be addressed by the government as soon as possible after appropriate consultation between the governments of the Commonwealth and New South Wales.'
The Government has acted on this recommendation. All the matters listed in the Committee's report have been examined by the Government in consultation with the New South Wales Government.

Government amendments will be moved to the Bill relating to some of the matters mentioned in the Report, and to some other matters. These amendments have been developed in consultation with New South Wales. The Attorney-General for New South Wales, the Hon John Hannaford MLC, has advised me that he has examined the proposed amendments.

Mr Hannaford referred to 2 specific matters in his letter: the commencement date and the test for legal professional privilege. Otherwise Mr Hannaford said that he has `no in-principle objection to these matters. However, I also note that my concurrence is subject to final Cabinet approval of the proposed amendments'.
An indicative list of the proposed amendments is attached.

In his letter, Mr Hannaford expressed a firm preference for the dominant purpose test for legal professional privilege. Mr Hannaford said `Although any divergence between the State and Commonwealth Bills would of course detract from the goal of uniformity, I am strongly of the view that a `dominant purpose' test would be more appropriate for New South Wales.'
I believe strongly that the current sole purpose test is appropriate. Accordingly, this appears to be an area where complete uniformity is not possible.
The Committee's second recommendation was that
`there be a period of at least six months between the passing of the Bill and its coming into operation to enable the legal community to familiarise itself with the Bill's provisions.'

The Government believes that there should be a substantial period between passage of the Bill and its coming into force. It had originally hoped that the Bill would be passed in time for a period of 6 months to elapse before its commencement. However, the Government does not believe that the period before commencement need be as long as 6 months, especially since the Bill has been around for so long.

Nevertheless, the Government proposes to move an amendment to the Bill to substitute `18 April 1995' for `1 January 1995' in the commencement provision. This will provide for a 6 month period if the Bill can be considered by the Parliament promptly. This date has the advantages of providing an appropriate period after passage and of being after a break (Easter) in the sitting of the courts.
In relation to the commencement date, Mr Hannaford said

`Ideally, I would prefer a joint proclamation date for both Bills. Passage of the New South Wales Bill, however, is subject to the State Cabinet and Parliamentary processes and as such may not take place by the proposed date. In such circumstances, and bearing in mind the lengthy and extensive amount of preparation involved with this Bill, a separate Commonwealth commencement date of 18 April 1995 may become appropriate.'

Mr Hannaford`s comment reflects the fact that it would not be possible to do more than table a NSW Bill before the NSW Parliament rises this year, and the NSW Parliament will no doubt not resume until some time after the NSW election on 25 May 1995.
The Committee's third recommendation was that:

`the legislation should be monitored after its enactment. This monitoring should be undertaken by a panel comprising representatives of relevant courts, legal practitioners and the Attorney-General's Department. The Committee will invite members of this monitoring panel to appear before the Committee in 1995 to report on any problems encountered following the implementation of the legislation.'
New South Wales, the Australian Capital Territory and some courts have been consulted about the Committee's recommendation and the issue of monitoring.

The Government agrees with this recommendation in principle. Subject to consultation with the courts and the legal profession about their participation, the Government hopes to have the necessary arrangements relating to the proposed committee complete before the legislation comes into force.
The Government will also be coordinating monitoring arrangements with those in New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory.
Yours sincerely
DUNCAN KERR
Evidence Bill 1993
INDICATIVE LIST OF PROPOSED AMENDMENTS
(excluding consequential drafting amendments)
Clause 2

para.tab: An amendment to substitute `18 April 1995' for `1 January 1995'.

speech.para: Clause 4

para.tab: Amendments to clarify the application of the Act in sentencing proceedings.

speech.para: Clause 8

para.tab: Drafting amendments to make it clearer that State and Territory laws applied in federal court proceedings by the Judiciary Act 1903 continue to operate except where inconsistent with the Bill.

speech.para: Clause 9

para.tab: An amendment to ensure that the Bill does not affect a power of a federal court (as well as a power of an ACT court) to dispense with the operation of a rule of evidence or procedure in an interlocutory proceeding.
An amendment to provide that the Bill does not affect the operation of a State or Territory law relating to bail.

speech.para: Clause 15

para.tab: Amendments to extend non-compellability for members of Parliament where giving evidence would interfere with attendance at a meeting of a joint Parliamentary Committee (to fill a gap in the clause) and, in the case of Parliamentary Committee meetings, to limit non-compellability to where the MP is a member of the relevant Parliamentary Committee.

speech.para: Clauses 18 and 20

para.tab: A drafting amendment to clause 18 to make it clear the discretionary family privilege in criminal proceedings only applies to a person who is a spouse, de facto spouse, parent or child of the accused at the time he or she is required to give evidence for the prosecution, and a consequential amendment to clause 20 to similar effect.

speech.para: Clause 20

para.tab: A drafting amendment to subclause 20(5) to omit the words `or on behalf of' (these words are unnecessary, and their retention might have implications for other provisions of the Bill).
An amendment to subclause 20(5) to make specific provision for comment by a judge where a comment is made by a co-accused about the failure of a parent or child of another accused to give evidence.

speech.para: Clause 21

para.tab: A drafting amendment to remove the possibility of an argument being put that a person producing a document or thing to a court in answer to a subpoena cannot be examined on oath or affirmation about the adequacy of steps taken to comply with the subpoena.

speech.para: Clause 32

para.tab: A drafting amendment to insert the words `or opinion' after `fact' in paragraph 32(2)(a) in order to ensure consistency with the rest of the clause.

speech.para: Clause 48

para.tab: An amendment to paragraph 48(1)(f) to enable a party to adduce evidence of the contents of a public document by tendering a purported copy of the document that purports to have been printed by authority of an Australian Parliament (or House or committee of such a Parliament).

speech.para: Clause 60

para.tab: An amendment to make the clause revert to its original operation in earlier Evidence Bills (that is, to provide that the hearsay rule does not apply to evidence of a representation admitted because it is relevant for a non-hearsay purpose).

speech.para: Clause 61

para.tab: An amendment to provide that the exception to the hearsay rule for contemporaneous statements by a person about his or her health, feelings, sensations, intentions, knowledge or state of mind is not subject to the requirement that the statement must have been made by a person who, when it was made, was competent to give evidence.

speech.para: Clause 65

para.tab: Drafting amendments to relocate the exceptions to the hearsay rule (for first-hand hearsay evidence in a criminal proceeding) which relate to representations in earlier proceedings outside subclause 65(2), in order to remove an inconsistency with subclause 65(5).

speech.para: Clause 67

para.tab: An amendment to require that notices given to other parties of an intention to lead `firsthand' hearsay evidence of a representation, where the person who made it is not available or is not to be called, be in accordance with any regulations or rules of court.

speech.para: Clause 68

para.tab: An amendment to change the 7 day requirement for objections under the provision to tender of `firsthand' hearsay evidence of a representation, where the person who made it is available to give evidence but is not to be called, to 21 days.

speech.para: Clause 69

para.tab: A drafting amendment to align the language of the clause more closely with that in the definition of `business' in Part 2 of the Dictionary.

speech.para: Clause 82

para.tab: An amendment to ensure that the provision fully prevents secondhand or more remote hearsay evidence being given of an admission and to ensure it does not exclude admissions made (rather than recorded) in a document.

speech.para: Clause 85

para.tab: An amendment to extend the `reliability rule' for certain admissions made by a defendant in a criminal proceeding to all admissions made in the course of official questioning by an investigating official or as a result of an act of another person who is able to influence the prosecution process.
A drafting amendment to omit subclause 85(4) (it was included as a drafting device in the Bill but it is unnecessary and has caused some confusion).

speech.para: Clause 87

para.tab: A drafting amendment to clarify the intended operation of the clause.

speech.para: Clause 114

para.tab: Drafting amendments to make the Bill closer in language to Part 1AA of the Crimes Act 1914 (to which some amendments are also proposed).

speech.para: Clause 115

para.tab: Amendments (partly to align the Bill more closely with Part 1AA of the Crimes Act 1914) toâ€”

provide that picture identification evidence adduced by the prosecutor is not admissible if the defendant was, when the pictures were examined, in custody unless (in broad terms) it was not practicable or not reasonable to have held an identification parade including the defendant; and
apply clause 114 to determine whether it was reasonable to have held such a parade.

speech.para: Clause 116

para.tab: A drafting amendment to state expressly that it is not necessary that a particular form of words be used in informing the jury of the need for caution before accepting identification evidence.

speech.para: Clause 120

speech.para: Senator J R Coulter
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Coulter
THIRD REPORT OF THE SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON THE FUNCTIONS, POWERS AND OPERATION OF THE AUSTRALIAN LOAN COUNCIL
I am writing to you to respond to the recommendations of the Third Report of the Senate Select Committee on the Functions, Powers and Operation of the Australian Loan Council.

The Committee made six recommendations which concern the nature of the Loan Council and the presentation of the financial information relevant to its operation. The key recommendations were directed towards accountability and disclosure of information. In recommendation Three it was proposed that the uniform reporting requirements established by Loan Council should include auditors' reports. Recommendation Five proposed that annual reports be presented to Parliaments including a consolidated, audited report by the Loan Council to the Commonwealth Parliament. In recommendation Six it was proposed that these arrangements should be made legally binding requirements on the Commonwealth and the State and Territory Governments by virtue of an amendment to the Financial Agreement.

As you would be aware, a significant reform of the Financial Agreement was formally concluded at the Council of Australian Governments meeting in February of this year. The signing of the new Financial Agreement was the culmination of a consultative process that took place over a number of years. The Financial Agreement Bill 1994 and the National Debt Sinking Fund Repeal Bill 1994 which will give effect to this reform were passed by the Commonwealth Parliament in June this year. The States and Territories have also been playing their part in bringing this work to fruition. Legislation has also been passed by Victoria, the ACT and the Northern Territory. In the other States complementary legislation to that passed by the Commonwealth Parliament has either received Cabinet consideration or has been introduced.

The revised Financial Agreement will give effect to Recommendation One of the Committee's recommendations which favoured the continuation of the Loan Council. The Commonwealth Government is of the view that there will continue to be a role for the Loan Council in the coordination and disclosure of financial matters for the foreseeable future.

In respect of the other key recommendations by the Senate Committee, I should say that the Commonwealth Government has no difficulty, in principle, with the idea that the Loan Council Allocation or the Statement of Financial Assets and Liabilities that the Commonwealth is to submit to the Loan Council should be open to ready scrutiny by the Auditor-General and the Parliament. The current powers of the Auditor-General provide scope for the Auditor-General to look at this area and the Loan Council Allocation has been reported to the Parliament in Budget Paper No 3 and, more recently, in the Final Budget Outcome 1993-94 document tabled in the Parliament at the start of the current sittings.

The basic thrust of the arrangements which have been developed by the Loan Council in recent years has been to emphasise the provision of comprehensive information about the public sector's need for funds to the public and to the financial markets. In the `Future Arrangements for Loan Council Monitoring and Reporting' adopted by the Loan Council on 5 July 1993 Loan Council noted that the Auditors-General of the various jurisdictions would fulfil their usual roles in relation to each jurisdiction's financial statements. That is, Auditors-General would continue, within their powers, to audit and report on the financial transactions of governments including, where relevant, those relating to a jurisdiction's Loan Council Allocation.

While the Government is open to proposals which will materially improve the public presentation of the Commonwealth's financial affairs it must be noted that the Committee's recommendations go beyond the Commonwealth's jurisdiction and deal with matters which are within the responsibilities of the State and Territory Governments. In particular, Recommendation Six envisages that the States and the Territories would be prepared to have reports on their affairs audited and tabled for review by the Commonwealth Parliament.

It is necessary to appreciate that the Loan Council is not an institution that is under the control of the Commonwealth Government but is comprised of representatives of sovereign Governments who are accountable to their individual State or Territory Parliaments. By its nature, the Loan Council is a cooperative institution in which durable agreements can only be achieved on a voluntary basis when there is perceived to be a common interest. Voluntary and informal arrangements have been a significant feature, and probably the major feature, of the Loan Council's operations throughout its existence. In these circumstances, the views of the State and Territory Governments are central to the Senate Committee's proposals. It is not possible or, indeed, appropriate for the Commonwealth Government to respond to the Committee's recommendations insofar as they relate to the affairs of the States and Territories.

I am not aware that there has been any response made to the Senate Committee's report by State or Territory Ministers although I note that the Premiers and Chief Ministers of the States and Territories signed the revised Financial Agreement together with the Commonwealth at the meeting of the Council of Australian Governments in Hobart on 25 February 1994 in the knowledge of the Committee's recommendations for further changes to the Agreement. The recommendations in the Committee's third report have been drawn to the attention of State and Territory officials. The responses received at official level indicated that there may not be a consensus amongst the States and Territories in favour of their implementation. In the circumstances, the Commonwealth proposes to keep under notice the recommendations of the Committee that involve the responsibilities of the States and Territories with a view to their being an input to the discussion when relevant issues are discussed in the context of the Loan Council.

The foregoing comments have concentrated on the major elements of the Committee's recommendations as they affect the nature and operations of the Loan Council as a cooperative Commonwealth/State body. I should also respond to other matters which the Senate Committee has raised in its report.

In Recommendation Four the Committee proposed that all authorities which could generate public sector debt that is subject to Loan Council review be advised of the reporting requirements with which they must comply. The Commonwealth Government fully endorses this recommendation which is already encompassed by the process for formulating the Commonwealth's LCA nomination in the lead up to the annual Loan Council meeting and the subsequent reporting of outcomes. Under this process Commonwealth departments, agencies and statutory authorities are notified of the information requirements under the new Loan Council arrangements. The States and Territories are responsible for advising their Departments and authorities of Loan Council reporting requirements.

In Recommendation Two the Senate Committee proposed that the State and Commonwealth Governments adopt accrual accounting as a matter of priority for the purpose of reporting all government financial transactions, including Loan Council disclosures. As a practical matter, the Loan Council could only move to an accrual system when all member jurisdictions had done so on a consistent basis. The implications of accrual accounting for Loan Council matters will need to be explored as jurisdictions become familiar with its general use for government operations and in the light of the objectives of Loan Council reporting. However, the Committee's recommendation goes considerably beyond the application of accrual accounting to Loan Council reporting and it would clearly not be appropriate, in the Government's view, for Loan Council matters to drive the broader issues which bear on the implementation of accrual accounting.

In relation to the broader issues, the Government announced several years ago that Commonwealth Departments and agencies were moving progressively to preparing their financial reports on an accruals basis. It is currently expected that all agencies will be able to report on an accruals basis for 1994-95. I understand that the States and Territories have also given considerable attention to the adoption of accrual accounting. The timing of their adoption of accrual accounting is a matter for the States and Territories to consider in the light of their own priorities.
Yours sincerely
Ralph Willis

talk.start.para: â€”The Senate is debating the Drought Relief Payment Bill 1994. This is the government's long awaited response to assist rural families in drought afflicted areas, many of whom have lived on negative or very low incomes for up to four years. The drought relief payment will provide eligible families in certified extreme drought areas with income assistance equivalent to the jobsearch allowance, partner allowance and family payment.

para.tab: This bill amends the Farm Household Support Act so that its objectives include `to provide financial assistance to farmers who are experiencing difficulty in meeting living expenses and who are in exceptional circumstances due to extreme drought'. In order to be qualified to receive the drought relief payment, a farmer must have a drought exceptional circumstances certificate issued by the state RAS authority. Importantly, farmers on farm household support may transfer to the drought relief payment, which has the advantage of not being repayable in the future. Drought relief payments are inalienable grants.

Farm related assets, farmers' life insurance and superannuation are all disregarded in calculating the value of the farmer's assets in assessing eligibility for the drought relief payment. The JSA income test will apply. A farmer does not have to put his property on the market to qualify; nor does he have to have a letter from the bank saying that he has been refused commercial financeâ€”a Stalinist tactic tried unsuccessfully with the farm household support payment.

The office of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) issued a question and answer paper following the drought package announcement from which we learn that the RAS extreme drought certification will be valid for six months at a time. Payments will be for up to six months at a timeâ€”which means they can be for less than six months and all clients will be reviewed every six months.

The legislation does not set out the length of time for which the drought relief payment is payable; nor does it provide for parliamentary scrutiny of the classification of drought declared areas. These are necessarily fluid areas as drought declarations over various regions will naturally change.

However, it does give absolute power over the eligibility of applicants to a memorandum of understanding between the RAS authority and the Secretary to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. The success or failure of the initiatives being debated in the Senate today will hinge on this memorandum of understanding.

In itself, the objectives and content generally of this legislation are admirable, if long overdue, but its effectiveness in alleviating genuine financial hardship for farming families suffering due to matters beyond their control is entirely out of the hands of the parliament and squarely in the hands of the negotiators of this memorandum of understanding.

Presumably, the minister will be issuing press releases as to changes in drought declarations, but I ask the minister, as an act of faith to the rural families he is trying so hard to help, whether he will table the memorandum of understanding reached by his department with the state RAS authorities and keep the parliament informed of alterations and changed drought circumstances.

Drought is a national issue and a national problem. The Senate cannot do its job and review the government's performance in combating drought unless this information is brought to its attention. There are many parts to the drought problem. This bill tackles the poverty aspect of many families whose stories have been so well highlighted in the media. It is true to say that the Australian people, by their generous response, have led the government to recognise the serious nature of the drought and its effect on Australian families in the bush.

It should also be said that the personal testimonies of people in the bush have been instrumental in attracting the attention and now action by the government. It was very hard for some of these families who were interviewed by the media to disclose private details about their financial situations. But because of the courage of a few, many thousands will benefit. Their actions have been very much a public service.

This legislation is expected to lead to expenditure on the drought relief payments of $43.45 million in the current year and $19.31 million in 1995-96, with an additional $4.36 million this year in family payments and $1.93 million next year. Much of the drought package and the coalition response is already on the public record. I would like to reiterate that, as far as providing a living allowance for families stung by years of low and negative incomes is concerned, this bill will be most welcome.

Rural families have not had the same access to income support as have families in the city areas with access to JSA, for example. The farm household support was essentially a loan and was therefore most unpopular. It was extremely difficult to be eligible for the JSA, so there was virtually no way for these cash-starved families to support themselves while their stock and crops failed season after season. The mushrooming of drought funds committees and the networks of charities and organisationsâ€”including the international aid organisation Care Australiaâ€”demonstrates not only the generosity of Australians but also the large hole that needed to be filled and should have been filled by government long before this.

Even so, winning cabinet support for this legislation was a singular achievement for the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, as he faced a cabinet used to imposing fees, charges and taxes on the rural sector rather than implementing incentives. The government's promise of tax incentives for farm storage and water facilities, and further initiatives in the areas of taxation and income equalisation deposits, will simply return to farmers some of what the Labor government has taken off them in the past.

In its first year of office alone, Labor cut general depreciation allowances, abolished farm fuel storage depreciation, scrapped automatic tax averaging provisions, increased various excise taxes, and abolished sales tax exemptions on some inputs. In 1985, farm water conservation was dealt a blow by replacing its write-off in the year of expenditure with a write-off over five years.

While royalty was wined and dined in 1988, assistance to isolated children was cut by 17 per cent, reducing the number of children being assisted from 19,000 to 14,500. This was followed by the termination of some equalisation arrangements and the hard-hitting assets testing so hurtful in particular to the chances of rural children getting a secondary and tertiary education. I have not even mentioned all the other taxes and fees imposed on rural industries over the last 10 years; nor the cuts to local government and road funding; nor the government's engineered years of high interest rates that have been so devastating to rural Australia.

We must keep this drought package in perspective. This is not government charity or even generosity; it is merely paying an instalment on what this country owes rural Australia. So this bill is good so far as it goes. It serves to redress some of the imbalance between the income support available to urban families and the income support available to rural families. This bill does something. Queensland has issued some 3,000 claim forms to date, according to a Social Security spokesman yesterday.

The group which has missed out on both income support and industry assistance is the non-farm small business community, many of whom have been carrying farmers through the long drought period and suffering great loss of custom because of restricted farm budgets.

The Queensland state government has instituted a small business drought assistance scheme to help locally owned small businesses affected by the drought. Businesses may be eligible for interest subsidies of up to $5,000 a year on new or existing commercial loans for up to two years. They must demonstrate that their need for assistance is related to the impact of drought, that they would be considered viable in normal conditions and have long-term prospects of profitability. To businesses on their knees, this is not much of a lifeline. It would be far more effective if backed up by federal support which matched the state effort dollar for dollar.

If we have learned anything from this drought, it is that long-term drought is a national problem affecting the health of a variety of communities, not just farming. A host of other economic performance indicators are affectedâ€”indicators such as employment, capital investment, savings, inflation and, most importantly, exports and trade. One cannot tackle a long-term drought by just focusing on income support payments for farmers. A holistic support approach is needed to prevent wholesale damage. And that means including structural assistance for agricultural and other small businesses in drought affected areas.

The government has allocated $25 million in its drought package to drought exceptional circumstances interest subsidies. These interest subsidies will often mean the difference between the success or failure of the farm enterprise. This is the assistance category which will make the difference between a rural sector being in good enough shape to capitalise on the rains when they come or in disrepair and years behind in making its rightful contribution to the national economic effort.

Since the government will not look at fodder subsidies to preserve breeding stock, RAS interest subsidies provide the only avenue to keep drought regions on their feet at a farm gate level. We must not confuse assistance to keep food on the farm table and assistance to keep the farm table on the farm. They are quite separate and go to two different parts of the drought problem.

Twenty-five million dollars for drought exceptional circumstances is not a committed response from this government. Nor did the government use the drought package as an opportunity to ease the eligibility criteria for RAS interest subsidies, as called for by the opposition, the NFF and other industry groups. Unless farmers can access RAS, it will not really matter how much is in the kitty.

It would be a repeat of the shameful failure of the wool rescue package if RAS eligibility criteria were not changed to reflect the fact that it is survival stakes out thereâ€”and those in a position to consider productivity improvements are in a luxurious position compared with farmers facing their fifth year of drought. The minister has given a commitment to review the eligibility criteria, but what every farmer wants to know is when will it happen. I personally asked the minister a question about that last week and he said that he was doing it now. I would like to know when is `now'.

I mentioned the wool rescue package because it is a salient example of how a well-meaning package can go terribly wrong if there is a hitch in delivery due to overly restrictive eligibility criteria. Aimed at 5,790 growers, the wool package was received by only 1,960. Only $15 million out of the allocated $42.2 million for wool exceptional circumstances got to the farm gate. Farmers could not meet the conditionsâ€”not because they were too well offâ€”and that meant that far too many efficient growers were left with nothing to get them through. The performance to date of RAS drought exceptional circumstances does not lead to optimism about the future.

From January 1993 to the end of March 1994 only 3,301 approvals were givenâ€”in the middle of a devastating drought. Yet we are told there are 12,000 to 15,000 farming families in dire straits due to this drought. The criteria are too restrictive. Removing some off-farm assets and raising the RAS cap does very little to get RAS to the many farmers with no off-farm assets and unable to get RAS so far. Unless the situation is addressed, the drought package will not go very far towards keeping devastated rural Australians going as a sustainable economic unit.
Finally, I remind the Senate that in his press release of 21 September concerning the drought package the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said:

speech.para: In coming weeks, I will also meet with the major banks and pastoral houses to discuss the important role they have in helping rural business and communities now and in the period of recovery.

We were told today, following a question by my colleague Senator McGauran, that that meeting has never taken place. As a senator for the worst drought-hit state, Queensland, I would very much like to know when those meetings will take place and what commitments the Prime Minister will receive from financial institutions about their important role in the rural sector's recovery.

para.tab: I look forward to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy reporting back to the Senate in the very near futureâ€”that is, provided the Prime Minister has made time in his busy schedule to keep his word and has not been too busy playing war games with his predecessor. As the Prime Minister said, it is in the interest of all Australians to take these measures.

talk.start.para: â€”I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak to the Drought Relief Payment Bill, which will introduce a drought relief payment for some of Australia's hardest-hit farm families. Let me say at the outset that the Australian Democrats certainly welcome this drought relief package announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on 21 September. I congratulate Senator Collins for getting these measures through the cabinet.

para.tab: The Democrats will be supporting this bill. We are keen to see it passed by the Senate as quickly as possible to ensure that there is no delay in making these drought relief payments available. To that end, we have exercised some restraint in the number of speakers that we will have on the bill. Perhaps the only regrettable part of the government's drought package is that it took so long for it to be brought to this place.

This drought, which for many parts of the eastern half of the continent has been the worst on record, has been going on for four long years. Action from the government to alleviate the suffering being inflicted on farm families is well and truly overdue. Unfortunately for some of our farming families, that action will have come too late.

With the drought looking as though it may stretch out until autumn next year, the pressure on Australia's family farmers is greater than it ever has been. It is inevitable that by the time the rains finally comeâ€”and we all hope that is sooner rather than laterâ€”a large number of farming families will have been forced to leave the land and forced to leave farming operations which may have been in the same family for four or five generations. These properties will be bought up at rock-bottom prices, and the expertise and character that farm families have provided to the Australian bush for so many years will be lost forever, as will their contribution to the social and economic framework of regional Australia.

In recent weeks I have had numerous phone calls from farmers who have seen a letter to the editor or an article in their local papers mentioning the Democrats and have rung up to offer their support andâ€”even more, I suspectâ€”to have a sympathetic ear at the other end of the line to talk through some of the difficulties they are currently facing. Drought is obviously the most striking of these, but high interest rates, low commodity prices and the gradual decline of country towns and services are still inflicting a heavy burden on farm families.

Some of the older families, who have lived through drought before but say that this time it has gone on so long that they need outside help, have been calling up. One man who has now retired on his farm in central Queensland said to one of my staff that some of his 10 children and 28 grandchildren are farmers. While he is very worried about them and has much to offer, he is scared to help them out in any way for fear of losing his pension. He said that when one of his children recently visited him for a few weeks and lived in their caravan in the backyard he lost his rates concessions, supposedly because there was `someone else' living on his property.

Others are younger families who have done as much as they could to prepare for the droughts that inevitably occur in this country but have found that their preparations were not enough for this latest extended drought. Ironically, it is some of these farmers who have made preparations that have found the financial preparations they have made for drought are the very factors that to date have precluded them from any government assistance. A number have complained that the only way they can get any assistance from the government is through interest rate subsidies under RAS, which means they would have to rack up more and more debt in order to get the subsidyâ€”a crazy, circular, unending trail of debt and more debt. The effects of rural debt then are just as crippling as drought for these particular families.

In the voice of another farmer who phoned one could tell there was a real mixture of anger, frustration and desperation. He said he was sick and tired of having to go out and look at his animals slowly starving to death. He said he spends hours on the phone trying to hunt down feed but, by the time he finds some, it has already been sold to somebody else. He said that what farmers are really looking for is results on the ground, not television pictures of politicians putting bandaid measures in place and proclaiming themselves the farmers' saviours.

So let us look at what the government is doing for farmers. Today we are considering the drought relief payment, and again I say that the Democrats welcome the introduction of this new payment. The drought relief payment will be available to those families whose incomes have been affected by extreme drought for 24 of the past 36 months. It will be subject to an income and off-farm assets test and will be paid at a rate equivalent to the jobsearch allowance. Partner allowance and family allowance will also be paid where these are appropriate. Importantly, these payments will be made without any activity testing.

Claims for the drought relief payment will be handled by the Department of Social Security, and farmers will need to provide a certificate from their rural adjustment scheme authority verifying that they are in exceptional drought circumstances. Recipients of the payment will also be eligible for a health care card, and their children will qualify for Austudy. I applaud all of those measures.

Farm assets, life insurance and superannuation will not be included in the assets test for the drought relief payment. I noted that a number of journalists described the exemption of farm assets as a major policy shift by the ALP, and the Prime Minister himself described it as a revolutionary change in policy. I am not so sure about that.

In some cases, farm assets are already exempted from the assets testâ€”such as under the farm household support schemeâ€”just as they are for some payments made under the assistance for isolated children's scheme. Perhaps it is not so much a revolutionary change on the part of the Labor Party, but a limited and begrudging acceptance of the fact that the assets test harshly discriminates against all farmers and has done so for many years. It seems to me that the Labor Party has assessed that the electoral cost to it of maintaining the inequity is minimal, except in this particular case.

I believe the intense media attention in this caseâ€”the media has done a service; let us compliment them, because sometimes we are very critical of themâ€”has been instrumental in bringing the real plight of farmers to all Australians. Because of the attention that has been focused on the assets test and its affect on drought-stricken farmers, the government has made this concession. Of course, the government was fully aware that, without this concession, no farm family would have qualified for the new payment.

If either the government or the opposition had listened to what we said for years when we tried to ease the assets test for farmers, some of the suffering that farm families have had to endure throughout this drought might already have been alleviated. Thousands of farmers throughout the country have had negative incomes for a number of years due to low commodity prices, high interest rates and other factors, including fire, flood and mouse plagues. Despite those negative incomes, those farmers have been unable to access the most basic social security or student assistance payment. Many of those farmers will still not gain anything from this package. I believe farmers need to be given the same assistance that all other Australians have available to them.

The government must recognise that family farms are not tradable assets. They are assets which, together with an accumulated wealth of farming knowledge, are handed down from generation to generation. This intergenerational transfer is an essential part of the Australian farming industry.

The Democrats are pleased to see farm assets exempted from the assets test on the drought relief payment. We urge the government and opposition to consider extending this principle to all other social security and student assistance payments. Overall, the Democrats welcome the introduction of the drought relief payment, just as we welcome the additional funding that is to be provided for RAS and rural counselling services. The drought package addresses the most desperate, short-term issues being faced by Australian farm families. It is not, however, a cure-all for our primary producers, and I hope it does not mean that people will lose interest in the plight of farm families.

The issue of rural debt, in particular, requires far more attention. As I have said on previous occasions, there is an urgent need for representatives from the various governments, banks, rural counsellors and farming organisations to work together to identify solutions to the debt crisis. I support Senator Boswell and Senator McGauran for their comments and questions today about the Prime Minister's promise to talk to the banks. This is an absolutely urgent task, and I trust that he will fulfil that promise.

For the farmers who have lasted this long and are still on the land, it will take many years to return to a position of profitabilityâ€”when herds can be re-stocked, run-down machinery can at last be replaced, more time and resources can be devoted to landcare issues and they can once again afford to send their children to college. Australia needs to stand by its farmers now and will need to do so for many years to come.

talk.start.para: â€”I am pleased to speak on the Drought Relief Payment Bill and to acknowledge that, at last, the government has brought matters to a head and brought this bill before the Senate to help the struggling farmers affected by the drought. I do not need to tell honourable senators how bad the situation is. This issue has been debated in the parliament quite extensively in the past four or five weeks, so there is no need to dwell on its severity.

para.tab: I know that the drought in the eastern states is the worst droughtâ€”by any stretch of our imaginationâ€”since 1982. In Western Australia, we have not had a bad drought since 1983. I have had the experience of going through a drought. I am not talking as someone who watches from a distance. In Western Australia, I went through the bad droughts of 1969, 1976 and 1977â€”two years in a rowâ€”and, of course, 1983. Even though Western Australia has had a reasonably good season, I feel for the farmers who are in that situation.

I am also pleased that the government has attempted to help farmers by way of social security measures rather than any other way. I believe that is the fairest and most basic way to help people. I believe it is a person's basic right to at least have food on the table, whether living in a country town or the city. Even a bankrupt person who might have been bankrupted by his own stupidity should have food on the table. It is the same for someone who loses a jobâ€”and jobs have been lost by stupidity. A person who loses a job through stupidity still has the basic right to have food on the table. The responsibility to provide basic needs for farmersâ€”no matter where they may liveâ€”probably falls on the rest of the people of Australia who are doing better.

I welcome the government's change in policy on Austudy. Outside a farmer's own plight on the farm, if he or she has children going through the education system who are not receiving Austudy, one of the worst things that can happenâ€”on top of the droughtâ€”is if his or her children have to break their education. I have quoted figures in this place on the drop-out rate for children receiving an educationâ€”when they take 12 months off or have a break during their course. Those figures are fairly high, although I do not know what they are at the moment.

I commend the government for taking away the assets test on farmers affected by the drought and for allowing farmers to meet the other criteria for 24 out of the previous 36 months. I believe that that is one of the most important measures, alongside having basic commodities. I also commend the government for putting in the flexibility for farmers if they have been affected by drought for 24 out of the past 36 months. If there is a drought followed by a reasonable season and then a drought, farmers can hardly say that they are out of trouble, so I welcome that flexibility.

I know it is very tough when farmers fall over one side of the line and qualify for assistance and then fall over the other side of the line. The government has to look at extreme cases like that. In the 1980s, with the devastating 1983 drought, the Western Australian government looked at its system. It used to declare droughts by shires and split shires. The bigger shires acted further on the recommendation of the local shires saying that a drought could be declared in a pocket within a shire without that area even including half the shire. I believe that system worked very well, and I think we could look at that situation in extreme, isolated cases.

It is not only lack of rain that at times creates drought. I know that Peter Walsh laughed when he was asked for drought aid because it had rained too much. It may seem stupid on the face of it, but those sorts of things, including frosts, can wipe people out. Of course, one can be insured for thunderstorms and hail, but not for a lot of the other things that I have mentioned. So I believe the government should look at people who are in extreme circumstances.

As I have already said, Western Australia has had a reasonable sort of season, but there are pockets of Western Australia that are badly affected by the present season, including the south-east of Western Australia in the Esperance area. Maybe they do not qualify as having been in extreme drought for 24 months out of the last 36, but something has to be looked at. There would not be very many people in that situationâ€”one could probably count them on one handâ€”but their position has to be looked at.

The most badly affected area in Western Australia is the pastoral areas of the East Gascoyne region, which is sheep grazing country. They may just qualify as having been in drought for 24 months out of the last 36 months. If they do not qualify strictly because of a month, I believe their situation also has to be looked at.

I also commend the government's move to pay social security rather than the farm supplement six months after a drought is declared finished. I welcome that. Because there is a big rain one day, people do not have an income the next. I remember the eastern states drought of 1982 breaking in March 1983. In fact, it broke very soon after Ron Barassi gave a pep talk at a bull sale in northern New South Wales. He said, `Have confidence and buy some of these bulls. The rains will come.' The rains did come within a few days, and Ron Barassi has claimed that fame forever and a day. The rains did come the next day, but it would have taken at least six months, and more in the case of a wheat cropâ€”if there were a drought in March, it would certainly be November or December before it was overâ€”before people's incomes started again. I commend the government for building in that flexibility.

Let us look to the future. I have said in this place before that the end of the drought will come one day. I am a super-optimist anyway. What the government has to do, whoever is in government at the time, is provide incentives for people affected in this way to provide for themselves. I am afraid that that has not been done probably for the last seven or eight years. Of course, for the last seven or eight years this government has been in power. I will not go into detail now, but we have to look at better IEDs and better incentives, without going overboard, to conserve fodder, water and cash reserves. The cash reserves come from those IEDs. That has to be looked at in the years to come.

I do not think this package does anything at all for the plight of small business, except that it gets some money flowing in the country. So at least some farmers indebted to small business can pay them something along the lines of what they owe. Though there is nothing in this package, I think something has to be done in the future for small business, which goes through these ups and downs that farmers go through in severe downturn.

Of course, the most important people are the children of those small business people. People in small business have assets, but they are blocked out by the assets test. But some of them have children long distances away at university. I can tell honourable senators from experience how much it costs to educate children from the country. They should be given Austudy to help them get through their courses so that in better times those younger people can provide for themselves. If they drop out and are not able to finish their courses, they will have to be helped by this sort of system again in the future.

I have used my allocated time, so I conclude by saying that I welcome these measures. There has been a big turnaround since the Prime Minister's first visit to Queensland when he said that anyone fool enough to live in that area should cop it. I am glad that the government has come around. Let us see what we can give these farmers to keep them in their places for another day.

speech.speaker: MacGibbon D.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I make a declaration in conformity with custom in this place that I am probably the sole member of the Senate who is a primary producer and who has been severely affected by drought for four years. The Drought Relief Payment Bill will not affect me in any way. I will not be an applicant under the provisions of the bill, nor will it confer any benefit on me or my family in any way at all. My present needs are for rain so that I can re-establish a cash flow again. As Senator Panizza said, that does not happen immediately after rain when one is an animal producer. It is probably 12, 18 or 24 months before one is re-established.

para.tab: I do not want to go over the technical points of this bill, which have been so well covered by opposition speakers, because we are very short of time. We are on a limited speaking time of about six to eight minutes each. What I want to do, though, is emphasise two points that illustrate the shortcomings of this government and the neglect it has shown of Australian rural industries. Those two points are quite simple: first, the delay in recognising that we had a drought of enormous magnitude upon a large part of Queensland and New South Wales; and, secondly, when at last the government responded and reacted to that drought, the administrative systems that it put in place were either inefficient or non-existent. It is only now, three weeks after the announcement was made, that there might be something in place to deliver the measures that were promised by the Prime Minister.

That is just par for the course for this government. There is a total neglect of, not to say contempt for, the rural industries of Australia. In the 12 years that the Labor Party has been in government we have seen a positive attack on the rural producers of this country, to remove from them the resources they need to pursue a profitable course which is of benefit not only to themselves but also the country.

There have been things like the removal of the effective income equalisation deposit scheme that was in existence under the previous Liberal government; huge increases in fuel excise, which impacts very greatly on rural producers; and the imposition of the fringe benefits tax, the significance of which on Australian rural industry has never been appreciated in this parliament. They are just three things that have made life very difficult. They have diminished the profitability of rural producers in Australia and, in so doing, have limited their ability to provide for themselves. We do not want to be given handout schemes in any way at all; we just want recognition for the particular difficulties we face and facilitation to provide for ourselves so that we are not a call on the public purse.

As I mentioned in the discussion on the matter of public importance in the last sitting week, depreciation rates are a good example. If we build a shed or put a dam in we get seven per cent depreciation allowed per year. Yet if one buys a personal computer and is a small businessman in the urban areas, there is a depreciation rate of 27 per cent. It can be written off in about three years.

Why can we not have a little bit of parity, particularly as rural industries are so important to Australia? Even in these difficult times they provide something like 25 per cent of Australia's export earnings. We cannot all live on welfare; we do need to earn money. Only last week we had the announcement that in the last quarter this country had spent a massive amount in excess of $2,000 million more than it had earned.

One of today's papers contained a small article based on some projections by Access Economics, a very reputable economics forecasting firm in Canberra. It forecast that the way things are going, unless the government takes some measures to control the drift, the balance of payments deficit will be $25 billionâ€”that is, $25,000 millionâ€”by the end of next year. We will have spent $25,000 million more that we earned. That has to be paid for by our exports. So, by any standards, there is a need to cosset and to look after our rural industries. All that we have seen is a contraction of those industries under Labor.

How can the situation be explained in any other terms than total neglect or indifference? Although we are experiencing a huge drought, the biggest drought in our history, despite all the comments in both chambers from members of the Liberal Party and the National Party, it was not until a month ago that the government recognised that we had a problem.

Then the Prime Minister went to my own state of Queensland and said, in effect, that drought was a natural part of life, and that we should stop whingeing about our lot. There was such an outrage over that that he was forced to come back a few weeks later. As a result of that we have this bill before us today, which we all welcome. I wish the legislation a speedy passage through the Senate. But it really is quite inexcusable that it took 3 1/2 years to recognise the magnitude of the drought and the fact that it is a problem of national significance.

Nothing happened after the announcement was made by the Prime Minister. There has been a total blanket on the dissemination of knowledge. The government, as a matter of priority, should have ensured, through the Public Service, that the terms and conditions relating to application for grants were spelled out clearly, that the grants available were spelled out clearly and that the Department of Social Security officers in rural areas and officers responsible for the rural adjustment scheme were fully advised.

I listened very carefully to what the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins, said in this chamber during question time earlier this week. I hope he is right, but if he is right, it has all happened this week. I can tell the Senate that up until Monday, when I came to Canberra, my office in Brisbane had received a number of calls. I was told by the rural adjustment scheme office in Brisbane that it had had more than 800 calls a day about this scheme and that staff simply could not cope. I was told that when the staff phoned around the country areas, Department of Social Security officers said they were being besieged by inquiries from farmers and applicants for assistance but that they did not have the information to provide to them. Further inquiries made by my office to head office in Canberra revealed a state of confusion.

I think it is bad government that that happens. The expectations of people who have been suffering a great deal were raised. We tend to think of droughts in purely financial terms, but the emotional consequences and the distress on families and people involved, not only in the rural industriesâ€”on the farms and properties themselvesâ€”but in the country towns, the small businesses, is really quite acute.

On that point, one of the measures undertaken in relation to the drought has been the distribution of food packages. That is a very noble act of charity by members of the community. But the actual distribution of food rather than sending money means that the shopkeepers in the country towns do not get the return on the sale of that food to people in the area, so their lot becomes that much more difficult again. Yesterday during question time, the Minister complimented members of the Department of Social Security. He said:

speech.para: Those officers have performed minor miracles in getting this money on the ground as quickly as they are.
Later on, in the same answer to the question, he said:
Something in excess of 3,000 applications, on my latest advice, have been processed just in the last 48 hours. That was the purpose of that exercise.

If they were processed, that is well and good. But the impression that I have formed, having followed this up in the most affected of the drought states, the state of Queensland, is that up till the end of last week really nothing effective had been achieved. I think that is quite inexcusable.

para.tab: Nevertheless, something is moving and I hope that relief is at hand for those people who apply for it under this bill. But we are a long way short of resolving the problem. We are always faced with droughts in Australia. When we get a drought of the magnitude of four or five years, such as the one we are facing now, is very difficult to cope in terms of water storage, fodder storage and so on. It does have a major effect. But we can look at ways of ameliorating the effects of droughts by encouraging rural producers to make provision for them, and I think this government has a long way to go in that regard.

In summary, this is really very little and very late. When I say it is very little, I note that this year $52.99 million extra is being spent and that $24.22 million will be spent next year. By way of comparison, I point out that over $150 million was spent on redundancy payments on the waterfront plus a lot of other money as wellâ€”in the aggregate it was far higher than thatâ€”and the nation got very little or no benefit from it. This is really the minimal response the government can make and it is very late.

speech.speaker: Macdonald Sen S.

talk.start.para: â€”I rise this afternoon to make my contribution to the government's drought package in response to the disastrous drought that has been going on for four years. My property is in an area that is under exceptional circumstancesâ€”in fact, it has been in drought for 27 of the last 36 months. Just to put that in perspective, our average rainfall is 28 inches a year, and this year we have had 9 inches. So it really is a disastrous drought for us.
