para.tab: I am probably the only senator who will spend, subject to my Senate duties, every weekend for the foreseeable future on the back of a feed bin, which is immensely depressing and an immensely expensive way to spend time. But that is obviously part and parcel of farming, and I guess that all farmers appreciate the difficulties that they face and can see the value of it in the end.

This response by the government is belated, but it is a case of better late than never. I think it is fair to say that the coalition can take a large amount of the credit for getting drought on to the national agenda. I commend my colleague and leader, Senator Boswell, for his role in the media in that regard and also the shadow minister, John Anderson, for his contribution to the debate with the package he brought down on behalf of the coalition two weeks ago.

Basically, that package dealt with the three prongs of immediate relief. The first area related to welfare. The government's response of the drought family payment and the removal of the assets test from Austudy certainly goes a very large way to meeting the principles enunciated under immediate relief. The second area that John Anderson talked about was the retention of the breeding herd, and that is something that remains largely unattended by this package. The third aspect that he talked about was reconstruction. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has said that later on, perhaps in November, the government will bring down a broader approach to taxation in dealing with severe drought in the future.

Two months ago, the Prime Minister was in Queensland. He said, `Droughts are natural.' Droughts are natural, but severe droughts are not. Some weeks ago, the government was moved to act because of the widespread publicity and the charity concert held by media celebrities. I noticed that Senator Collins just yesterday, in answer to a question from me, said, `Those areas that are not in exceptional circumstances can look to getting some help from the farmhand appeal.' I am very thankful that the farmhand appeal has been operating; I believe that it has brought city and country closer together. But to think of charity being the only thing available to farmers who do not qualify under exceptional circumstances is extreme naivety.

I understand that, in terms of the amount of money available, the federal government originally allocated $10 million for Farmhand on a one-to-one basis. Senator Collins said yesterday that 3,800 farm families had received $9 million. That is about half of what is available. The drought will go on for an awful lot longer than the money available under farmhand will last. The reason the Prime Minister acted was that he could see that the drought was electorally damaging. He sort of discovered the drought. The media fell upon his visit in a frenzy. The day after the package was announced, I read an article by Asa Wahlquist in the
Sydney Morning Herald
which I think really puts in perspective how the media fell onto the package and said how good it was. She said:

speech.para: A century of antagonism and suspicion was yesterday allayed when the Prime Minister championed the needs of farming families.

I think she has gone a little overboard there, especially when we consider that the previous response from the government had been so pitifulâ€”$14 million in extra RAS fundingâ€”and especially compared with the Prime Minister's instant response of $150 million for the Cahill Expressway, and the multimillions of dollars that were pushed in the way of the waterside workers to get them back to work recently and to get ANL to be a saleable proposition. But I do not wish to proceed further with that.

para.tab: I just want to make a couple of brief points about the ongoing problems. The first concerns the feed grain situation. It was reported earlier this week that there was a three-week supply of feed grain available in the eastern states. The minister said that he has ABARE working to complete a national grain audit. I am pleased that the minister has said that, despite the pessimistic forecasts, the government expects that in aggregate there will be enough grain to meet domestic food and feed requirements.

There will have to be movements of grain around Australia and the importation of feed grain and specialist grain, such as high quality durum wheat, that is required for pasta production. Even if the minister is correct and there will be enough feed grain available, there is a feed crisis, as there is a cash crisis to pay for the feed. The intensive livestock industry is particularly affected. Piggeries are closing. Poultry industries, especially those in areas situated away from the coast and unable to access imported grain because of the necessary AQIS protocols, and the feedlot and grazing industries are all affected by the unavailability of grain.

I know the minister has approved the importation 120,000 tonnes of sorghum and 10,000 tonnes of maize. That is to be applauded. We, as a nation, are not set up to import large amounts of grainâ€”we just do not have those sorts of portsâ€”so it is a whole new crisis for us to face. Just to put it in perspective, New South Wales normally has a winter cereal crop of about 5 1/2 million tonnesâ€”and half a million tonnes are expected this season. In Queensland, the normal crop is about 3 1/2 million tonnes. Again, there may be half a million tonnes produced. New South Wales normally produces about 500,000 tonnes of sorghum, half of it on the Liverpool Plains, an area from which I come. The shortfall for feed grain in New South Wales will be three million tonnes; and if the sorghum crop fails, it will be five million tonnes.

The price of feed grain has nearly doubled in the last two months. Wheat has gone from $160 a tonne to $230 a tonne and maize has gone from around $180 a tonne to $300 a tonne. Hay and baled sorghum stubble are virtually unprocurable. The inflationary and trade impacts of this crisis are very hard to quantify. Food prices are already going up. The prices of wheat, cereals, fruit and vegetables are already going up. The CPI will certainly be affected by this drought. The price of chicken, pork and eggs is going up. It will damage the worst balance of payments figure but one, that being in January 1990. The August balance of payments current account deficit was $2.1 billion, which will require higher government borrowingsâ€”and can only flow on to higher inflation,.

ABARE suggests that rural exports will decline by nearly six per cent in 1994-95. That will amount to around a $3 billion loss for farmers. The blow-out in the current account will certainly have an effect on interest rates. It must be remembered that, for every one per cent rise in interest rates, debt repayments for farmers will increase by about $150 million a year. It is worth saying that, if the government will not cut its spending, everybody in the country must cut their spending, because the fact of interest rates going up means that farmers, mortgagors and everyone else who owes money will have more money to pay back.

The minister has indicated that he is having a feed audit. I suggest to him that he consider a feed summit because they are part and parcel of the same thing. New South Wales farmers are calling for a summit; the coalition is calling in addition for a fodder subsidy. That would certainly be part and parcel of a discussion on the feed audit. I ask the government to look again at the possibility of a fodder subsidy. The minister indicated that in 1982-83 it was rorted. He has given no evidence of former convictions. He also said it caused a blow-out in the price of grain. I can tell senators that the price of grain has gone up very substantially this time, without any sort of a feed subsidy.

I would like to make a point about the inclusion last week of the six areas initially said to be in exceptional circumstances in New South Wales. Over the last 36 months, these areas have been in drought for a considerable time: Dubbo, 16 months; Grafton, 17 months; Merriwa, 23 months; Mudgee, 19 months; Nyngan 19 months; and Scone, 17 months. Mr Harry Woods, who heads the rural task force for the government, naively suggested that the farmers in these areas who did not at this stage qualify under exceptional circumstances should rely on charity from farmhand. Whilst I applaud farmhand and all that it has done, it is a very sad day for Australia when our farmers are reduced to receiving handouts from the Salvos or the Smith Family. I do however applaud the city for identifying with this country problem.

We must plan for the future. Farmers must have the ability to plan. There must be recognition that severe drought is a natural disaster. There must be a recognition of the hurt that small businesses are feeling in this drought and a return to the natural disaster relief arrangements for severe drought so they can access help as well. I applaud the New South Wales government on it decision yesterday to contribute $20 million particularly to assist them, and also the Queensland government, which has done the same thing.

There must be a recognition of the incredible debt burden that farmers are facing. It is not just a problem for farmers; it is a problem for the banks and the government. As was pointed out today in question time, the Prime Minister has not yet met the banks, as he promised when he announced his package.

Like Senator Panizza, I am an optimist. People on the land have to be. So I would like to finish on a slightly optimistic note and say that it looks as though when this drought breaks, as it surely will, prices for grain, wool and beef will be strong for a couple of years. But high prices are good for farmers only if they have something to sell. Prices can go up 300 per cent, but that will not benefit farm families in the broad because they have been so weakened by this drought. At the end of the day, I have to agree with an editorial in
The Land
of 1 September, which states:

speech.para: Unless this country wakes up to itself, the end of this droughtâ€”when it comesâ€”will trigger the biggest exodus from the land Australia has seen. And it won't be because of the drought.

The drought will be merely the catalyst. The real reason will be the sense of futility that farmers are increasingly evincing as they battle against overwhelming odds to survive in a country that prefers to keep them poor.

speech.speaker: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

talker.name: Senator BROWNHILL
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

talk.start.para: â€”I am conscious that the Senate wishes to expedite the passage of this Drought Relief Payment Bill 1994 so that the little bit of benefit to be gained from it will get out to the people who need it very badly. Therefore, I will not go through the many concerns that I have about our reaction to the drought, not the least of which is the absence of any plan to protect the nucleus of Australian stock and the absence of any scheme to provide affordable feed for farmers to feed the stock they have.

para.tab: We also need to keep in mind the parlous economic state of the agricultural sector prior to the drought which was the direct result of anti-rural government policies. I think most of them can be attributed to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) when he was Treasurer or since he has been the Prime Minister. Those policies include increased primary industry charges, fuel excise increases, wholesale sales tax increases, investment allowance removals and the removal just recently of the exceptional circumstances provisions for wool growers.

The government reneged on its election promise to remove the assets test for farm families to receive Austudy. It imposed and extended the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax and basically imposed de facto death duties on rural communities. The government also gutted the IED scheme, removed the wool floor price scheme and gave us high interest rates that especially hurt the farmers. The result of that was that farm borrowings moved from about $5 billion up to $17-odd billion, and today's farm indebtedness is now $17.3 billion. I think it went from $5 billion to $16 billion in the five years prior to 1993.

Aside from all that, about 8.5 per cent of farmers have left their properties in the past 10 years. The Prime Minister, even though of late he has taken a little interest in the farming communities, kicked them in the teeth prior to that. Along with all the things I have mentioned, the farming community had adverse terms of trade throughout the 1980s.

I applaud the New South Wales government for the additional $20 million drought package that it came out with in the last 24 hours. As a patron of the RSPCA, I particularly wish to applaud the $1 million being directed to the RSPCA to assist it in humane stock slaughter schemes and other assistance measures. I trust that this aid will not be tied in the bureaucratic knots in which the federal aid seems to be.

In light of the arguments surrounding the exclusion of the six rural land protection board districts in New South Wales from eligibility for exceptional drought, I would like to place on record direct comments made by Bruce O'Meagher, the Assistant Secretary of RAS within the DPIE, at a satellite conference held on 29 September with Department of Social Security officers around Australia. I seek leave to incorporate in
Hansard
the transcript of that conference. When Minister Ray was at the table, I got permission to do so.
Leave granted.

The transcript read as follows
â€”

speech.para: Text from video satellite link-up held in conjunction with DSS and DPIE at regional centres throughout NSW on 29/9/94
Speaking: Bruce O'Meagher: AS. DPIE
"In NSW there are 21 droughted areas. These were established after consultations between ourselves and the NSW Government and they are on the screen now.
(21 RLPB districts appeared on the screen, including the 6 now regarded as not qualifying).

Q: (From Upper Hunter Counselling Service): "Is the Minister aware that the Scone & Merriwa Shires have been drought declared for 22 out of the last 48 months and that the neighbouring shire of Tamworth has been included as an Exceptional Drought area but Scone and Merriwa have not?"

A: (O'Meagher): "That is not correct. Scone and Merriwa and Tamworth are all in the areas that were initially assessed as being in greatest need. What happened, in terms of the establishment of the areas where assistance would initially be made available, was that two governments assessed those areas where the drought had been going longest and where the need was greatest and those are the areas that have been determined."
Two more quotes from O'Meagher: they infer that the areas initially determined to be in exceptional circumstances drought, were not assessed under the 24/36 rule.

"When we determined that an area is in exceptional circumstances we take a bundle of factors into account. There is the time it has been in drought, there are historical rainfall patterns and the cumulative rainfall deficiencies right now, there is the soil and pasture conditions and there is also the current and historical income patterns of the area. We take all those kinds of factors into account before determining that an area falls into exceptional circumstances and determining the initial set of protection board districts that would be covered those factors were taken into account by the 2 Governments, decisions were made as to which assistance would initially apply, and then there's a general trip wire, if you like, for additions to that area, and that's the 24 out of 36 rule."
"The situation in relation to determination of drought affected areas is, leaving aside the areas that have already been determined, is the 24 out of 36 months."

talk.start.para: â€”This transcript shows quite clearly that as at 29 September Mr O'Meagher was in no doubt that the districts of Scone, Merriwa, Grafton, Dubbo, Nyngan and Mudgee were indeed eligible for assistance, and he advised the DSS officers and the counsellors from those areas accordingly. If a cruel hoax has been played on the farmers in those districts, the blame must lie with the federal department which gave such advice on a state wide link. In relation to the parlous state of these areas which have now been taken off the list, I would like to quote part of a letter I have from Andrew Badgery, a rural counsellor in the Upper Hunter Rural Counselling Service. It states:

speech.para: The drought in the Upper Hunter is so severe that it is threatening the viability of even the best farmers in the region. My best clientâ€”
I ask honourable senators to remember that this letter is from a counselling serviceâ€”

is going to lose $70,000 in the next 12 months and have no cattle for sale in 1995. Farmers have given up their life styles, their health and their children's education to minimise debt and maintain the herd
at all costs
. There is little money to put food on the table and still they are not eligible for any government assistance, they will have to begin selling their herds. They feel that the government has forgotten them and some have indicated that once they lose their life's work (their herd) then suicide is their only remaining option! To slightly relax the guidelines for the drought package would give them some hope so they can at least feed their family!
NB: I AM NOT TALKING ABOUT THE VIABILITY OF FARMERS, I AM TALKING ABOUT IMMEDIATE SURVIVAL.

That is how tough and crook things are out in the bush at the moment. Drought is not a time for politics. It is a time for all levels of government and all sides of politics to work together through a national tragedy. The drought has affected efficient and inefficient farmers alike and, because of the immense contribution the rural sector makes to Australia's export income, it is in the national interest to provide assistance to all who need it.

para.tab: I am consciousâ€”I have discussed this with the minister and othersâ€”of the enormous financial consideration that governments face in dealing with the problem. It is true that no amount of money will alleviate the pain and the suffering, but we must do all we can and

speech.para: we must have more flexibility. Arbitrary lines drawn by bureaucrats at the tax office are not the appropriate response to this human tragedy. I urge the minister to take the decision making processes back to the coalfaceâ€”to the rural lands protection boards, the shire councils. They know who needs help now and which areas can hang on a little longer. We should allow them to advise the federal agencies directly, then we will really know what is happening out there. It should not be done by somebody sitting Canberra.

para.tab: The bureaucrats in Canberra do not have the relevant knowledge, and they should not be trying to make the assessments from a map. Exceptional circumstances cannot be determined by just a map. Any assessments must take into consideration the differences within shires as a result of floods, fires, rain shadows or any other circumstances that only those on the ground who know the region can determine. A person from the south of the state and who had suffered a big bushfire a year or so ago rang me the other day. Although he received some aid and some help for that, the problem is that, even with the little rain he has had, it takes years for the country to come back again after a bushfire has gone through it. So I hope something can be done about that.

I hope that, with the realisation that grain imports will be required, the federal government has in place strategies to facilitate that grain being distributed at affordable prices. The government must also give serious consideration to waiving such things as the excise on fuels used to transport stock, fodder and water. Nobody has really done much about that yet. People who want to donate things have asked me how they can get them to the affected people. Again, more flexibility would be a great help.

I remind the Senate of the economic circumstances caused by failed Labor government policies. I note also the tremendous contribution that farmhand has made but express disappointment that under its trust deeds no money can be directed to assist animals. So, again, the animals miss out. Without their stock, farmers have nothing. It is regrettable that, out of all the assistance measures being devised, only the New South Wales government, which has allocated $1 million, has directed assistance towards stock.

I welcome the drought package but urge and plead for more flexibility in its administration and for greater understanding by the bureaucrats of the implications for Australia of this truly national disaster. I await with anticipation the package for the future which will be brought down in the next month or so. I quote from `Economic Insight' from the National Farmers Federation:

speech.para: New South Wales and Queensland departments of agriculture have estimated that since the drought began the cost to their economies has been in the order of $5 billion.

There has been a $5 billion cost to the economies of those states since the drought began, and here is the government giving a social welfare package to the rural communities totalling under $200 million. We have to put it in context and think what the losses will be in the next few years if something more is not done, and done quickly.

para.tab: The rural sector must be given planning so that it can prepare for the next drought far better than economic policies allowed farmers to prepare for this drought. That is the key to any drought package: we have to be able to plan ahead and be given the incentive to put fodder away. That is the real key. We have not had the appropriate packages of incentives to date. Let us hope that the government does not let this drought pass without ensuring that farmers know what must be done before the next drought.

talk.start.para: â€”I am aware that the government and the coalition wish to get the Drought Relief Payment Bill 1994 through this afternoon. Time is rapidly running out so I will curtail the remarks I wanted to make on the drought relief package. My colleague Senator Brownhill and all those who spoke before him have very adequately examined the package and made the opposition's views on it known. They made some very constructive suggestions on it.

para.tab: I live in a rural area. I understand what it is like to live in the country, to have one's community reliant upon agriculture and to see that the whole community revolves around the proceeds of agriculture. There are not many politicians who do live in country areas. I know that Senator Brownhill does, the honourable member for Parkes, Mr Cobb, does and people like Senator MacGibbon have interests in rural areas. But there are not many of us who actually live in a rural area and understand what is happening.

Fortunately, the area in which I live is not stricken by drought. It is a sugar area. It is almost a relief to see the greenery in those areas. But I am conscious of the enormous difficulties being experienced in many of the rural areas of Queensland, New South Wales and also Western Australia. Regrettably and tragically, this drought is extending into other parts of Australia as well.

I welcome the package from the government. Again, it is too little, too late. It seemed to take the government a hell of a long time to work out that there was a drought and then it took the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, a longer time to work out the severity of the drought. It may be recalled that he initially said, `It's just a drought. It's the sort of thing that normally happens. They've got to look after themselves. They've got to put up with it. They've got to expect it.' That was Mr Keating's initial attitude. It was only after he eventually got out of the ivory tower in Canberra and looked at what was really happening that the enormity of the tragedy affected him.

It is still a bit unfortunate to see the government's priorities. Mr Keating has announced a drought package of $150 million. I should not have to point out, but I do, that Mr Keating says that as if he is giving his money. Of course, it is taxpayers' moneyâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”Giving them their own back.

â€”Exactly, it is taxpayers' money going into it. He has offered $150 million of taxpayers' money for drought relief. It shows the priorities of this government that at the same time that he is doing that for all of those drought stricken farmers in absolutely tragic situations, he is offering the New South Wales government the same amountâ€”$150 millionâ€”to pull down a perfectly good, working highway, the Cahill Expressway, because he does not like the look of it and he thinks that tourists coming to the Sydney Olympics will not like the look of it. It works; it is there; and he has offered $150 million, the same amount that he is offering for drought, to the New South Wales government to pull it down, to get rid of it. That shows the tragic way in which this government organises its priorities.

para.tab: Madam Acting Deputy President, I suppose you know the joke that is going around the bush. It is, regrettably, a wry sort of joke. It goes like this: what is the difference between the drought and the Cahill Expressway? The answer is: Mr Keating cannot see the drought from Kirribilli House. It is all too tragically true. This package that is before us is welcome. It is good to see that something is being done.

We will await what the government proposes to do to try to drought-proof Australiaâ€”the long-term rebuilding and infrastructure. I hope that Mr Keating will again follow the lead set by the opposition, as he has done in this drought package, by looking at some major infrastructure projects for the future that might lessen the effect of drought in the future. Madam Acting Deputy President, you will recall that the Leader of the Opposition, Alexander Downer, in his major directional statement
The Things That Matter
did indicate that the coalition would be setting aside a portion of the proceeds of the privatisation of government assets to reinvest in major infrastructure projects. The sorts of things we will be looking at in major infrastructure projects are roads and railways. Many of these will be in rural areas, in regional Australia, and will help to alleviate some of the huge unemployment difficulties that are there.

Other things that we will be looking at in that context will be things such as water storage and dams. I hope someone on the other side can tell me that I am wrong, but I cannot remember a dam that has been built under the term of this government. I remember the Burdekin Dam in my area, started by Malcolm Fraser. We remember the Fairbairn Dam, the Ord Riverâ€”a series of other dams back in those days when it seemed to be a proper thing to have infrastructure and dams. It seems to be politically incorrect now to have dams and infrastructure in inland Australia. I do not know why this government does not give some thought to getting involved in major dam work again. Since the Liberal government went out of power we really have not seen the construction of any dams. That is one of the things that the coalition will be looking at in the linking Australia infrastructure plan that Alexander Downer has announced in
The Things That Matter
.

We also indicated that we will be reintroducing the black spots program. That was one of the very few good things that the Labor government did. It promised it in 1990â€”again, following a commitment we had made. It was dragged kicking and screaming into implementing a black spots program, but to give credit where it is due, it did it. But it only lasted for three years and then it cut it out. It was one of the better programs it has implemented and it cut it out.

We have committed ourselves in
The Things That Matter
document to reintroduce the black spots program. I hope that by mentioning that we will reintroduce the black spots program, by mentioning that we will reinvest part of the proceeds of privatisation in national infrastructure, we will embarrass the Labor Party into doing something similar even before we get into government after the next election, because those sorts of things are needed in Australia.

I want to say how glad I am that something has been done for farmers, but I want to raise the plight of small businessmen in drought affected areas. I have been mentioning this for a couple of months now, but the government just does not seem to have heard. I am very pleased that the shadow cabinet is looking at it. I pay tribute to the shadow minister for small business, Mrs Judy Moylan, who has been very active in raising this matter in coalition areas. She has made a very good point that I support, and have supported for a number of months now. I know that my colleagues, Senator Ferguson and Senator Panizza, are very keen on that and are very aware of the real difficulties being experienced by small business.

Farmers have had real difficulties, and fortunately they are getting some assistance now, but small business has been completely ignored by this government. I have raised this matter a number of times in press releases and otherwise, and I have given examples of where small business people in drought affected communities have been forced out of business. The executive director of the Queensland Retail Traders and Shopkeepers Association, Mr Ian Baldock, has supported the things that I have been saying. He has given an example of what has happened in the Toowoomba area. That is an area that has been badly affected by drought, and five businesses have been forced to close due to the drought conditions.

As Mr Baldock says, many of his shopkeeper members have debts on their books of up to $150,000, principally from farmers. In many instances these small businessmen have actually been acting as banks for farmers. They have been supporting them. They have not been demanding payment. They know that the farmers have no money.

talk.start.para: â€”And they have not been charging interest, either!

â€”The businessmen have had to borrow money from their banks. They have had to pay the wholesalers and the suppliers, but they have given this free credit to the farmers at no interest, as my colleague has just said. That is the way people are in the bush. Small businessmen do that, but they cannot keep doing it. They cannot keep paying their own bills, borrowing from their own banks and leaving those sorts of debts on their books. In the Toowoomba area alone the result has been the loss of five businesses that we can identify. The same is happening all around regional Australia.

para.tab: The real tragedy is that once those businesses close, very seldom do they reopen. It simply means that another small community, another town, in Australia becomes a ghost town and fades into history because this government has been too stingy and too uncaring to think about these matters until this time.

talk.start.para: â€”Is $164 million stingy?

â€”It is okay for Senator West to prattle on. It is too little, too late. If those opposite had done something in the past we would not have got to this stage. It is only recently that people from country New South Wales have been able to convince the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, of the tragedy of the drought. He has been too interested in buying $2.2 million mansions overlooking Sydney Harbour, and getting rid of the Cahill Expressway. He was not interested. Does Senator West remember when he said, `Oh look, droughts are things that farmers have just got to put up with. They happen all the time.' It was only when the Prime Minister was forced out into the country areas that he knewâ€”
â€”Truth and you areâ€”

â€”Senator Schacht need not talk about truth; I am still waiting for his apology. Senator Schacht made an absolute fool of himself at question time today on national TV. What a fool! He said, `Senator Macdonald has not done anything.' The letter was there. It has been with the government for some time. There was poor old Senator Schacht shooting off his mouth again. He has the hide to suggest that I am not telling the truth about Mr Keating and his recent conversion to the tragedy of drought.

para.tab: I make a plea to the government to consider the plight of small business. Senator Schacht is the minister for small business, is he not?

talk.start.para: â€”He talks as if he has had a lot of experience in small business.

â€”He has had a lot of experience. As has been said, he turned the Labor Party in South Australia from a big business into a small business. I think he is the minister, but I really do not know; he is such an ineffective minister. Let me look at my list. Yes, he is the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. Have we heard Senator Schacht saying anything about the plight of small businesses in drought-affected areas? Can anyone point me to anything that he has said about that? Senator Schacht has great experience in small business.

para.tab: What did he do in life? He was a teacher! Then he worked for the Labor Party. He has great experience in small business. He must have a real feel for it. He must know how it is for these people who work in their own businesses 18 hours a day, seven days a week. He would not understand that, would he? He has always been one of those who got his pay cheque at the end of the week, whether he worked or not. He has never worked in here, so he really gets his pay cheque under false pretences. He has never understood what it is like to run his own business. He does not know what it is like to be in a situation where, if the customers are drought stricken and cannot pay, the businessman does not get fed himself. Senator Schacht does not understand those things. That is the trouble with the Labor government.

Of all those in the ministry we have only about six out of 30 who have ever had any experience in business. The rest of them, who are now trying to run this country, come to the ministry as public servants, as union officials or as Labor party apparatchiks. Those people have never had to worry about where the next dollar is coming from. It is no wonder that they cannot understand the plight of farmers and small businessmen in our country. Although I expect absolutely no compassion from the so-called small business minister, I ask those in the government who have some responsibility and who treat this matter more seriously than the very junior small business minister to seriously consider the plight of small business in drought-affected areas and see whether they can get together a package to assist those people.

Madam Acting Deputy President, I apologise that I have gone for longer than I intended, but that was because I was provoked by the other side. I want to conclude there to allow others to speak on this bill so that we can get it passed and get the relief out to the drought affected areas before the parliament rises this week.

talk.start.para: â€”I am delighted and proud to be associated with the Drought Relief Payment Bill 1994 because what this package does is recognise very clearly and very carefully that there are droughts and there are droughts. There are droughts which it is impossible for the average, normal, good farmer to anticipate and prepare for. This package is going to provide a safety net for those people who have experienced four years of drought in some areas. Farmers on the Darling Downs have lost eight crops and have had no income for four years. It costs between $50,000 and $60,000 just to put in a crop. Those farmers may as well have stood there and burnt eight cheques for $50,000 or $60,000. Half a million dollars has been lost by farmers in trying to get a crop, but the rain has not come at the right time.

para.tab: This package is designed to help those people to live through the rest of the time that this drought is with us. It is designed not to stop on the day when the rains come; there is a period of six months before it will be reviewed. This is a very good part of the bill because it recognises very clearly that, when the rain comes, the cashflow does not start. Those who have wool will have to wait until the normal shearing time, which could be six to 12 months away. Those who have crops have to wait until the crop has been sown and harvested. It will give farmers a buffer of extra time after the drought has finished and allow them to continue with an income and not be faced with the situation where they are totally bereft of income.

This package is estimated to cost $164 million over two years. Anyone who says that that is not a significant amount of money does not live in the real world. Senator Ian Macdonald was speaking today about the plight of small business. This package will help the small businessman as well because it will guarantee the farmers an income with which they can buy commodities from the shops in the towns. It will provide at least some of those shops and businesses in the community with income as that money is spent on food and essentials that the farmers have to buy. Those opposite keep forgetting that point. They seem to forget that the farmers will actually spend that money and that the recipients of that money will be those small businesses which are very dependent upon those farmers buying goods and commodities in their towns. So it will have an effect.

Those opposite also say that we should spend more money now, but it is those same opposition members who talk about fiscal responsibility and cutting the deficit. What programs would they cut? Obviously they do not want to cut any of the social security programsâ€”or do they?â€”any one except this one. I am not quite sure how they plan to do that.

As I said, this package provides a systematic approach to drought relief based on the principles of the national drought policyâ€”a policy that recognises that drought is a recurring feature of rural Australia which needs to be factored into the normal farm business management, but which acknowledges that government assistance is necessary for people in exceptional circumstances where droughts go on longer than the norm or what they can reasonably be expected to provide for.

The package also includes a commitment to match dollar for dollar the farmhand appeal. Yesterday during question time we heard the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) say that a $5.6 million cheque from the federal government had been handed over to the farmhand appeal. He also outlined how he envisages the layer below those who have been droughted for 24 of the last 36 months could be assisted by farmhand as well, so that those who are heading towards that severe area of drought would also be given extra assistance.

We know that additional measures yet to be announced are being considered in relation to areas of taxation, income equalisation, landcare and climate research and these sorts of things. These are the things that will benefit the farmers after the drought is over, and this is being worked on. This package has been put together with the close cooperation and consultation of the farmer organisations, and that is very important to remember.

There have been snide, mucky comments made by some honourable senators opposite about the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) discovering the situation only of late and not caring. Obviously that is a load of rubbish. He has had his ministers looking at this issue. I know that Senator Collins was trying to get the New South Wales minister responsible to provide information about the situation in New South Wales as far back as August or so. That New South Wales minister just dillydallied around and did not come up with very much assistance for our federal minister; but we will leave that aside.

As I said, this is a very important package. It ill-behoves people to stand here and say, `You should do this, you should do that and you should do something else.' Those opposite need to look at what their recently outlined policy would do. It was formed without any cooperation or consultation with the industries. I believe there are two versions of the policy enunciated by Minister Anderson in both of which, New South Wales, which I represent, would have been significantly worse off. In the first formulation, that of two consecutive years of drought, only one New South Wales rural lands protection board would have qualified. Under the second proposal, that of three years of drought in five, six districts would have qualified. That is the proposal of those opposite who are saying that we are not doing enough.

There are something like 15 lands protection boards included in our proposal, but ours is not enough; theirs obviously must be better. In my state, depending on which criteria we want to look at, either one board or six boards would be eligible; but our proposal is not good enough. Their proposal would provide less assistance than ours; but that is not the way they choose to look at it. They just want to continue with their opposition mentality of saying, `Oh, dear. This is not very good. Mine's better than yours. You can't do that. This is what is wrong with it.' This is the sort of thing that we have to put up with all the time from this opposition. It is opposition for the sake of opposition, and that does nothing for the farmers or for this country. Our approach has been to say that those people who have been affected by drought for 24 out of 36 drought declared months will attract support from this package.

One of the difficulties which both sides acknowledge contributes to the difficulty of establishing an equitable policy response to the phenomena of severe drought is the lack of agreed definition of what constitutes drought. I was talking to some people today from the Barwon area who are here for the Federal Inland Development Organisation meeting. They were talking about how their area is currently not drought declared, yet it is on the New South Wales border. Below them in New South Wales is drought declared, above them is not. None of the members of the inquiry into drought by the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs is here.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)
â€”I am.

talk.start.para: â€”I am sorry, Mr Acting Deputy President; you were there. You will recall that that was one of the problems we had. In 1991 we saw graphic maps with this wonderful doughnut, and here was the doughnut again around the Barwon area on the border of New South Wales and Queensland. Queensland, under its criteria, was not in drought, yet there was a straight line from Barwon to the New South Wales border. Senator Ferguson's state does not declare droughts. This adds to the problem. There is now a conservative government in South Australia; he had better fix it up, had he not.

â€”But even prior to that, Senator Ferguson's party, which has been the predominant government in that state, had never done anything about defining drought. These are the sorts of things we have to contend with when we are looking at this legislation, and it ill-behoves people to be critical.

para.tab: The list that has now been approved of those who qualify as being in exceptional circumstances is not set in concrete. As time passes, if there is no rainâ€”and please, God, let it rain today or tomorrowâ€”and more areas become affected and qualify for the 24 months out of 36 category, they will have to be considered and placed on the list. It is very important for people to realise this. The other thing that people need to realise is the amount of money people are getting, which is related to the jobsearch allowance.

All in all, this is an excellent package. This is a package that, once the drought is over, can stay on the statute book because this is the legislation that can be the guide long into the future for farmers, states, federal governmentsâ€”everyone. They will be able to say, `This is how it should work.' This package gives farmers an idea of the length of time that they have to be self-sufficientâ€”and it is a reasonable length of time. I have not had any farming organisation tell me that it is not. It also lets them know that, at the end of that time, they will not be cast out or forgotten and will be given assistance. That is very important. That is what this bill is about. As the Prime Minister said after the election, we will extend our hand to help up those who are unemployed. This package is us extending our hand to help those who are suffering severe drought.

talk.start.para: â€”I am conscious of the time and the fact that we want to make sure that the Drought Relief Payment Bill is concluded today. I have to say that I welcome the package the government has put forward for the measure of relief it will give to some farmers in New South Wales and Queensland. But I do not want to forget the many farming families and primary producers in my state of South Australia suffering tremendous difficulty, both through drought and for a variety of other reasons, who will not get any benefit at all from this bill.

para.tab: We heard Senator West say why that will not be the case. We also know that they will receive some benefit from the farmhand appeal. We have heard the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) and Senator West talk about the $5.6 million that this government is contributing on a dollar for dollar basis matching the money raised in the farmhand appeal. When we really think of $5.6 million, we realise that it is about half of what we would pay for a good house in Sydney these days. That money has to cover all of the people in dire need and in dire straits throughout the rural areas of Australia who will not receive benefits from this drought assistance package.

It is fair to put some things into perspective when talking about just what this package will do. Many people have been slow to realise the extent of the drought. Other very sensitive people, some city dwellersâ€”I spoke about this earlier to Senator Cooney, and I am sure he is one of themâ€”understand the difficulties that many rural people are going through at this particular time.

Senator West also said that one cannot prepare oneself for the type of drought we have at present. If the right incentives were provided through a properly constructed IED scheme where people could put away money for bad times such as this, they could work. Of all the various industries throughout the country, the one industry that likes least to look for any sort of handout is the tradition of the farming industry. For over a century now the farming industry has worked the land and, in many cases, has been able to put up with many hardships that people living in metropolitan areas would not put up with, although I am pleased to say that some of those hardships have been alleviated through modern technology. Farmers are prepared to live on very low incomes. They are prepared to go through very hard times and not look for a handout because there has never been a handout mentality throughout rural communities.

While this bill addresses the immediate problems of some farmers, we need to remember that in most rural areas throughout Australia it is not just farmers who are suffering. Senator West referred to how this scheme will help inject money into the small businesses throughout Australia. If one took the time to travel through those areas, one would realise that it would take more than drought relief payments to get many of the small businesses in rural communities back on to a profitable basis again.

talk.start.para: â€”Where will the money come from?

â€”Senator West talks about moneyâ€”this scheme provides $160-odd million over a period of two years. She may remember that 12 1/2 years ago a coalition government set aside something like $356 million at a time of droughtâ€”in 1982 dollars. So I would not brag about the amount brought forward in this package being an enormous amount of money to help farmers in 1994 dollars. But I do welcome the package because it will provide relief for some of those who are most in need, particularly in New South Wales and in Queensland.

para.tab: Only two weeks ago I spent some time in the worst drought affected parts of South Australia; that is, the west coast and the Eyre Peninsula. My colleague the honourable member for Grey, Barry Wakelin, is a farmer in this area and he understands the problems. He has done a tremendous job in trying to do what he can for the people in the electorate of Grey. Having been through drought himself, he understands the problems. The honourable member for Grey certainly has done everything in his power to make sure that people in the Eyre Peninsula of South Australia receive any possible help.

During that trip I was able to see in some of the smaller rural centres the extent of the run-down of the communities. It is not just businesses that get run down; it is total community structures. Once the community structure is destroyed through poor economic times and hardship, it never recovers. I have yet to see a small town survive which has lost its businesses, its doctor, its hospital or any major business like a machinery firm. The other day I went through the town of Wudinna where there were beautiful, almost new empty buildings which will never be used for the purposes for which they were built. In one case a machinery firm built a large building. The community is now trying to use all of these buildings for something elseâ€”in this case the development of a telecentreâ€”to try to introduce some new skills for the people in the area so they will not be totally reliant on primary production in the future for their incomes.

Throughout all of these areas, unless something is done to stop the trend, I cannot see any of these small communities ever recovering. That will not help Australia as a nation, particularly as we still rely quite heavily on primary production for our export income. It will be more difficult for people in those areas to continue to function in the way that they have in the past. It is rather sad.

I spoke to a rural counsellor in this town who has some 80 clients on his booksâ€”and this is an area that will not receive money from this Drought Relief Payment Bill. He is almost sure that after Christmas this year 33 of those clients will disappearâ€”they can no longer be saved. He said, `I have another 30-odd ready to take their place.' That gives some indication of the extent of hardship on the Eyre Peninsula, an area that will receive no funds at all from this drought relief package.

It is sad that it has taken so long for a bill like this to come before the parliament because we have known for two or three years at least that farmers and primary producers, particularly in Queensland and New South Wales, have been in dire straits. Yet it seems that the only way anything happens is when the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) makes a visit and sees the conditions first hand. Until the Prime Minister made the visit, nothing happened.

I could take the Prime Minister to a lot of other places that are suffering just as badly as some of the places that he has been to in northern New South Wales. Some of these places have been suffering for a variety of reasons. One area that has suffered tremendous hardship got a small amount of rain and then only three days later had a severe frost which wiped out any existing cropsâ€”unusual weather circumstances, and not the sort of weather that they normally expect. So there are lots of other things besides severe drought that can impact on people's incomes in rural areas. It is fair to say that the government has been very slow to recognise the needs of farmers in particular who have suffered over a long period of time now. By the time this package reaches those people who are suffering, they will be nearly at the end of their tether.

As well as help for farmers, some consideration needs to be given to providing the right incentives so that when the drought breaks and farmers become more viable there is some mechanism to encourage farmers and primary producers. Maybe such a mechanism should not necessarily be restricted to farmers and primary producers. Business people could do the same thingâ€”prepare for such terrible times as they are having now by putting aside some money via a revamped IED scheme or something along those lines. They would rather have a mechanism where they could provide for their own future than come cap in hand to governments when things get really tough.

talk.start.para: â€”It is a pity they didn't do it in the wool industry when the prices were high.

â€”Hindsight is a wonderful thing. The IED program that was in place before was not attractive enough for people to use it. We have to make it attractive so that people will be prepared to somehow set aside money in the good times to carry themselves through times like this, so that governments do not have to come to the rescue as they are doing at this stage, and those people that are involved can at least try to keep going in the industry that they have known all their lives.

para.tab: I welcome the government's assistance to those people who will receive it. In some cases it is rather too limited but at least, for the people who will be getting help from this drought relief package, it may be just the thing to get them over these really tough times so that when the drought breaks and times get better they will still be there to earn and provide the export income for Australia that we so drastically need.

talk.start.para: â€”The many good points about this Drought Relief Payment Bill 1994 have been touched upon already. Certainly the bill will be passed and become an act and will carry with it everybody's best wishes for those to whom the money will go.

para.tab: I would like to add an extra dimension to what has already been said. I have been to the countryâ€”as you would well know, Mr Acting Deputy President, because I have been there with youâ€”and in my youth, which seems a long time ago, I lived in the country. However, it would be fair to say that I have become very much a city person. My family is a city family and their means of earning an income are located in the city.

This bill raises issues of concern to the entire country. Senator Ferguson quite graphically pointed out how drought has affected country towns, how people and businesses have been driven out of those towns and have not recovered. I go into the country enough to know that that is true. We talk about the taxpayer's dollar and how it is expended. But another way of describing it is as the community's dollar. It is the community's money, not the government's money.

Deep down, Australia is a community. That is shown in times of crisis, such as the bushfires earlier this year and during this present drought. From my own state of Victoria, a lot of feed has been sent north, and it has been done gladly. While there is not much joy to be had out of this drought, there is some to be found in this sense of community.

As a city dwellerâ€”no doubt I am speaking on behalf of all city dwellersâ€”my sympathy goes out to the people who have been suffering from drought. But more than sympathy, dollars from the community's treasure chest are going out too. If the sorts of people that Senator Ferguson and others have spoken about get to the point where they are in need of help, it is incumbent on us all as a nation, as members of a common community, to help those people.

It is wrong to call that sort of assistance a handout; it is not. It is an essential contribution by Australians as a whole to a particular section of the community. It is absolutely essential that we keep people on the land. That is a matter realised not only in this country but also in places such as Japan and Europe. In fact, I do not think that the contribution the people on the land make to this country is as appreciated here as it is in other places.

Not too many city people have spoken in this debate because there was an agreement to truncate it, but I am sure that plenty of other senators would have spoken if there had been time. As a city person, I just wanted to emphasise that this is a matter of concern not only for country people to worry about but also for all Australians.

speech.speaker: O'Chee Sen W.G.

talk.start.para: â€”Senator Cooney, my friend from the other side, is quite right in saying that most of those who have spoken in this debate on the Drought Relief Payment Bill 1994 have been from outside the cities. As someone who lives outside a city, I would like to say how grateful I was to hear Senator Cooney's words today. He is a very fine person and I have a lot of respect for him. I was glad to hear that the people in the city understand what this drought is about.

para.tab: Mr Acting Deputy President, no hyperbole can be applied to this drought; there can be no exaggeration of how bad conditions are. This is a drought beyond hyperbole. Senator Cooney is correct in saying that the measures which are needed in the bush are not handouts. I am of the view that they are very much what this nation must do to protect a valuable investmentâ€”the strength of rural and regional Australia as our primary industry and the people living outside capital cities.

I am of the view that the $164 million provided for in this bill will probably not be sufficient, but it would be churlish of me to berate the government. I merely seek the opportunity to lay on the table some very real concerns about what must be done for the period of the drought and the period following the drought.

Lest anybody be under any misapprehension about how bad things are, I would like to convey something of what I have seen. I spent the greater part of last week travelling by road around some of the worst affected areas in central and northern Queensland. There were places I visited where I could not tell the road from the paddock because there was not a blade of grass. The paddocks were like crushed gravelâ€”sad, tragic places where tough, resilient people eke out whatever they could to survive while they wait for the drought to break.

One of the concerns echoed many times was that, while there was something in this package for farmers, there was nothing in the package that was seen to be of help to the working man on the property. That is a grave concern. The number of properties that used to have three or four people working on them and now have none is huge. And we must remember that, on the whole, every one of those working men represents a family which is now without income. While I know that those people are eligible for jobsearch allowance, they have a particular difficulty because, in most cases, working men on properties receive not just an income but accommodation and often a bit of tucker as well. So their families not only lose an income, they also lose accommodation and they may lose some tucker.

If the drought continues, the government must consider making available the money that it would otherwise have to pay in jobsearch allowance to farmers so that they can keep working men on the property. This will prevent families having to move out of on-farm accommodation and into the cities, which in most cases will mean their having to move to coastal areas. That is certainly something we need to avoid and the government must consider this aspect if this drought continues.

I am also concerned about the effect of debt. The climatic conditions are terrible. The resilience of the cattlemen, the woolgrowers, the grain growers and all those people out there making a living from primary industry is incredible. But debt could still sink our primary industry sector unless something is done to tackle the problem. That is why I believe that it is absolutely critical and a matter of utmost urgency that the government, the banks, small business organisations and the farming representative bodies get together for a debt summit to give some consideration to debt restructuring. This is not just for farmers but also for the small business sector because incomes are drying up there as well.

With me last week when I was travelling around quite a lot was Mrs Deanne Kelly, the National Party candidate for Dawson. One stock and station agent to whom we spoke said, `We don't have an income because no-one is selling any stock. Our small sales of wire and chemicals are not being paid for because we are having to carry people. But at the same time we have outgoings every single week.' For the small business sector in rural Australia, this drought is as much a problem as it is for the farming sector.

Unless we can come up with some creative ways of dealing with debt, it will be not only farmers who lose out. The small business sector will also lose out because, as farmers go off and leave bad debts, the small business sector will suffer. Then the banks will lose out by having to make large write-downs. As a consequence of that, the public purse will lose out.

I think it is critical that the government gives some incentive so that banks which want to make a partial write-down of debt can do so. Banks should be able to look at their loan portfolio and form the view that 20 per cent of their loans would be more viable if they wrote them downâ€”10, 15, 20 per cent or whateverâ€”and got the farmers or the small business people in a situation where they were viable and could continue after the drought.

We may well find that when interest rate subsidies go, the level of drought induced indebtedness is such that those businesses just will not survive, even with the best will in the world. That is why I believe a debt summit is absolutely critical; it is the way forward in this community and in this country. I am not saying that banks have an obligation to write off loans willy-nilly, but there is a lot that can be done if banks, government, small business organisations and farm bodies get together and look at the problem. I believe that unless the government calls a debt summit then a crucial part of the equation is missing and this nation as a whole will suffer.

I am also concerned that something is done to ensure that precipitous action is not taken against farmers whilst they are in the drought. I draw the government's attention to part 11A of the Bankruptcy Act, which provides a mechanism by which the relevant minister can effectively create a stay of execution of proceedings against farmers who are in particularly bad circumstances. I think it would be appropriate if the government gave some consideration to invoking the provisions of part 11A of the Bankruptcy Act to at least provide protection for people who are on exceptional circumstances rural adjustment. That would enable them to not worry about those extra debtsâ€”the ones not covered by any interest subsidy they receiveâ€”until such time as they start to come out of drought.

It is terribly sad that people only need one, two or three creditors with $1,500 of outstanding debts for which they have a judgment and those people can be made bankrupt. All the good work that the government puts in can go to naught if a farmer is made bankrupt and forced off the land, and then the government is up for a re-establishment grant as well. So I believe it is absolutely critical that the government gives consideration to that mechanism.

With a list of people who are drought affected and in exceptional circumstances, it makes it very easy for the relevant minister to comply with all the requirements under part 11A of the Bankruptcy Act and to give these people not a release from their debt but just a breathing space to get them up on their feet again. I am sure that these are the sorts of people who would bend over backwards, do anything and work any hours to ensure that they can repay the debts they owe. The people we are talking about who are out there struggling and scraping are the people who could have walked away a long time ago. They are there not just because they want to survive but because they have a very real intention of paying every cent they owe and doing whatever they can to look after their farms and their communities and make sure that nobody suffers as a result of the suffering which they have to endure.

My final point is in relation to provisional tax. My concern is that when farmers come out of drought and get their first income, they will be hit not only with tax but also with provisional tax. At high marginal rates of taxation they could be looking at provisional and income tax bills that could effectively be as high as 80 cents in the dollar, which would wipe out any ability those people had to repay their debts or even pay the interest due as interest subsidies were withdrawn.

Therefore, when the drought ends the government has an obligation to look at provisional tax with a view to releasing people from provisional tax in that first year after drought. These are all real issues that the government can address, that are not going to cost the government an enormous amount of money and that would be of immense value. I believe they ought to be adopted.

I end on a hopeful note. Everybody knows that the drought will one day end; it is just a matter of waiting for the rain. As Banjo Paterson once wrote in
With the Cattle
, when the drought ends, it's a beautiful thing. He said:

speech.para: The days are done of heat and drought upon the stricken plain
The wind has shifted right about and brought the welcome rain
The river runs with sullen roar, all flecked with yellow foam
And we must take the road once more to fetch the cattle home.

There will come a time to fetch the cattle home. There will come a time to bring in the crop. I thank the government for what it has given us. I believe we will need more. I hope the government will be willing to give that. I hope the government will be willing to consider the matters I have raised to make sure that this countryâ€”not just our farmers but the country as a wholeâ€”recovers from drought and goes from strength to strength.

talk.start.para: â€”I am not surprised that the government's drought package amounted to $160 million, which is significant and substantial. There was criticism of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) when he made comments about drought being part of the landscape, comments which were taken out of all context. This package shows he is concerned, as is the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) and as was Mr Crean before him, all of whom have made visits to drought-affected areas.

para.tab: The background is that we are a caring society. We do look after people in many walks of life. People in the farming community are entitled to that sort of care, help and support. I guess people look at drought and say that drought is drought, but it is not. Drought can mean arid conditions, a lack of water. But severe drought is another matter. It is a condition which creates circumstances where suicides occur, where people lose properties that have been in the family for some generations.

I always recall your remark, Mr Acting Deputy President, when we were on the rural and regional affairs committee. You said that as a member of the committee and as a farmer you were shocked to see in Queensland the Salvation Army putting food on farmers' tablesâ€”that you never thought you would ever see that day. Well, it did happen and it certainly brings home even more starkly the problems facing the country people.

There have been drought inquiries which have made certain suggestions as to how drought can be managed but again I emphasise that a drought of this nature cannot be managed; it is not possible. It is a time when the whole communityâ€”as it has done, and it should be commended for so doingâ€”should come to the support and aid of the farming community.

The situation has been made even worse by depressed market prices. It was good to see members of the National Farmers Federation and others in the rural communities commend what the government has done. They, like others, would have liked $260 million, but there is a limit to how much money can be allocated to various areas to help industries and people.

Senator O'Chee made a point about the working men. I would not like anybody to read that and think that the only reason the numbers of workers on farms and grazing properties has been reduced drastically is drought. There has been a reduction in the number of people working on farms over some time because of better management techniques, better technology and larger machines.

But what Senator O'Chee said about the working men needing some assistance is valid. As with city people, they are entitled to and do get paid the jobsearch allowance. When they were seeking help from the government previously the assets test substantially got in the way of their getting assistance. In many cases where they did get assistance, it was to get off the farm. If that did not occur in a certain time, they had to pay the money back. This package does away with that, and I am very happy about that.

Before I move away from the comments Senator O'Chee made, I would like to say that I very much agree with his proposition that provisional tax should not be levied on farmers within the first year of coming out of drought. The package is there to help the farmers. I hear people say that the rural industry will become defunct and it will be a catastrophe. That is not true; it will always be there. But it would give an opportunity for large companies and absentee landlords to buy land that is currently, and has been for many years, held by family farmers. I do not think anybody wants that to happen. That is one of the important parts of the package where these people will be assisted. I think that is really great.

Might I say, as chairman of the inquiry of the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs into the rural adjustment scheme, that drought came very much into the evidence that was given.
Time and again people talked about the unfairness of the assets test and that they should have access to social service payments because their circumstances were just as difficult as those of people in the city and, in some cases, even more difficult. I think it is a great thing that we have done away with the idea of the assets test. It did prevent people from getting that payment.

Another matter that was raised, and correctly so, was that if the sons of farmers, for instance, or farmers themselves were to get a jobsearch allowance, they had to be prepared to go away and work at a time when their presence was required to look after the property and to see that the stock and the property were not damaged any more than they had to be. The fact that they can now get a payment and stay on the farm is very important. It is not something that just came to the minister or the Prime Minister; it is as a result of the pressure that has been put on over time by people from all walks of life in this situation. I think it is a fair set of circumstances.

I would like to wind up by saying that I do not think some of the banks or the lending institutions can hold their heads very high because of the way in which they behaved on many occasions by encouraging people to go into debt over their heads and then not helping when the circumstances became grave as a result of people overextending themselves. But we cannot label the whole banking group as being bad because of the practice of some. I would just say that I disapprove of those who engaged in bad practices and appeal to them to change their attitude. They should be patient with people who, after all, have the potential to come good and to repay their debts. I hope that those who have been doing the right thing, and those who have even had a moratorium on the payment of interest ratesâ€”I think it might have been partly for a commercial reason, but I do not look any gift-horse in the mouthâ€”continue doing that. I believe the package is a very good one, and I certainly commend it to the Senate.

speech.speaker: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

talker.name: Senator COLLINS
talker.role: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

talk.start.para: â€”I thank all honourable senators for their contributions to this debate on these important measures. I appreciate the fact that most senators who participated in the debate this afternoonâ€”and I tried to listen to as much of it as I could in between doing other thingsâ€”seemed to keep political point scoring out of the debate with, I must say, some notable exceptions. But I will not dwell on that.

para.tab: The package is, of course, a package which is not yet complete; I want to stress that. We are interested in now proceeding with the next step in this package, which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) announced at the press conference when this package was announced. This package, as it stands, is costed at $164 million but, importantly, the Prime Minister gave a commitment that the government will consider what are essentially post-drought measures that are very important in providing, as he termed it, generous investment allowances for drought proofing properties.

The reason I want to stress that, even more than the package in front of us at the moment, is that there is no question that we have to get much better nationally at managing primary production in Australia than we are now. Most members of the farming community are well aware of and fully agree with that sentiment. As I have said on other occasions, prior to 1992â€”when all primary industry ministers in Australia, irrespective of their political persuasion, adopted for the first time in this country's history a national drought policy, extraordinary as that may seemâ€”and as the drought task force and the Senate committee that examined this issue clearly found, we had gone through a never-ending cycle of good seasons, bad seasons, crisis and government assistance. Then when the crisis is over, everybody goes back to doing what they were doing beforeâ€”until the next crisis.

I was very heartened by the fact that this got a lot of discussion at the special meeting of ministersâ€”the ARMCANZ meetingâ€”called recently to discuss the drought. There was not one dissenting voice in the room; and as you, Mr Acting Deputy President Calvert, know, and as we are painfully aware, five of those six governments are conservative, not Labor. Not a single dissenting voice in the room supported any move to go back to where we were before, to where we looked after drought as part of the national disaster arrangements. I put it squarely on the table because I wanted to hear what the other administrations in this country thought about it. Not a single person supported that proposition. Every single minister supported the notion of all governments working together to help farmers plan and manage better for drought in the future until, hopefully, we can get to that halcyon day that Peter Walsh paintedâ€”which certainly will not occur in my lifetime, but is a good goalâ€”when all national disasters, such as drought, fire, flood, low commodity prices, frost, mouse plagues, and everything else, get capitalised into the value of the asset in this wonderful, pure economic model that Peter painted and we do not have to give farmers any assistance at all.

We all agreed that that would be a very desirable end for everyone, including the farmers, but it is not going to occur for a very long time. However, in the meantimeâ€”while we are moving to that ultimate goal in a perfect world, which we do not live inâ€”we all acknowledge that state and federal governments do have to devote their efforts to providing much more focused resources for primary producers to help plan for and manage these events.

The farming a sunburnt country package, which was a combined effort of the Bureau of Meteorology and my department and which was released just a short time ago, contained, in some views, dramatic information. But it is a fact that across Australia primary producers make an income in three years out of 10. Of course, there are vast regional differences in that. That is a national measure across the whole primary industry sector, but it is a valid measure in considering the importance of management in this new and sophisticated age that primary producers must live in.

I mention this because I have just come to the chamber from a meeting with the people in the departments of agriculture who developed the Rainman computer package, which we are launching in parliament next week. That package is the most highly sophisticated database of information available to primary producers on historical rainfall patterns in this country that I have ever seen. It is an extraordinarily useful package.

One of the reasons I mention it is that the people who are working on this are also planning the next phase of Rainman, which also plots in the areas where this sophisticated data is availableâ€”and there are many areas where departments of agriculture have kept this dataâ€”in combination with the rainfall patterns, the levels of pasture growth and grain production, and profit and loss as well. It was interesting to see a graph of a typical Queensland cattle station in a good area and to look at the plot over the last 20 years of the pasture growth patternsâ€”positive and negativeâ€”on a typical cattle station. The thing that hits us when we look at a graph like that is that we say to ourselves, `My God, what a sophisticated and difficult exercise it is these days managing a herd on a cattle property, dealing with those peaks and troughs and deciding how many head of cattle to run on a particular paddock or on an entire property.'

We have to acknowledge that we need to put more resources, state and federal, into helping farmers plan for the degree of sophistication that is required now. I think that an extremely useful additional step will be the delivery of the investment allowances for drought proofing properties that the Prime Minister has committed the government to providing. I want to make the point that this is not the end of the packageâ€”this is simply the instalment to this point.

The fact is that up to this point the federal government alone has committed in excess of $250 million on this drought, with more to come. I regret to say that there is a lot of misinformation in the community about the drought. That is inevitable but it is a little disconcerting and discouraging when we see it emanating from the highest quarters and receiving the publicity that it does.

I note, for example, the debate that has been going on in the New South Wales parliament while we have been sitting here about the things that I am being called upon to do by members of parliament in states that are drought affected. There is a mass of this stuff but I will just give one example that has been reported by AAP. The item states:

speech.para: The New South Wales Deputy Premier and National Party Leader, Ian Armstrong, said he wanted the Commonwealth to give rural people some encouragement by reintroducing the Income Equalisation Deposit Scheme so farmers could put away some money to tide them over until the good times return.
