It will come as a hell of a surprise to the 6,000 depositors and people who own the $135 million currently in that scheme that it does not exist and that we have to reintroduce it. But that is the understanding of the New South Wales Deputy Premier and National Party Leader of what we provide.

para.tab: That information was delivered to me today and is an example of the things I am being asked to do. Now, I am not having a go at Mr Armstrong, but if the Deputy Premier and National Party Leader is saying this in parliament, I should not be too surprised about getting it from farmers when I talk to them. They say, `Why don't you reintroduce the IED scheme?' I have said to people, `Why do we have to reintroduce it? It not only exists but the last time I checked it had $135 million in it and six and a half thousand deposits.'

talk.start.para: â€”Because it is deficient, that's why.
â€”Then he should say that.
â€”He doesn't recognise all the classes.
â€”Comrade, then that is what he should say.
â€”Everybody knows what the problem is. We are asking you to address it.
â€”I am not addressing myself. I think that Senator Watson has come late into the chamber. Why does he not listen to what he is responding to?
â€”That doesn't affect the issue. There are deficiencies.
â€”Can those opposite restrain their colleague. I was about to conclude but now I am not going to. I just want to clear Senator Watson's mind on the subject.
â€”I don't mind, but there are deficiencies.

â€”Not only have we acknowledged that they need to be looked at, we are doing it, and we have given public commitments to doing it. The problem is, Senator Watson, that I am being contacted by farmers who are asking me to establish the schemeâ€”establish it, not improve it. So I am not surprised when the National Party Leader in New South Wales in parliament today called upon me to do the same. I simply want to say that as much asâ€”

para.tab:
Senator Watson interjecting
â€”

talk.start.para: â€”Do not try to defend the indefensible. I am simply saying that all politicians should cut down on the point scoring and try to improve the level of knowledge in the bush about what is available to farmers. We are about to spend $600,000 trying to fix this up again by telling people what is available. People are labouring under the misapprehension that these schemes are not available to them when they are.

para.tab: Senator Watson should have listened before he staggered into the chamber and contributed to this debate. For his benefit, I repeat that the IED scheme exists, it has got six and a half thousand deposits in it and a total of $135 million, and we are examining ways of improving it.
I will conclude by making one other point. The other thing that truly does not exist in this country is a scientifically valid definition of a severe drought.

talk.start.para: â€”Try 60 per cent below average rainfall.

â€”I know you are rich, John, but a scientist you ain't. I simply repeat the fact that what does not exist currently is a nationally accepted scientific definition of extreme drought, which of course is vitally important for government policy making.
â€”That is what we said back in 1992.

â€”Indeed; all I am saying is that all state and federal government offices are at this moment working very hard to address that. My personal view is that I do not think we will be able to achieve a single, nationally accepted definition because with a country the size of Australia and the regional differencesâ€”

para.tab:
Senator Panizza interjecting
â€”

talk.start.para: â€”I will just ignore all interjections, complying with Senator O'Chee's wish that I sit down. What is achievable, however, is a far greater degree of national uniformity than we have at the moment. The problemâ€”and it is a real problemâ€”is that there are criteria that determine drought declarations in Queensland, there is a different set of criteria in Victoria, and a completely different set of arrangements again in New South Wales. Then, of course, there are states, such as South Australia, that have no drought declarations at all. That is obviously totally unacceptable. If we cannot continue to pursue a national definition, we can at least achieve a far better measure of consistency with the way in which drought is declared in respect of government programs, state and federal. I thank those honourable senators who have contributed to this debate.

â€”Given the uncharitable remarks made by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins, I rise to correct some false impressions that he may have given. We all support any measures whatsoever that the government may wish to take at this late hour to improve the awareness of people of what exists and what is available to them at the moment. That is not in dispute but I would like to draw attention to the fact that there are problems with this so-called IED scheme which Senator Collins is praising.

para.tab: There are problems with ownership structures and availability. There are problems with the levels of benefits, and many of those problems have been created by the government, which changed the previous status of IEDs. I hope that the matter can rest there.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

(2)

"provisional tax uplift factor"

"provisional tax uplift factor"

This amendment is to omit the proposed definition and substitute `provisional tax uplift factor'. It sets it at 5 per cent. It takes out the existing definition of `for subsequent years unless parliament otherwise decides'. We have had this argument already.

para.tab: Amendment negatived.

speech.speaker: Kernot Sen C.

talker.name: Senator KERNOT
talker.role: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

speech.para:
Clause 66, page 52, proposed definition of
"provisional tax uplift factor"
, paragraph (b), line 4, omit "10%", substitute "5%".

The purpose of this amendment is to give members of the opposition the opportunity to match their rhetoric with their actions. They said in the wider debate, `Not this year but next year'. They said, `We put the government on notice that we will do it next year.' That is exactly what this amendment does; it puts the government on notice that the opposition wants to do it next year. Let us see how this goes.

talk.start.para: â€”We will not be agreeing to the amendment. I think we need to clarify the commitment that we gave. During the hearing of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration in relation to the uplift factor, we were concerned about a number of factors, including the fact that the issue had not been modelled. It appeared that the government was trying to extract the maximum amount of money.

para.tab: However, given that it is now five months since the budget announcement was brought down, and given that all the schedules have been printed, it would be irresponsible to change budgets. We change budgets when there is retrospectivity involved, blatant political promise, inconsistency or technical defects. But there are problems with an upper house picking and choosing items. However, we put the government on notice that, unless it is able to establish a better rationale for determining the uplift factor, we reserve the right to make amendments next year. I think it necessary to clarify that. For that reason, this amendment put forward by the Australian Democrats is not in line with that commitment.

talker.name: Senator SHERRY
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

talk.start.para: â€”The arguments have already been canvassed. We will not be supporting this amendment.

talker.name: Senator KERNOT
talker.role: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

talk.start.para: â€”Senator Watson has said that he is putting the government on notice that, if it does not do what he asks, he reserves the right to make amendments next year. What is that? That is an absolute cop-out. It is like saying that the opposition will not oppose the privacy bill.
â€”You know where I stand on that.

â€”I do know where Senator Watson stands, and unfortunately I have chosen the wrong person. I will speak about the Liberal Party generally. It says, `We will not oppose the privacy bill.' Why does Senator Watson not do the same thing for this matter? Here is an opportunity for him. I know how he feels about small business and the effect of provisional tax on cash flow. In my view, it is a bit much to keep using these avoidance tactics.

â€”I am a little unhappy about the way the Australian Democrats misrepresent this whole situation. In terms of cash flow, the figures are not a complete loss to small business because anybody, including small business, subject to the provisional tax arrangements, has the opportunity to put in a variation. The majority of people subject to this would put in a variation. I think the issue has been misrepresented, particularly the position that we have taken. A number of organisations have subsequently tended to distance themselves from the stand that the Democrats have taken in terms of the manner in which they have attempted to embrace their supporting of their ideas in relation to this particular budget.

para.tab: Amendment negatived.

The purpose of this series of amendments is to deal with a matter that we have raised in the past. On that occasion, Senator Watson said that there was a great deal of merit in this particular proposal. So I hope that he will see fit to support this amendment the second time round, as he has now had time to think about the merits of it. Indeed, there are very many merits. After clause 85, we are inserting a new division which states:
"85A. The object of this Division is to provide a rebate of tax for gifts of real property to natural heritage conservation organisations.

That is the essence of this amendment; all the other parts of it are really conditional and necessary to bring this into effect. So the first statement under `Object of Division' in relation to 85A is what we are really seeking to achieve.

para.tab:
Further to what I have just said about Senator Watson supporting this proposal the last time we raised it, Mr McLachlan in the other place has also spoken eloquently and very frequently about the desirability of private citizens becoming involved in the conservation effort. Mr McLachlan, whom Senator Watson and Senator Reid would know has achieved considerable environmental improvements to his own property, has spoken frequently about the fact that it is impossible for governments to achieve everything in the area of acquisition of land for conservation purposes, environmental protection and protection of threatened species and that it is not only necessary but highly desirable that private citizens become involved in these activities.
We agree that private people and private organisations can do a lot in caring for the environment and should not be disadvantaged in any way for carrying out those activities. That is the point of our amendment.

Already we have a situation in which donations of money to recognised conservation bodies are tax deductible. Those moneys are used for environmental protection purposes. This amendment simply seeks to extend that desirable facility to gifts of land. We see that as being a perfectly reasonable and sensible extension of the same principle. I think the government would be the first to agree that it is not in a position to acquire all the land that should be acquired for the purposes of environmental protection. It also would be aware that in a number of instances tax deductions are available for environmentally damaging purposes. So extending the range of tax deductibility for environmentally protective purposes would help somewhat to redress that imbalance.

Why should any distinction be drawn between donations of money for environmental purposes being tax deductible and donations of land being similarly tax deductible? A person who owns land and who would like to see that land used for environmental protection could go through the process of giving that land to a recognised conservation body, being paid for it and then donating the money back to that conservation body. That donation of money would then be tax deductible. But what a ridiculous situation we are expecting that person to go through, because that person may then be exposed to capital gains tax if the land had improved in value and would be subject to conveyancing fees, and the full benefit of the donation made for the purposes of conservation would not be realised.

For those reasons we strongly urge the committee to support this amendment and to include donations of land as a tax deduction. I point out that all the other parts of the amendment are consequential to that first one. All honourable senators need to do is understand and agree with the broad principle of this amendment to agree with it in its totality. I ask honourable senators to support that principle.

talk.start.para: â€”In terms of the success of this amendment, if the coalition were to agree to it, it is true that we might be able to get it through the Senate. But the likelihood of convincing members of the Labor Party in the House of Representatives to support it is a major difficulty. I acknowledge that there is some merit in this measure. I will certainly take it to Mr McLachlan and, in government, we will certainly give this sort of measure very active consideration. We are about practical politics at the moment. I think it was somewhat remiss that Senator Coulter did not put it to Mr McLachlan at an earlier opportunity for appropriate evaluation. I rest my case there, and I thank the committee.

â€”We thank Senator Coulter for moving this amendment. We have put forward the need for this particular measure and such incentives for conservation for some time. It is important to send farmers the right messages economically and to make certain that the tax system reflects the other policies of government. In this case it is land care and the protection of remnant vegetation that are of concern.

para.tab: In the bad old days, the idea of farming and land use was that cleared land was productive while land with trees and bush was seen as useless. Measures were put in place to ensure that farming and pastoral land was cleared. Some of those were direct requirements or penalties under land laws; some of them were incentives and disincentives. The tax regime reflected those priorities and to some extent still does.

We now know that those older views of land and nature were wrong. Farmers know this, and that is why they have been a major force for land care, pushing the government. The result of unrestricted clearing is not greater productivity; clearing results in land degradation, salinity and soil loss, and loss of habitat for birds and other creatures that work to biologically control pests. It also has a very detrimental effect on the ecology and species generally, including effects on weather. It results in wider forms of degradation.

The Great Barrier Reef, like other reefs in the vicinity of intensive agriculture, is showing signs of severe stress and is dying in some areas. This is due to two factors: siltation and increased nutrients, factors which change the ecological balance that favours reef polyps over algae. The silt and nutrients come from run-off of soil and fertilisers. One method of natural control is through the use of fringing vegetationâ€”plants that stop much of the run-off. Clearing simply exacerbates the situation.

The tax laws favour clearing and disadvantage saving bush. The deductions for the value of timber felled on land in the first year after acquisition, for land where the purchase price is attributable in part to the existence of merchantable standing timber, is basically an incentive to clear. In line with this, we also support a change to section 15 of the Loan (Income Equalisation Deposits) Act 1976, which deals with farm management bonds to allow deposits to be specifically allocated for landcare purposes. Likewise, we support a measure to ensure that all tax concessions, grants and loans to farmers and farm enterprises be contingent upon the development by January 1997 of approved whole farm plans, which include targets for environmental protection and restoration and are in accord with regional biodiversity strategies and catchment management plans.

The problem for farmers is not just one of eliminating incentives to clear. We need positive incentives to retain or plant bush. As the coalition knows, farmers are having a hard time. One of the worst aspects of this is that farmers simply cannot afford to do what they know they should do to make their farms sustainable. I would like to repeat myself and say that farmers have been at the forefront in the push for land care. It is their land and their life, and they know that over-farming does not help. They have experienced the pain of seeing their land turn to salt pools and the soil blow away. For this reason, the Greens also support a number of measures designed to generate some economic gains for farmers to offset the immediate losses of over-farming.

We support 150 per cent tax deduction for land care work. Although there is a distinct lack of figures, businesses claiming in 1991-92 at 100 per cent deductibility cost the government only $36 million. This component would be expected to cost around $54 million in total, an increase of $18 million. Section 75D of the tax act should also be amended to make additional measures, for instance, restoration of riparian zones, wetlands, costs of protecting remnant vegetation, eligible as landcare expenditure. This is a small amount compared with the cost of land and water degradation.

We also support a 120 per cent tax deduction for the cost of seedlings and saplings of Australian trees and 150 per cent for local native trees where these are used for revegetation or land care. This is not applicable to commercial plantations; it is dual land care/commercial use at this rate. Tax deductions for use in commercial plantations would be set at 25 per cent for seedlings and saplings of Australian trees and 50 per cent for local native trees. Australian fauna often is specifically adapted to certain flora. This is designed to aid a shift from `Australian trees', which may include those like the Tasmanian blue gum, to trees appropriate to the region which will support existing remnant animal and bird populations.

Senator Coulter has proposed tax deductibility for leaving bushland as it is. This can be achieved by extension of tax laws which make conservation of built heritage deductible. It brings natural heritage into line with built heritage and says that natural things have value. This seems to be a minimum measure in ensuring that the tax system reflects the values of the community and the policies of government. It also seems likely that farmers who donate remnant bush that they wish to preserve understand that it will make their farms better and see this as the most cost effective way of doing so.

In Western Australia, we have had contact from some farmers who are having difficulty servicing their loans at the moment. Some of them have remnant bushland which may not have a terribly high market value, but they would have more ability to sell if there were this tax deductibility.

talk.start.para: â€”They have no taxable income, that is the problem.

â€”Senator Watson is querying this but it has actually happened in the last few weeks that we have been contacted by farmers who are saying that they are having trouble servicing their loans. Therefore, if they were able to find a buyer who would preserve the remnant bushland on their land, that bush would be maintained. By that means, there would probably also be volunteers to help manage that land. Any weeding and fencing work that needed to be done would be more available through those means. It is also a means of helping a number of farmers through a very difficult time when there is land that they know they cannot farm or those who, for positive reasons, are preserving land for its natural bush qualities.

para.tab: We believe it is great also, and will help both farmers and the region, if non-farmers purchase land and donate it. Our major concern is to ensure that natural heritage conservation organisations should have sufficient resources and integrity to ensure that the land is conserved as natural bush. We have pleasure in supporting the amendment.

talker.name: Senator SHERRY
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

talk.start.para: â€”The government will not be supporting this amendment. In dealing with Senator Margetts's contribution, I agree with many of the points she made about the need for conservation of the environment, particularly in many areas of Australia where, incorrectly, land has been cleared and there has been obvious degradation of the environment. But I do not think Senator Margetts has read the amendment. This amendment does not provide for any of that. What it does in terms of programs specifically targeted at curing those problems is to provide for a very open-ended deductibility for land to be donated. It does not specify what should occur to that land or what sort of land should be donated. It is totally open-ended.

para.tab: There are a couple of reasons why we oppose the amendment. This four-page amendment is unrelated to the legislation before the committee. Senator Coulter has moved an amendment like this beforeâ€”I acknowledge thatâ€”in a similar manner, by attaching it to a tax provision that is unrelated to the nature of the amendment that he is attempting to move. I am sure it is legitimate; there is nothing illegal about it. But in terms of assessing a proposal that is open-ended and could cost tens of millions of dollars, it is not the correct way to assess something of this nature. We do not know the cost of this measure to the budget. It could be $10 million, $20 million, $100 million.

Returning to the earlier argument, I would make the point that this land may not be land that needs attention. We could donate any land. That is one of the critical weaknesses of Senator Coulter's proposal. It is not a reasonable way in which to target what may be necessary and what I accept we need to be doing in many of these areas. But surely if we are to provide finance via way of a deductionâ€”whether it is $10 million, $20 million, $100 million or moreâ€”we should work out to which areas of this country the assistance needs to be directly targeted. We are very sceptical about very open measures of tax deductibility that do not have appropriate checks and balances. This government has funded a number of programs. Landcare is an obvious and very successful one that has been acknowledged by all, right across the environment and primary industry sector and across all political parties.

For those reasons, we cannot accept Senator Coulter's amendments. I welcome the principle put forward by Senator Watson that we will not accept it in the House of Representatives. I do not know whether he would be advancing that principle with respect to his position on other legislation. Perhaps if we were to declare that we were not going to support it in the House of Representatives, those opposite might support all our future legislation on that basis.

talk.start.para: â€”We are being practical.
â€”I accept that Senator Watson is being practical. He recognises the weakness in this approach and I welcome his support in opposing this amendment.

â€”It is possibly true that the amendment could be more detailed. I think that is a welcome statement in that it would indicate that the minister is prepared to think about or talk about within the government moves in the future which do have a program worked out. I know that a number of groups put such submissions to the government, for example in the process last year, including the Australian Conservation Foundation and so on. The information is in. There is a wealth of information about what benefits this bringsâ€”not just how much it costs the government, but what it brings in terms of benefits to communities, and eventually to government revenue when things work better, rather than at times of degradation of land.

para.tab: Perhaps we could get some sort of positive indication that the government will take on board this idea. Possibly the government can work with the various stakeholders and people with good ideas and come up with some finetuning. Indeed, it may come up with an idea that we can all have the pleasure of supporting in future.

talker.name: Senator SHERRY
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

talk.start.para: â€”There is a process by which these sorts of programs can be pursued. Senator Margetts, as a Green senator, and the Democrats have a structure within the context of the budget by which they can pursue these measures. Far be it from meâ€”

para.tab:
Senator Margetts interjecting
â€”

talk.start.para: â€”Just let me finish. Far be it from me as a humble parliamentary secretary, representing the Minister for Trade, who was representing the minister for industry, who was representing the Treasurer, to give some imprimatur to that suggestion, other than to indicate the way in which it can be pursued within a budget context. Personally, I have some sympathy for properly targeted measures for dealing with land degradation problems, but not open-ended measures that could cost tens of millions of dollars which might not necessarily achieve anything on the lines of what has been suggested.

â€”I pick up, first of all, the point that Senator Watson made in relation to Mr McLachlan. I do not think I have ever come into this chamber and picked up newspaper articles and press releases of other senators and tried to quote back to them what they have said. But I could easily have done so in the case of Mr McLachlan. He is on the record as saying that this measure should be implemented.
â€”He's not denying it.

â€”And Senator Watson is saying he is not denying that. Here we are putting down an amendment which gives effect to what Mr McLachlan, the shadow minister for environment and heritage, has abundantly enunciated on a number of occasions. Yet we are told by Senator Watson that those opposite cannot support it. I find that really strange.
â€”Butâ€”

â€”There is no `but', Senator Watson. The opposition's spokesperson on this issue has said that this is what should be done, and here we have given the opposition an opportunity to vote for it, but it is not prepared to do so. I thank Senator Margetts for using the words `minimal measure'. This is indeed a minimal measure, but we know full well that when we have tried more ambitious measures, more courageous measures, there is very little chance that the government will support them. So, one puts up minimal measures in the hope that the government might have the sort of courage that the Whitlam government had in 1972.

para.tab: I have been in the conservation movement long enough to have battled long and hard right through the 1950s and the 1960s to get section 75(1)(b), as I recall it, in the old tax act, in relation to tax deductibility for the clearance of land, modified. It took years and years and years, and when Mr Whitlam became Prime Minister he had the courage to radically change that section of the income tax act and to significantly modify it to restrict tax deductibility for the clearance of land. I just wish that the present government had that sort of courage, but we do not find it. When we put up a minimal measureâ€”and I thank Senator Margetts for that assessmentâ€”we find that the government still cannot support it.

The parliamentary secretary has said that this is open-ended. What a lot of nonsense! We have a long list of bodies to which donations are tax deductible. What happens if Rupert Murdoch, in his sudden magnanimity, decides to give $100 million to the Australian Conservation Foundation as a tax deductible donation? It is not likely to happen, but the process of making donations to bodies tax deductible is open-ended. The government has no idea whatsoever what donations are going to come in, and so it has no idea what the effect is going to be on the total tax take. To attempt to draw some distinction between land and money on the basis of open-endedness is clearly ridiculous.

I draw Senator Sherry's attention to the section at the bottom of page three where one of the amendments says, `The environment minister and Treasurer may classify as a natural heritage conservation organisation' and so on. It clearly gives the minister the power to determine that those bodies that are legitimately accepting land for proper conservation purposes are bodies within the meaning of these sections. Clearly, that provides to the minister and the government the two controls that are necessary: firstly, that the land is legitimately to be used for conservation purposes; and secondly, some control on the so-called open-endedness. I really do not think that the government has put up any argument in relation to this.

As everybody has acknowledged, I have previously moved an amendment along very similar lines. The government should have this on its agenda and it should be looking at it. We should not need to take it further before the government considers the merits of it. Hopefully, we will come back at some future time, as Senator Margetts has suggested, with an amendment in a suitable tax bill which will achieve this objectiveâ€”hopefully a lot more. Senator Margetts has outlined a number of things, many of which were in our
Getting to Work
document. They are things that we have proposed previously.

This is a minimal measure. Please, government, take this as notice that we will continue to move amendments like this. Please consider it and, if this one is not suitable, come forward with another amendment at some future time which we can all support.

talker.name: Senator SHERRY
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

talk.start.para: â€”I have just a brief response to the assertion by Senator Coulter that this is a minimal measure. He has drawn our attention to the paragraph at the bottom of page three of the amendment and asserts that this is a limit. It is a limit on the nature of the organisations that can receive a gift of land as certified by the environment minister and the Treasurer, but it is not a limit on the total amount and the value of the land that can be donated to the organisations. That is the sort of open-ended commitment that I am referring to.

I am fairly confident that in some measure he will attempt to address in government the sorts of issues that have been raised in the committee debate today.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

speech.para: No.1â€”Clause 129, page 75, at end of clause, add "and provide for sales tax credits in respect of parts used in re-manufacturing goods sold to or leased by exempt users".

This clause affects sales tax and what are known as remanufactured goods in Australia which are sold to exempt users. The coalition amendment will provide a sales tax exemption for parts used in the remanufacture of goods sold or leased to exempt users, such as government departments, schools, libraries and so on.

para.tab: The amendment is necessary for two main reasons. Firstly, the existing treatment of remanufactured goods was not apparently intended by the new sales tax legislation and is inconsistent with the sales tax treatment of both new goods and imported remanufactured goods. Secondly, the current treatment is a disincentive to the burgeoning local remanufacturing industry. Remanufacturing plays a beneficial role in the Australian economy. I thank the Greens and the Australian Democrats for their support for this measure.

This amendment will encourage the remanufacturing industry, which has great potential for significant future growth. There is growth in the overseas demand for remanufactured goods, and Australia's remanufactured goods are substitutes for the new and remanufactured imported goods. Of course, there are also significant employment and recycling advantages.

Senator Schacht's comment in a public hearing some time ago was that the government would have further discussion with the industry about the issue. That was encouraging and I therefore find the government's response tonight somewhat disappointing.

In the bill the government is extending the availability of sales tax exemptions to parts used to repair goods to be exported. The coalition amendment goes one step further and follows the logic in the same direction. It will therefore restore the status quo of the sales tax position as at 1 January 1993. It is no good for the government to say that for decades the law was unclear because the law operated very clearly in relation to this issue. The restoration of the sales tax exemption, while generating significant benefits for the economy and encouraging the use of recycled products, will have a very minor impact on revenue.

During the second reading debate I expounded the virtues and the necessity for the support for this measure. Because of the lateness of the hour, I will not reiterate those arguments but I refer this chamber to the second reading debate. I ask honourable senators to support the amendment.

talker.name: Senator KERNOT
talker.role: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

talk.start.para: â€”As has been indicated, the Australian Democrats will be supporting this amendment because it encourages the recycling of goods. In doing that, it encourages a highly labour intensive process to occur in Australia rather than the import of more goods from overseas.

para.tab: We think the goods should have been made to last longer in the first place, and I think this will encourage manufacturers. It is important to note that this sales tax exemption is being sought only for the non-taxable sector. It should result in a reduction in the price of goods by encouraging remanufacturing. Charitable and educational bodies will be able to obtain photocopying, photographic and other equipment at a much lower price. That will enable those bodies to release funds for other purposes, and I think that is an important principle.

talker.name: Senator SHERRY
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

talk.start.para: â€”First, let me deal with the last point that Senator Kernot made about charitable organisations and government departments being able to obtain photocopiers at a much lower price. We do not believe that is going to be the case.
â€”You don't?

â€”No, we do not believe that will be the case. At the moment these goods are sold at about 20 per cent of the retail price. At best, we might see a three or four per cent reduction in the price of the good.
â€”If you are a charitable organisation, that helps.

â€”It certainly does; but with respect to the cost of this measure, we are not just looking at charitable organisations. The sales tax is on the parts used in the remanufacturing process. These parts make up only a small fraction of the cost of repairing the good or recycling the good.
â€”It will actually increase the number available on the market, which means the price will be competitive.

â€”We will see what the price will be when Senator Margetts dashes out to buy her second-hand photocopier. The remanufacturing is a labour intensive process, not a capital intensive process. This means that the substantial cost of refurbishing the photocopier is labour, not the parts. In fact, labour comprises 85 per cent of the value of the remanufactured goods. So, for that reason, the point made about the substantial reduction in price is just not correct.

para.tab: Provision has been made for a sales tax credit to be given where spare parts are used in repairing goods for export. This follows amendments last year in relation to spare parts used in repairing machinery that is ultimately sold to farmers, miners and manufacturers. Xerox and other companies are seeking a sales tax credit on spare parts used in repairing remanufactured goods that are ultimately sold to exempt persons such as government departments, schools and libraries.

The government is opposing the amendment that the opposition and, obviously, the Democrats and the Greens are supporting. There is nothing in the structure of sales tax in Australia which requires a credit ground of the kind being sought. It is simply an extension of a concession, that is, the concession given to government and benevolent bodies to not pay sales tax on goods they use. The basic design of the sales tax system is to tax the output of manufacturers; that is, the sales tax is a tax on goods.

To avoid double taxation, the inputs of manufacturers are exempt from sales tax because their value is picked up in the outputs which are taxed. But the inputs of service providersâ€”for example, the tourism industryâ€”are taxable because they do not produce other goods which are subject to tax. Thus, the tax free status of inputs to service providers such as government departments and hospitals is a concession which the opposition amendment seeks to extend.

The economic impactâ€”and I have already partly dealt with thisâ€”of providing the credit ground would appear to be very marginal at best. I have already outlined some issues in respect of that. It is material to note that sales of remanufactured goods to tax exempt users is only a part of the picture. In fact, around 60 per cent of sales of remanufactured goods are to taxable users. Australia positively discriminates in favour of local remanufacturing where sales are to taxable users. Imported remanufactured goods are subject to sales tax on their whole value when sold to taxable users.

Goods previously used in Australia which are expected to be repaired and then re-imported are subject to sales tax on the new parts and labour component of their value when sold to taxable users in Australia. This provides local remanufacturing with a significant advantage in the major part of their market. If there is a problem in making salesâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”Plus a sales tax impost.
â€”Let me finish, Senator Watson.
â€”What is the rate of tax on it?

â€”Senator Watson may laugh at a measure that is likely to cost millions of dollars. I will make a point about that at the conclusion of my contribution. If there is a problem with making sales to the tax exempt sector, it must be because of something other than dollars of sales tax. Remanufactured goods are already in some industries 20 per cent cheaper than new goods and carry the same warranty. If government departments still will not buy them it has to do with something other than the sales tax issue.
â€”They will buy them, so you are going to get them cheaper.

â€”I have already argued that the cheapness of the sale price arising from this is very minor. It is not minor in terms of the tax the government is going to lose. I will come to that point later. There are administrative complexities in having credit grounds on parts used in second-hand goods. Given the marginal benefits of providing the credit ground, the government is not inclined to add to the costs of operating the sales tax system. The opposition frequently criticises the government for the cost of the sales tax system. The opposition is proposing to make it more complex.

para.tab: There can be no guaranteed way of ensuring that the benefit of the credit ground would flow through to the end users, in which case the credit ground could simply be a transfer from the Commonwealth to the bottom line of the remanufacturers. That is where the money will go. There are literally hundreds of good ideas for not charging sales tax on certain goods.

talk.start.para: â€”If only we should listen to them.
â€”Yes. Senator Margetts can tell us where she is going to make up the lost revenue.
â€”Yes, we can.
â€”The Democrats can, but I am not sure the Greens can.
â€”Oh!
â€”I am not having a go at Senator Margetts. I am just criticising her.
â€”What's the difference?

â€”I am criticising her in a reasonably pleasant way. I will be a bit tougher in a moment. All of these good ideas come at a price and when taken together the price is significant. Given the range of pressures on the budget and the other reasons outlined, on balance the government cannot agree with this measure. This measure, which is unfortunately going to be carried, will cost millions of dollars. It is the height of irresponsibility, not so much on the part of the Greens and the Democrats because they are not likely to form government and we are used to irresponsible measures from themâ€”
â€”We showed you how to raise taxes.
â€”Yes, the Democrats did show us how to raise taxesâ€”
â€”And how to spend them.

â€”The Democrats certainly show us how to spend the taxes we raise. This year and next year when those opposite are giving their input to the budget, they will be reminded of these sorts of measures that cost the government millions of dollars and do not accomplish what they want. I am getting worked up now. The previous amendment could have cost the government millions of dollars.
â€”Do you want the bill tonight?
â€”We are doing well. It is three minutes to seven. When the government stands to lose millions of dollars, it cannot take these things lying down.
â€”Tax the rich; that could help.

â€”Tax the rich. That is Senator Margetts's solution. It is not that easy. Senator Margetts photocopies this sort of argument all the time and puts it forward all the time. There would be millions of dollars in lost government revenue and it will not accomplish what those opposite want. I am surprised by the grossly irresponsible stance that the opposition is taking, and I am particularly surprised at Senator Watson's stance. For a party that seeks to win government to continually erode the government's tax base in this way is grossly irresponsible. The opposition is continually saying that we should cut government expenditure and cut taxesâ€”
â€”But you have to be true to your promises; that's the problem.
â€”There is no breach of commitment here, Senator Watson.

â€”There was. Read the
Hansard
.

â€”There is not. Unfortunately, Senator Watson believes the opposition's propaganda. We know what we committed ourselves to at the last election. This is not a breach of our promises. For all those reasons, I make a final appeal to those opposite to reconsider their position. What does a few more million dollars taken off the government's budget mean to an irresponsible opposition?
â€”Keep to your script.

â€”I do not have a script on this. We know the opposition is irresponsible, wasting millions of dollars. Given the budget deficit, we have to find savings elsewhere. That is the sort of irresponsible opposition we have. Members of the opposition are peeved because they lost the last election. They think they were robbed. They still cannot acknowledge the idiotic program that they put up and on which they were defeated. They intend to be irresponsible by eroding our revenue base. For that reason, I am very disappointed that the Greens and the Democrats are joining in this peevish approach to the development of policy and to erode our budget. And I hope you all have a good weekend.

â€”I remind the people listening to this debate and the Senate that the government gave a clear undertaking when it introduced streamlined sales tax that people who were exempt prior to the new arrangements would not be subject to tax under the subsequent arrangements. The purpose of this amendment is to keep the government honest to that undertaking, which it is now attempting to walk away from. The government is now arguing that it is losing millions of dollars of tax. It never had that tax, so this is a new tax. It is breaking a promise.

para.tab: I remind Senator Sherry of the comments he made last year in relation to the amendments to assist producers in the mining and agricultural area in relation to repairs for cash. This draws my attention to a failing of the government at the time to include the leasing arrangements. Farmers in this day and age cannot always pay cash. They increasingly are entering into leasing arrangements. I draw Senator Sherry's attention to the major problem with that amendment at that time. If he is going to be consistent, he needs to address that issue to include the leasing as well as the payments in cash in the mining and agricultural areas.

We ask Senator Sherry, on behalf of the Labor Party, to honour his undertakings. Effectively the government is casting aspersions on the quality of its purchasing officers in the various exempt areas because they are unable, according to the government's criteria, to push a case as to whether the reduction in sales tax arising from this would be passed on in the form of lower charges. That argument is a reflection on the ability of purchasing officers to negotiate and to be aware of the components of the cost structures.

The amendment has not only economic advantages to Australia in terms of relief, the balance of payments and employment opportunities but also advantages for the environment. I wish Senator Faulkner were here because I am sure he would have given this issue much more consideration.

The sort of equipment we are looking at really takes up a lot of tip space when it is junked. Here we have a facility to reuse that equipment in an environmentally friendly manner and this will be used always by exempt users. We are referring to Commonwealth governments, state governments, hospitals, charities and all those sorts of agencies which deserve the maximum consideration in being able to purchase their goods at the lowest price.

I ask people listening to this debate: do you not think it is wrong that these goods can come into Australia without sales tax being paid on them whereas the locally produced products attract very high sales tax? I asked the minister what the rate is and he will not tell me because he is embarrassed by it. Is it a sort of penal rate? Is it a pretty high rate?

talk.start.para: â€”It is 21 per cent.

â€”That is right. It is 21 per cent, thank you. We were aware of that. There is a 21 per cent sales tax on goods produced in Australia, but imports are free of that 21 per cent sales tax. Be consistent. Re-examine this and agree to the amendment.

speech.speaker: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

talker.name: Senator SHERRY
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

talk.start.para: â€”I will be brief, although I will not appeal to the populace who I am sure are listening to the debate.
â€”The argument is won.

â€”I know the argument is won because the opposition has the numbers. But the opposition has not won the argument. The only point I want to make is that, at the last election, our commitment was that this package would be revenue neutral. That is not what the opposition is doing now. This industry knew the approach we would take on this issue. It is unfortunate that the opposition is making this amendment, because the outcome will not be revenue neutral. It will mean the loss of many millions of dollars in revenue to the government.

talk.start.para: â€”Clauses 156 to 159 concern the Royal Flying Doctor Service. During the second reading debate I pointed to the anomalous sales tax position which exempts from sales tax only the purchase of transceivers which are used `mainly' for communicating with RFDS. I strongly urge the government to review this situation. Not unlike the sales tax anomaly which I spoke to a few moments ago with respect to the parts used in the re-manufacturing of goods, here is another example of what I call the streamlined sales tax revenue regime failing to accord with the old sales tax law. I remind Senator Sherry that the commitment I am referring to was not a government election commitment but a commitment made in relation to the transition from the old sales tax regime to the new sales tax regime, which came into effect on 1 January 1993.

para.tab: I remind the Senate that the `for use mainly' test in the current legislation has the unintended effect of removing the exemption for wireless transceivers used by most people in remote areas for maintaining contact with the RFDS for emergency medical assistance. I remind honourable senators who were listening to the Ian McNamara program on Sunday when they were raising lots of money for the Royal Flying Doctor Service of the eloquent service that is provided by that organisation and the reliance of these people in the outback on these transceivers. I therefore draw the attention of the committee to this anomaly, which is disadvantaging those people in the outback, in relation to the new sales tax regime compared with the old one.

talk.start.para: â€”That is right.

â€”I note that I am getting a lot of support here from my colleague from Western Australia, Senator Panizza, the man from the bush, the man who represents the outback. Of most concern, of course, is the risk that direct communication with the RFDS will dramatically reduce and could result in an increase in suffering and possible loss of life for those living and travelling in remote areas of this great country of ours.

para.tab: As I indicated during the second reading debate, it is interesting to note that the Adelaide branch of the tax office is not actually following the letter of the law. I applaud it for that because, as Senator Chapman, who is from South Australia, knows, there are a lot of people who benefit from these transceivers. In permitting certain organisations to apply the `for use' test in the previous legislation, obviously the tax office holds the view that the current legislation is incorrect. The government, I believe, needs to address this issue immediately, and I ask for a commitment from Senator Sherry that he will address this issue.

Unfortunately, amendment is outside the proscriptions that we have laid down in terms of changing government budget strategy. But, again I ask Senator Sherry to address this issue and ensure that this issue is amendedâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”Earlier today I gave a notice of motion and subsequently also asked the Minister for Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) a question urging the government not to sign the United Nations convention on desertification tomorrow as this government plans to doâ€”and with very good reason. There has been an overwhelming response to the Liberal and National parties' committee of inquiry into the United Nations convention on desertification. Among the many and wide-ranging submissions, not one supports the signing of this convention without reservation. There are a few who do not oppose the signing, but even they believe that there should be much greater community consultation before signing and are implacably opposed to ratification should the government determine to lodge a national action plan.

para.tab: Today Senator Faulkner, in reply to my question concerning the government's precipitous signing of the United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification, stated that he did not give a damn about the coalition's inquiry. That comment from the minister is simply another reflection of the arrogance with which this government treats the Australian community. There should have been a full-scale Senate inquiry into the government's intention to sign this convention. That was a motion that I put to the Senate some weeks ago. It was only narrowly defeatedâ€”by two votes.

The inquiry not having been established, the Liberal and National parties, aware of the enormous community concern about the proposed signing by the government of this convention following the conclusion of treaty text negotiations in June of this yearâ€”community concern which I am sure Senator Panizza is also aware of, representing as he does the rural areas of Western Australiaâ€”determined that we would conduct our own inquiry. Therefore, we set up a committee of inquiry which consisted of me as chairman, Senator Kemp, Senator Crane, and Senator O'Chee from the National Party. The coalition believes that it is important to permit Australian individuals and groups an opportunity to present legitimate concerns about this treaty and to provide a forum for that to occur, given that this government in its arrogance failed to consult adequately with industry groups, with state governments and with rural communities potentially affected by this treaty.

The results of this coalition inquiry have more than justified the parliamentary party's decision to establish it. In stating that he did not give a damn about the coalition's inquiry, the minister has effectively thumbed his nose at those who forwarded submissions to our inquiry and agreed to willingly participate. The minister has effectively told those peopleâ€”individuals, and some significant Australian companies and industry associations with a wide cross-section of membershipâ€”that he does not give a damn about them.

Among the companies and organisations that have made submissions to this coalition inquiry are the National Farmers Federation, a number of the state divisions of the National Farmers Federationâ€”such as the South Australian Farmers Federation, the New South Wales Farmers Association and the Victorian Farmers Federationâ€”the Australian Mining Industry Council, the district council of Mt Remarkable, CRA Ltd, Kidman Holdings, the pastoral company, and the Country Women's Association of NSW. The list goes on and on. These are the people about whom Senator Faulkner says he does not give a damn.

It is staggering that the government, in the face of this massive opposition to its actions in signing this treaty, has chosen, with this extraordinary display of arrogance by the minister, to ignore the message coming from these people of some significance in the Australian community. Perhaps part of the blame lies with the media for not drawing the attention of this issue to those Australians who live in the coastal regions rather than the inland, more isolated areas. Perhaps some of those people living in coastal regions may not be aware of the significance and the potential impact of this treaty.

This treaty might not be as headline-grabbing an issue as sexual privacy but let me say to this Senate that it essentially deals with the same issue. That issue is the centralised grab for power by this governmentâ€”in the case of the desertification treaty, to wrest control of rural land management from state governments. The central issue is the use, yet again, of the external affairs power to enact legislation to take away the management of problems which are best left to local communities to solve, to people who are close to the problems and who can assess which techniques may best be used to suit unique local conditions.

It is hard to imagine a more ludicrous situation than a government department bureaucrat, comfortably ensconced in a cosy Canberra cavern, setting policy for outback Northern Territory, far northern Western Australia, which my colleague Senator Panizza represents so well, mid north-west Queensland or, indeed, the western areas of New South Wales that my colleague Senator Woods from New South Wales represents.

In my own state of South Australia, local government councils are aghast at this prospect. It is beyond the imagination of farmers in the mid-north of South Australia to conceive of how these people could have the gall to dictate policy to them from Canberra.

There is another issueâ€”the fundamental weakness inherent in treaty negotiations of this sort. Parameters which may initially be set by the federal government at the beginning of negotiations are rarely re-examined during the treaty negotiation process. Each negotiating session results in a markedly different text to the one on which the government may have set its original parameters. Negotiating teams are left to protect the nation's interest as the texts alter and only report back to the government at the conclusion of each negotiating session.

A small group of people on the negotiating committee are therefore left to battle with protecting Australia's national interests, often in an arena where Australia's traditional United Nations negotiating blocs and allies, due to different trade and economic structures, may not have negotiating positions consistent with our own. All this is done without reference to the parliament or even the cabinet. The dangers or challenges of these treaties often cannot be foreseen and the impact on Australian domestic policy, including trade implications, should be fully investigated prior to signing. In the case of this treaty, this government has simply failed to do that.

It is my understanding that the current Treasurer, Ralph Willis, will undertake the signing on behalf of Australia at the opening ceremony in Paris on 14 October, which is tomorrow. The Treasurer is undertaking this task apparently because he will be in the area at the time. The government is perhaps to be commended on its restraint, and I applaud the economy of multi-tasking in designating the Treasurer to sign this treaty rather than perhaps Senator Evans or Senator Faulkner taking another overseas junket to perform this function.

I certainly hope that Treasurer Willis does not make the same mistake as the lately departed environment minister, Ros Kelly, at the Rio Earth Summit. She signed for Argentina instead of for Australia, the only similarity being that both begin and end with the letter `A'.

talk.start.para: â€”Ha, ha!
â€”I note the reactions of my colleagues to that performance by Mrs Kelly. Of course, it was reinforced by other misadventures into which she fell and, because of which, subsequently fell from grace.

para.tab: It is worth making one final point: the treaty cannot be ratified until a sufficient number of countries have signed it. The best guess by foreign affairs experts is that this process may take up to six months.

I would like to close with a question for the government: why has there been such undue haste in signing this treaty? It would be better for the government to delay signing it until such time as the government can better explain the impact this treaty will have on Australia and Australians and at least make some attempt to alleviate the genuine, legitimate concerns which Australians have about this treaty.

Experience with the climate control convention has shown that the government clearly does not understand the implications of these treaties, nor can we meet our obligations under them in time. There are often hidden impacts which may take yearsâ€”and a High Court decisionâ€”to be revealed. Surely the government should learn from its mistakes. There is every reason for us to urge it to do so. The only reason that one can possibly give for the government signing this treaty tomorrow is that it wants to grandstand at the opening ceremony for the sake of international popularity. That is simply not good enough when, as I said, the Australian community has many concerns about this treaty. The signing ought to be delayed until some later period.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: â€”Tonight I want to address one of the most important issues in Australia todayâ€”homeless youth. In particular, I want to focus on and talk briefly about one of the great workers in this field, Bill Crews. Bill is the minister at the Uniting Church in Ashfield, which is in my former electorate of Lowe. He is a delightful fellow and one of my great heroes. He came to Ashfield some years ago and I think it is fair to say that he sent some shock waves around that local church which was, until then, the average local Uniting Church.

para.tab: Bill Crews decided that Christianity should be not only theological but practical and, as a result of his work in this area, he set up the Exodus Foundation. The Exodus Foundation essentially offers food and shelter to homeless kids. He has worked tirelessly on this particular project and has turned it into an example of what Christianity should be and sometimes is notâ€”that it should not be a dry theological religion by itself; it should a religion in action, a religion helping the community.

Bill has demonstrated to the Uniting Church in Ashfield what I might call Christianity with its sleeves rolled up. Bill devotes every waking moment and, I suspect, every sleeping moment too, to this foundation. If in my lifetime I achieve a fraction of the good for the community that Bill has achieved already, I will be justifiably proud of my existence and I expect my family would be too.

But the issue today is a sad one. Two weeks ago, Bill had to close his refuge for homeless kids. Why? There are essentially two different reasons. The first is a reduction in funding from private sources. Bill has done a fantastic job throughout the recession in raising enormous amounts of funds to keep this project going, to reach out to literally thousands of homeless kids and unemployed and disadvantaged people in the area. He has performed minor miracles but for some reason the funds have recently dried up.

I plead for help for the Exodus Foundation. I say to any company or individual, rich or poor, who has a few dollars to spareâ€”particularly if they have a lot of dollars to spareâ€”there is no better cause to donate to than this worthwhile cause. I am sure that this view is widely shared. I know that my colleagues currently in the chamber certainly share this view.

I cannot emphasise what a wonderful job this foundation does for the community. It is absolutely fantastic. So I pleadâ€”almost in desperationâ€”for the community to open up its pockets and donate money to this foundation to rectify the problem. I am proud to say that all the profits and income of the New South Wales Premier's cocktail partyâ€”that is, John Fahey's Liberal Party cocktail partyâ€”will be donated to the Exodus Foundation. Even though that may be a small gesture, I am delighted to be part of that.

The second reason the refuge was closed relates to government. This has happened in a number of different ways. The first relates to the bureaucracy. The bureaucracy has interfered in the caring of homeless children. It used to be a simple matter. Bill used to do it in a nice, simple fashion. He used to offer shelter, food, support and counselling. He did it, I think it is fair to say, on a shoestring but he did it remarkably effectively. I think the results of his pastoral ministry speak for themselves.

But then the bureaucracy got involved. The bureaucracy put in regulations, red tape, requirements and formsâ€”most of which was unnecessary. The regulations that now have to be followed in this area by people like Bill Crews mean that something like $4,000 per homeless kid has to be spent per monthâ€”mainly to meet the requirements of the bureaucracy. Bill can provide shelter and food for something like $10 a day, so there is a great discrepancy there.

The bureaucracy is requiring social worker support and other such things, many of which are very desirable. But it has become counterproductive when the requirements of the bureaucracy are such that refuges such as Bill's are being forced to shut down. I have to say that the bureaucrats in this regard are all too often raising barriers rather than lowering them. They are excluding people rather than including them. There was a recent article in the
Sydney Morning Herald
by Amanda Meade who, in reporting on some issues, indicated that something like 40 per cent of the needy were still sleeping on the streets in spite of the apparent investment in homes for those people.

Bill rightly pointed out that it would be cheaper to send the homeless kids to a high cost, first class, upper level boarding school than to care for them in the way the bureaucracy wants. That is a terrible indictment of the bureaucracy. But there are more problems and, again, sadly they are with the government. One is the difficulty of accessing government funds. Today, Bill said to me, `They just keep changing the rules. They tell us to put in applications on appropriate forms, so we ask for the forms. Then they tell us the forms aren't available because they are being redrafted and reprinted. We then ask to get into the system anyway, only to be told, "You can't get into the system unless you have the applications on the proper forms; and the proper forms are not there." It just goes round and round in circles. If you are already in the system you are okay; but if you are not in the system, it is very difficult to get into it.'

Very recently, the foundation was told that there was no more funding available for the next two years. It is clear, according to sources in the area, that there are people in that system who are known to be doing a substandard job but they can get extra money from the pool because others, who may have better plans, cannot get into the system because of all the red tape. As Bill describes it, it is an unbelievably frustrating bureaucratic nightmare. I emphasise that Bill is the most reasonable of men. His views on this matter are to be taken with the utmost seriousness.

Another indication of the problems he has faced is that at the back of the Uniting Church in Ashfield there is a building which is rather like a gym or a warehouse. It is nothing very fancy. It is financed, if I remember rightly, by Burns Philp. My commendations go to Burns Philp for investing in this. It was planned to be a crisis refuge but it cannot be opened as a crisis refuge because the bureaucrats have said that to be a crisis refuge there cannot be a dormitory arrangement; there have to be two separate dormitories. There have to be partitions; there have to be privacy arrangements. Because of that, the kids who would be sleeping in this refuge are not allowed to go there. Instead, they are sleeping in the gutters.

It is unbelievable that there is not enough commonsense in the bureaucracy to realise that whether or not there is a partition is of no great moment when the alternative is sleeping in the gutters amongst the addicts, the thieves and the muggers who are outside. To meet the requirements of the bureaucracy, the foundation would have to spend another $20,000 to $40,000. It is such sadness. It breaks my heart to see people like Bill and his wonderful team of volunteers working their hearts out, to have it thrown back in their faces like this, by an uncaring bureaucracy.

There is still a problem. I do not know how big it is. Seven or so years ago, Burdekin told the country that something like 25,000 people are affected. There seems to be no doubt that there is still an ongoing problem. Bill told me that only last night a doctor called and drew his attention to the plight of a woman and her five children. They had been living in a car since the recent death of her husband. Bill sorted things out. As he said, the organisation gives priority attention to the plight of kids. It is basically into providing food, shelter and support. But it cannot get the bureaucrats to realise the enormity of the problems. They continue with their tail chasing and buck-passing and invent new ways of stopping people from accessing government funds, rather than helping people to do the work and to deal with the realities of the problems in the community.

The government, as I understand it, spends over $100 million in this area but, sadly, it is not effectively spent. If people like Bill Crews have to close down a refuge, it is the worst possible indictment of government expenditure and management that I can imagine. There is a duplication because the system is organised and run by the federal bureaucracy and implemented by the state bureaucracies. So, on top of that, we have duplication in this area. How anybody could imagine that would be effective is beyond me.

We have a system where the nature of the regulations means that it costs $20,000 a month to put through the four or five kids and youths that Bill was looking after before. It had managed to operate for 12 months and that project almost sent the Exodus Foundation broke, in spite of all the fund raising and hard work that Bill and his volunteers are doing. They had to close the program to enable them to keep operating in other ways in the community. They followed all the rules for their refuge and that is what made it expensive. They followed all the rules, but they could not get the money. They were between the devil and the deep blue sea.

There seems to be nobody really caring about the plight of the kids in the system. It fills me with embarrassment to be part of a supposedly great, leading nation in this world which has a problem like this on its own back doorstep, where kids could be easily looked after, cared for, fed and housed and yet they are not because of the bureaucracy not really caring about the real world, only about their own comfort, their own empires and their own promotions. I say to the minister responsible, Brian Howe, a man who claims to have compassion in these areas: show some of that compassion and some of that commonsense and fix this problem.
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: Woodley Sen J.

talk.start.para: â€”I rise tonight to speak on the Port Hinchinbrook development because I believe there are still questions which need to be answered. I would like to place on the record some of these questions and some of the background which makes me ask and continue to ask questions about this particular development.

para.tab: One of the questions is to do with legal advice that we understand the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Faulkner, may have received on the extent of the Commonwealth's powers to intervene in the construction of the Port Hinchinbrook resort. I believe that many of us would like to see that advice. We would like to know what the advice says. We would like the minister to release that advice. That is the first matter.

I give the minister credit that he has made some effort to try to protect native forests, for example, in states such as Tasmania, but I do want him to act to protect this precious site in Queensland. So another question I ask is: will he do this to the extent of the powers he has?

Again, I give Minister Faulkner credit that he has insisted on adequate scientific studies to be carried out in the Hinchinbrook Channel, which is part of the World Heritage area, before approval is given for dredging. However, there does not seem to be recognition from either the state or federal governments of the problem of allowing construction of the resort to go ahead while assessment of the impact of its operations is still being undertaken. What is going to happen, I ask, if construction continues for another six months and then the evidence comes in to show that World Heritage values of the area will be significantly affected?

Given that the developer insists on not changing any aspects of his development, although I give him credit for reducing the number of beds from the original proposal, will we be faced with a half or fully built resort which is, quite justifiably, refused permission to operate? Honourable senators can see the problem. Will the Queensland government, which has done all it can to push this development through, be prepared to pay compensation for the expenses incurred by the developer?

It is very unclear whether the baseline study of the Hinchinbrook Channel, which is required by the federal minister, will be adequately carried out. The Queensland environment minister talks of a study which will be concluded in a few weeks and which is being carried out by the Department of Primary Industries, which can hardly be seen as an independent or objective participant.

I need to place on record the lack of confidence I have in the processes presently and formerly undertaken by the government. I have a letter, obtained under freedom of information, from Mr Williams to the Coordinator-General's department dated 15 April 1994. It is his comments on the environment report. He writes:

speech.para: As a result of the meeting on Wednesday night, 13th April, at which Chris Pattearson, Jan Bimrose and I discussed major issues as contained in the document I have now had the opportunity to fully consider the contents of such document and Jan Bimrose has already received by fax my comments and suggestions which must be incorporated before it is released to the public.
Further, he says:

My suggestions for amendments to the report are not negotiable on the grounds that I am not about to embark on this major project with skeletons in the cupboard that I will have to argue about at a later date.

Honourable senators can see how concerned someone could be that Mr Williams should have had such input to what I would have hoped would be a totally independent document. Mr Williams further states in his letter to the Office of the Coordinator-General:

I stated earlier in this letter that I am not negotiable in regard to my requirements for an amended document and, furthermore, I am not negotiable in regard to the date established for the issue of permits (6th June, 1994).
Finally, Mr Williams concludes his letter to the department by saying:

In view of the above I feel that I have unshakeable grounds for insisting that such delays as have been caused by non compliance of the grounds rules established should be compensated for by shortening the time from closure of public comments to the issuing of permits.
I also quote from the fax from the Coordinator-General to Mr Williams responding to his letter:
I refer to your two facsimile messages . . . and a third facsimile message of 15 April 1994, in relation to the draft Environmental Report.

para.tab: Your comments and requests have been examined in detail and the following changes made to the document . . .

speech.para: I wish I had a little more time to read those changes, but perhaps another occasion will suffice. Honourable senators can understand the concerns that we have when we discover that Mr Williams had such a significant input to the writing of that environment report.

para.tab: Another concern which has been expressed is the pressure from the influx of people into the area. Many people are worried about this. Contrary to statements made by Mr Williams, many of these people come from Cardwell and the surrounding areas. I will quote from just one of the letters that I received today. It is a letter to Senator Kernot. The gentleman who wrote this letter is a former overseer for the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service. He writes:

speech.para: Should a channel be allowed, people pressure alone will be devastating to the small islands of the family group, including both Gould Is. and the Brook Island group, Hinchinbrook Is. in particular would suffer from the effects of visitation, it would be a tragedy to see this beautiful island (degraded) because of too much visitation. Qld NP&WS have a system regards limiting the number of campers on an area at any one time, but this does not apply to day visitors, so large numbers of people can use an area daily with tragic results. I was o/seer in charge of island parks in this local area from 1972 until 1988 and saw first hand, damage that can be done to areas with only light visitation . . .

I received a phone call from another gentleman who was born in Cairns, who lived in Cardwell in the 1940s, 1950s and 1960s and who still visits the area regularly. He says that it is a marvellous area, and I concur in that, but he believes the environment is under pressure from people being attracted by the development. He says that a large number of people in Cardwell are not convinced about the development.

para.tab: Let me conclude by saying that construction of this oversized resort is happening today, yet all these questions are yet to be answered. It will soon be too late. I urge the minister to visit Hinchinbrook and to use all of his power to convince the Queensland government to start playing by the rules.
