talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 30 August 1994:

para.tab: With reference to the sale of the remainder of the uranium stockpile, reported by Australian Associated Press on 24 August 1994:
(1)(a) What was the tonnage of the remainder of the uranium stockpile; (b) What was the price gained per pound; and (c) What was the selling price of the stockpile.
(2) To which country or countries did the Government sell the remainder of the uranium stockpile.
(3) How will the uranium be used in those countries.
(4) What were the terms of the sale of the uranium stockpile to those countries.
(5) At any time during the sale, were terms discussed about preventing the buyer from `on-selling' the uranium or plutonium to other countries.
(6) What safeguards are there to prevent a buyer on-selling the uranium or plutonium to other countries.
(7) Are these safeguards effective or adequate; if so, what is the basis for this view.

(8) Does the Government have any evidence of countries on-selling Australian uranium or its by-product plutonium to other countries; if so: (a) Which countries were involved; (b) What amount of uranium was involved; and (c) What was the end use of that uranium.

(9) If any of the above questions cannot be answered at this period in time, will the Minister provide an explanation as to the rationale for this decision together with a time when this information will be available and a commitment to provide that information as soon as it is available; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

para.tab: (1)(a) 1814 tonnes;
(b) Confidentiality clauses in the sale agreements prevent both parties to the agreement from releasing details of the terms and conditions of these agreements, including details of purchase price;
(c) in the order of $60mâ€”but the exact amount to be received is subject to movements in market prices and exchange rates up to 30 June 1995.
(2) All material from the stockpile is being delivered to buyers in the United States and in Canada for use in those countries.
(3) Concentrates from the stockpile will be converted into nuclear fuel for use in civilian electric power generation.

(4) Confidentiality clauses in the sale agreements prevent both parties to the agreement from releasing details of the terms and conditions of these agreements. However conditions incorporated in these agreements are consistent with the Government's stated policy that material from the stockpile will only be sold for civil electricity generation in North America.

(5) All Australian uranium, including the stockpile, and nuclear material produced from it are subject to stringent nuclear safeguards. It may only be transferred to countries which are parties to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty with which Australia has concluded bilateral nuclear safeguards agreements.

(6) Under these bilateral agreements, Australia's prior consent is required before Australian Obligated Nuclear (AON) material may be re-transferred beyond any bilateral partner's jurisdiction. Such consent would only be given by Australia for re-transfer to other countries in the network of Australia's bilateral nuclear safeguards agreements.

(7) Yes. All AON material, upon initial transfer to another country, or after a re-transfer to a third party, is subject to international Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) safeguards, and verification of non-diversion is carried out by the IAEA. Under our bilateral safeguards agreements the Australian Safeguards Office (ASO) accounts for all such AON material as it moves through the fuel cycles of, and/or is re-transferred between, Australia's bilateral partners. Detailed documentation on transfers and re-transfers, and regular reports of each bilateral partner's holdings of AON material are provided by the ASO. By comparing reports with its own calculations and by conducting regular `reconciliation' visits to each bilateral partner, ASO verifies the AON material is properly accounted for by them.
(8) Yes. The transfers and re-transfers of AON material between the jurisdictions of Australia's bilateral partners are reported each year in the Annual Report of the Director of Safeguards.
(9)(1)(b) and (4). For reasons stated above further information on the terms and conditions of sale cannot be provided.

talk.start.para:
â€”On 1 September 1994 (
Hansard
, page 798) Senator Ellison asked me the following question without notice in relation to a native title claim by the Miriuwung Gajerrong people:

para.tab: Can the Minister advise as to whether he believes that it is an appropriate course of action to engage in mediation with each of the respondents, bearing in mind there are so many and that there could be numerous respondents in other cases? Is this a procedure that the Minister endorses?
The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The question of appropriate procedures for applications for a determination of native title is a matter for the President of the National Native Title Tribunal. The President has issued guidelines for processing applications for a determination of native title. These guidelines include procedures for dealing with large numbers of parties and for the conduct of mediation conferences.

In relation to the conduct of mediation conferences the guidelines state that the Tribunal may conduct meetings between the mediator and all the parties together as well as meetings between the mediator and one or more parties separately or privately.

The first mediation conference in this claim was held on 20 September 1994. At that conference the Tribunal outlined the mediation process. The meeting was followed in the next 2 days by a series of meetings with particular interest groups. Further meetings will be held in late October.
The Tribunal is also conducting separate meetings with the parties to identify similar interests.

Given the common nature of many of the interests involved, the Tribunal is having no difficulty arising from the number of persons seeking to become parties. In 2 cases, common interests are represented by community groups.

This is the first stage in the mediation process. If it becomes clear that it is not possible to resolve the claim by mediation the President will refer the claim to the Federal Court for a decision rather than prolong the mediation process.
